book.name: Isaiah
book.info: About sixty-four years, from around 760 B.C., a few years before the death of King Uzziah (Azariah), to about 696 B.C., a few years after the death of Hezekiah ([link]6:1[/link]; [link]1:1[/link]).
book.subject: The Salvation of Jehovah through the Incarnated, Crucified, Resurrected, Ascended, and Coming Christ

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]vision of [note]1[/note]Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of [xref]b[/xref]Uzziah, [xref]c[/xref]Jotham, [xref]d[/xref]Ahaz, [i]and[/i] [xref]e[/xref]Hezekiah, the kings of Judah:
verse.note: Meaning [i]the salvation of Jah.[/i] The book of Isaiah, in its content concerning God's eternal economy in Christ, is the leading book among all the books of the prophets. This book is the vision that Isaiah saw ([link]v. 1[/link]), the word that Isaiah saw ([link]2:1[/link]), and the burden that Isaiah saw ([link]13:1[/link]; [link]15:1[/link]). The vision, word, and burden in Isaiah are concerned with God's eternal economy in Christ, which is thoroughly covered in this book.[br][br]The book of Isaiah unveils that God's dealing in love with His beloved Israel and His righteous judgment upon the nations bring in Christ, the Savior ([link]43:3[/link]; [link]49:26[/link]), who is God ([link]9:6[/link]) incarnated to be a man ([link]7:14[/link]), possessing both the divine nature and the human nature ([link]4:2[/link]), living on this earth ([link]53:2-3[/link]; [link]42:1-4[/link]), crucified ([link]53:7-10a[/link], [link]12[/link]), resurrected ([link]53:10b-11[/link]), ascended ([link]52:13[/link]), and coming ([link]40:10[/link]; [link]64:1[/link]) to meet the need of God's chosen people and the nations ([link]9:1-7[/link]; [link]49:6[/link]) in God's all-inclusive salvation ([link]12:2-3[/link]), that the restoration of all things, of the created yet fallen universe ([link]2:2-5[/link]; [link]11:6-9[/link]; [link]35:1-10[/link]; [link]30:26[/link]), may be brought in, which will consummate in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]65:17[/link]). Hence, the content of Isaiah covers God's entire economy of the New Testament, from the incarnation ([link]Matt. 1:18-25[/link]) to the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21-22[/link]), with the Old Testament background of God's dealing with Israel and His judgment upon the nations. According to Isaiah's prophecy, the Christ who was processed for the divine purposes is the centrality and universality of the great wheel of the move of the Divine Trinity ([link]Ezek. 1:15[/link] and note 1) for the accomplishing of His economy in the divine dispensing of Himself into His elect.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Hear, O heavens, and hearken, O earth, / For Jehovah has spoken: / I have brought up [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]children, and I have raised [i]them;[/i] / And [i]yet[/i] they have rebelled against Me.
verse.note: In the book of Isaiah, God's love toward Israel is exercised in a threefold way: as a Father ([link]1:2-3[/link]; [link]63:16[/link]; [link]64:8[/link]), as a nursing Mother ([link]66:13[/link]), and as a Husband ([link]54:5[/link]). Since God deals with His beloved Israel in a loving way, His dealing with them, in general, is a matter not of judgment but of chastisement. God's dealing with the Gentiles, the nations, however, is a matter of judgment based on God's righteousness, on His justice.[br][br]God deals with people according to what He is. God is holy and righteous; He is the Holy One and the righteous One ([link]v. 4[/link]; [link]24:16a[/link]). As the Holy One, He chastises His people that they may be holy ([link]Heb. 12:10[/link]), and as the righteous One, He judges the nations because they are not just and righteous. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].

verse.text: The ox knows his owner, / And the donkey, his master's manger; / [i]But[/i] Israel does [xref]a[/xref]not know, / My people do not much consider.

Alas, sinful nation, / A people heavy with iniquity, / [xref]a[/xref]Seed of evildoers, / Children acting corruptly! / They have forsaken Jehovah; / They have despised the Holy One of Israel; / They have become estranged [i]and have gone[/i] backward.
[note]1[/note]Where will you be stricken again? / Will you continue [i]your[/i] [note]2[/note]apostasy? / The whole head has become sick, / And the whole heart faint;
verse.note: Or, Why.
Jehovah chastised the children of Israel because of their apostasy, i.e., their forsaking God and turning to and serving another god ([link]Jer. 2:13[/link]).

verse.text: From the sole of the foot even to the head, / There is no soundness in it, / [i]Only[/i] bruises and blows / And raw wounds — / They have not been pressed out nor [xref]a[/xref]bound up / Nor softened with oil.
Your land is a desolation; / Your cities are burned with fire; / Your field — in your sight / Strangers devour it; / It is a desolation, like something overthrown by strangers.
And the [xref]a[/xref]daughter of Zion is left / Like a booth in a vineyard, / Like a hut in a cucumber field, / Like a besieged city.
[xref]a[/xref]Unless Jehovah [note]1[/note]of hosts / Had left to us a surviving few, / We would have been like [xref]b[/xref]Sodom, / We would have resembled Gomorrah.
verse.note: Or, Sabaoth. So throughout the book.

verse.text: Hear the word of Jehovah, / You rulers of Sodom; / Hearken to the instruction of our God, / You people of Gomorrah.

What is the multitude of your [xref]a[/xref]sacrifices to Me? / Says Jehovah. / I have had My fill of burnt offerings of rams / And the fat of fed cattle; / The blood of bulls and lambs / And goats, I do not delight in.
When you come to [xref]a[/xref]appear before Me, / Who has required this of your hand, / To trample My courts?
Bring no more vain offerings; / Incense is an abomination to Me. / New moon and Sabbath, the calling of convocations — / I cannot bear iniquity and the solemn assembly.
Your new moons and your appointed feasts / My soul [xref]a[/xref]hates; / They have become a burden on Me; / I am weary of bearing [i]them.[/i]
Thus, when you spread forth your [xref]a[/xref]hands, / I will hide My eyes from you; / Even though you multiply [i]your[/i] prayers, / I will not hear. / Your hands are full of [xref]b[/xref]blood;
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Wash yourselves; cleanse yourselves. / Turn away the evil of your deeds / From before My eyes. / Cease doing what is [xref]b[/xref]evil;
verse.note: After Jehovah's chastisement on His beloved children, Isaiah presents Jehovah's loving exhortation ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]) and promise to His chastised people. Jehovah's loving promise is a promise of forgiveness ([link]v. 18[/link]) and of restoration ([link]vv. 26-27[/link]).

verse.text: Learn to do good. / Seek justice; / Correct the ruthless. / Defend the [xref]a[/xref]orphan; / Plead for the widow.

Come now and let us reason together, / Says Jehovah. / Though your sins are like scarlet, / They will be as [xref]a[/xref]white as [note]1[/note]snow; / Though they are as red as crimson, / They will be like [note]1[/note]wool.
verse.note: In God's full salvation He not only forgives our sins, exempting us from the penalty of our sins and removing the record of our sins from before Him; He also washes away the traces of sins in us, making us as white as snow and white like wool. Both snow and wool are naturally white. Hence, as a result of God's washing, we become not only white but also naturally white, as if we had never been defiled. The washing that makes us as white as snow is a positional washing from without through the blood of Jesus Christ ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3b[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5[/link]), whereas the washing that makes us white like wool is a washing of our nature metabolically from within by God's Spirit and by His life ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link] and note; [link]Titus 3:5[/link] and note 4). Cf. note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 1[/link].

verse.text: If you are willing and listen, / You will eat the good of the land;
But if you refuse and rebel, / You will be devoured by the sword; / For the mouth of Jehovah has spoken.
How the faithful city / Has become a [xref]a[/xref]harlot! / She who was full of justice, / She in whom righteousness [i]once[/i] lodged, / But now murderers!
Your silver has become dross; / Your wine diluted with water;
Your rulers are rebellious / And companions of thieves; / They all love bribes / And chase after rewards; / They do not defend the orphan, / Nor does the widow's plea come before them.
Hence, the Lord Jehovah of hosts, / The Mighty One of Israel, declares: / Ah, I will ease Myself of My [note]1[/note]adversaries, / And I will avenge Myself of My [note]1[/note]enemies;
verse.note: Cf. note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link]. God chastised Israel because Israel had rebelled against God to such an extent that they became not only His adversaries, who were within God's nation, but also His enemies, who were outside God's nation.

verse.text: And I will turn My hand against you. / I will thoroughly [xref]a[/xref]purge away your dross as with lye, / And I will remove all your alloy.
And I will restore your judges as at the first / And your counselors as at the beginning. / Afterward you will be called the city of righteousness, / The faithful city.
Zion will be ransomed with justice, / And her returning ones with righteousness.
And [i]there will be[/i] the shattering of rebels and sinners together, / And those who forsake Jehovah will meet their end.
For [note]1[/note]you will be ashamed of the [note]2[/note]terebinths / That you have taken pleasure in; / And you will be embarrassed at the gardens / That you have chosen.
verse.note: Many MSS read, they.
Trees used in the worship of idols.

verse.text: For you will be like a terebinth / Whose leaves are falling, / And like a garden / In which there is no water;
And the strong man will become [note]1[/note]tow, / And his work a spark; / And they will both burn together, / And there will be none to extinguish [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: I.e., fibers shaken off from flax when beaten.

verse.text: The word which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

[xref]a[/xref]But in the [xref]b[/xref]last days / The [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]mountain of the house of Jehovah will be established / On the top of the mountains; / And it will be lifted up above the hills; / And all the [xref]d[/xref]nations will stream to it,
verse.note: The mountain here signifies the kingdom of Israel, whereas the mountains and the hills later in the verse signify the kingdoms of the nations. In the restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 3:21[/link]) the nation of Israel will be the foremost among the nations.

verse.text: And many peoples will come and say, / [xref]a[/xref]Come and let us go up to the [xref]b[/xref]mountain of Jehovah, / To the house of the God of Jacob, / That He may instruct us [note]1[/note]in His ways, / And that we may walk in His paths. / For from Zion will go forth [note]2[/note]instruction, / And the word of Jehovah from [xref]c[/xref]Jerusalem;
verse.note: Lit., out of; indicating the source of His instruction.

Heb. [i]torah,[/i] frequently translated [i]law[/i]. During the millennium, the thousand-year kingdom, the restored nation of Israel will be the priests in the earthly part of the kingdom ([link]61:6[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]), the kingdom of the Son of Man ([link]Matt. 13:41[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), and the overcoming believers in Christ will be the priests in the heavenly part ([link]Rev. 20:6[/link]), the kingdom of the Father ([link]Matt. 13:43[/link]). By this priesthood all the peoples of the nations will be taught and instructed. See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Zech. 8[/link].

verse.text: And He will [note]1[/note]judge between the nations, / And will decide [i]matters[/i] for many peoples. / [xref]a[/xref]And they will beat their swords into plowshares, / And their spears into pruning knives; / Nation will not lift up sword against nation, / Nor will they learn [xref]b[/xref]war anymore.
verse.note: In the restoration Christ will be the unique ruler on earth. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 32[/link].

verse.text: House of Jacob, come and let us [xref]a[/xref]walk in the light of Jehovah.

For You have abandoned Your people, / The house of Jacob; / Because they are full of [i]customs from[/i] the east, / And they are soothsayers like the Philistines, / And they clasp hands with the children of foreigners.
Their land is full of [note]1[/note]silver and gold, / And their treasures are limitless; / Their land is also full of horses, / And their chariots are limitless.
verse.note: The nations were rich not only in money but also in idols ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]20[/link]). Idols and money go together. This is the reason that money is called mammon ([link]Matt. 6:24[/link]; [link]Luke 16:9[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]13[/link]). Because the nations trusted in idols, God judged them in order to humiliate them ([link]vv. 9-22[/link]).

verse.text: And their land is [xref]a[/xref]full of idols; / They bow down to the work of their hands, / To that which their fingers have made.
Thus the ordinary man is humbled, and the man of distinction is abased — / But do not forgive them.
Enter into the [xref]a[/xref]rock, / And hide in the dust, / From the dread of Jehovah, / And from the splendor of His majesty.
Man's [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]haughty look will be abased, / And the loftiness of men will be humbled; / But Jehovah alone will be exalted / In that day.
verse.note: Because the nations were haughty, it was necessary for Jehovah to humiliate them, to bring them down, through judgment. God's judgment on the haughty nations ushers in the God-man, Christ ([link]4:2[/link], [link]5-6[/link]), issuing in the restoration of the nation of Israel ([link]4:3-6[/link]; [link]2:2-5[/link]), which brings in the kingdom and consummates in the new heaven and new earth ([link]65:17[/link]).

verse.text: For Jehovah of hosts will have a [note]1[/note]day / Over everything proud and lofty, / And over everything lifted up that it may be abased;
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 1[/link].

verse.text: Over all the [note]1[/note]cedars of Lebanon, / Which are lofty and lifted up, / And over all the [note]1[/note]oaks of Bashan;
verse.note: Typifying lofty persons, those who lift themselves up.

verse.text: Over all the [note]1[/note]lofty mountains, / And over all the [note]1[/note]hills that are lifted up;
verse.note: In figure signifying countries, nations, and kingdoms.

verse.text: Over every high tower, / And over every fortified wall;
Over all the ships of Tarshish, / And over all their pleasant [note]1[/note]artifacts.
verse.note: Or, images. The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]haughtiness of the ordinary man will be humbled, / And the loftiness of the men of distinction will be abased; / But Jehovah alone will be exalted / In that day.
And the idols will vanish completely.

And [i]men[/i] will go into caves in the [xref]a[/xref]rocks / And into holes in the dust, / From the dread of Jehovah, / And from the splendor of His majesty, / When He arises to make the earth tremble.
In that day a man will cast / His idols of silver and his idols of gold, / Which they made for themselves to bow down to, / To the moles and to the bats,

So that they may go into the crevices of the rocks / And into the clefts of the cliffs, / From the dread of Jehovah, / And from the splendor of His majesty, / When He arises to make the earth tremble.
Stop regarding man, / Whose [i]life[/i] breath is in his nostrils. / For of what [i]value[/i] is he considered to be?
For now the Lord Jehovah of hosts / Is [xref]a[/xref]taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah / Every kind of support — / All the support of bread / And all the support of water;
The mighty man and the man of war, / The judge and the prophet, / And the diviner and the elder;
The captain of fifty and the highly regarded; / And the counselor, the wise magician, and the knowledgeable enchanter.
And I will make [xref]a[/xref]youths their rulers, / And capriciousness will rule over them.
And the people will be oppressed, each by the other, / And each by his neighbor. / The youth will be arrogant to the elder, / And the contemned one to the one who is honored.
When a man takes hold of his brother / In his father's house [i]and says,[/i] / You have clothing, you be our ruler, / And these ruins will be under your hand;
He will solemnly say, / I will not be the one who binds [i]your wounds,[/i] / For in my house there is no [note]1[/note]food or clothing; / Do not appoint me as [note]1[/note]ruler of the people.
verse.note: As part of His chastisement of His people, God took away from them all their rulers, leaving them with no rulers ([link]vv. 2-4[/link]). Here Isaiah links the ruler with the food supply. To be a ruler, one must feed the people. Ruling and feeding are not only a pair; they also work together in a cycle and give rise to each other. Thus, if there is feeding, there is ruling, and if there is ruling, there is feeding. In the church, when there is the proper feeding, everything will be in order.

verse.text: For Jerusalem stumbles, / And Judah falls, / Because their speech and their actions are against Jehovah, / To rebel against the eyes of His glory.
The countenance of their faces witnesses against them, / And they declare their sin like [xref]a[/xref]Sodom; / They do not hide it. / Woe to their soul! / For they have brought evil upon themselves.
Say to the righteous that [i]it will go[/i] well [i]with them,[/i] / For they will eat the fruit of their actions.
Woe to the wicked man! [i]It will go[/i] badly [i]with him;[/i] / For the result of his deeds will be done to him
My people — their oppressors are children, / And women rule over them. / O My people, those who lead you are leading you astray; / And the path for your ways they have hidden.
Jehovah stands firm to contend, / And He stands to judge the people.
Jehovah will enter into judgment / With the elders of His people and their rulers. / [i]It is[/i] you [i]who[/i] have consumed the vineyard; / The spoil of the poor is in your houses.
What do you mean by crushing My people / And grinding the faces of the poor? / Declares the Lord Jehovah of hosts.

Moreover Jehovah said, / Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, / And walk around with outstretched necks / And lusting eyes, / And trip along with quick, little steps, / And rattle the anklets on their feet;
The Lord will strike the scalp of the daughters of Zion with scabs, / And Jehovah will expose their secret parts.
In that day the Lord will remove the beauty of [i]their[/i] anklets, headbands, and crescents;
The ear pendants, the bracelets, and the costly veils;
The headdresses, the ankle chains, the sashes, the bottles of aromas, and the amulets;
The [i]finger[/i] rings and the nose rings;
The formal gowns, the frocks, the wraps, and the purses;
The mirrors, the fine linen garments, the turbans, and the veils.

And instead of a sweet smell there will be rottenness; / And instead of a belt, an encircling rope; / Instead of well-set hair, baldness; / And instead of fine garments, the girding of oneself with sackcloth; / A brand instead of beauty.
Your men will fall by the sword, / And your mighty, in battle;
Then her gates will mourn and lament, / And she, being desolated, will sit on the ground.
And seven [note]1[/note]women will grasp / One man in that day, / Saying, We will eat our own bread / And wear our own clothes; / Just let us bear your name; / Take away our [xref]a[/xref]reproach.
verse.note: This verse is a link between God's judgment ([link]ch. 3[/link]) and Christ. According to [link]v. 2[/link], to these women who escaped God's judgment, Christ as the Shoot of Jehovah will be beauty and glory, and Christ as the fruit of the earth will be excellence and splendor. This is the ushering in of the God-man, Christ, through God's judgment.

verse.text: In [note]1[/note]that day the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shoot of Jehovah will be beauty and glory, and the [note]2[/note]fruit of the earth, excellence and splendor, to those of Israel who have escaped.
verse.note: The day of the coming restoration of the nation of Israel ([link]Matt. 17:11[/link]; [link]19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 1:6[/link]; [link]3:21[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]).

In this book Christ is unveiled as the God-man. [i]The Shoot of Jehovah[/i] refers to Christ's deity, showing His divine nature, and [i]the fruit of the earth[/i] ([link]Luke 1:42[/link]) refers to Christ's humanity with His human nature. As the Shoot of Jehovah, Christ comes out of God, out of eternity ([link]John 8:42[/link]; [link]Micah 5:2[/link]). As the fruit of the earth, Christ, having a human body made of dust ([link]Gen. 2:7[/link]), grows out of the earth (cf. [link]53:2[/link]). In the restoration, to those of Israel who have escaped, Christ in His deity will be beauty and glory, and in His humanity, which expresses His divine beauty and glory, He will be excellence and splendor. [i]The Shoot of Jehovah[/i] denotes that through His incarnation Christ is a new development of Jehovah God for the Triune God to branch Himself out in His divinity into humanity ([link]7:14[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:22-23[/link]). This is for Jehovah God's increase and spread in the universe. [i]The fruit of the earth[/i] denotes that Christ, as the divine Shoot of Jehovah, also becomes a man of flesh from the earth ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). This is for the Triune God to be multiplied and reproduced in humanity. As a man with the divine life, He is a seed, a grain of wheat, to produce many grains, His believers as His many brothers, through His death and resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]20:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]).[br][br][i]The Shoot of Jehovah[/i] denotes the riches, the refreshing, the vigor, the growth, and the productive power of the divine life. [i]The fruit of the earth[/i] denotes the produce brought forth, carried out, and expressed in Christ's humanity. As seen in the four Gospels, all the fruit born by Christ came out of the divine life, but it was produced in Christ's humanity. In Christ, the God-man, God and man live together as one, with God as the life inwardly and man as the fruit outwardly.

verse.text: And he who is left over in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been [xref]a[/xref]written down in Jerusalem for life;

When the Lord has [xref]a[/xref]washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and has cleansed away the bloodstains of Jerusalem from her midst, by the [note]1[/note]judging Spirit and the burning Spirit.
verse.note: Lit., the Spirit of judgment and the Spirit of burning.

verse.text: Jehovah will create over the entire region of Mount Zion and over all her convocations a [xref]a[/xref]cloud of smoke by day, and the brightness of a [xref]b[/xref]fiery flame by night; for the glory will be a [note]1[/note]canopy over all.
verse.note: In the restoration Christ as the Shoot of Jehovah in His divinity and the fruit of the earth in His humanity will be a covering canopy of glory and an overshadowing tabernacle of grace ([link]v. 6[/link]). The canopy is the covering glory of Christ in His divinity that will cover the entire region of Mount Zion and all its convocations, i.e., all the interests of Jehovah God on the earth. The glory of Christ will cover this entire region as a canopy of two sections: a cloud of smoke for a shade from the heat in the daytime, and a cloud of brightness of a fiery flame to keep the darkness away at night (cf. [link]Exo. 40:38[/link]; [link]Num. 9:15[/link]). The tabernacle ([link]v. 6[/link]) is the God-man, Christ, in His humanity with His grace to be the overshadowing protection and defense for God's chosen people ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 12:9[/link]).

verse.text: And there will be a tabernacle as a daytime shade from the heat and as a refuge and a [xref]a[/xref]cover from storm and rain.
Let me sing of my Beloved, / A song of my Beloved concerning His [xref]a[/xref]vineyard. / My Beloved had a vineyard / On a [note]1[/note]fertile hill.
verse.note: Lit., horn of a son of oil.

verse.text: And He dug it up and cleared away its stones, / And He planted it with the choicest vine. / Then He built a tower in the middle of it, / And hewed out a wine vat in it. / And He looked for it to produce grapes, / But it produced only wild grapes.
So then, you inhabitants of Jerusalem / And you men of Judah, / Judge between Me / And My vineyard.
What more could I have done for My vineyard / That I have not [i]already[/i] done for it? / Why then, when I looked for it to produce grapes, / Did it produce [i]only[/i] wild grapes?

And now I will make known to you / What I will now do to My vineyard: / I will remove its [xref]a[/xref]hedge, and it will be consumed; / I will break down its wall, and it will become a trampled place.
And I will make it a waste; / It will not be pruned, nor will it be hoed; / But thorns and thistles will come [i]on it.[/i] / And I will command the clouds / Not to rain upon it.

For the vineyard of Jehovah of hosts is the house of Israel, / And the men of Judah, the plant of His good pleasure; / And He expected justice, but instead, bloodshed! / [i]He expected[/i] righteousness, but instead, an outcry of distress!
Woe to those who join house to house, / Who lay field to field, / Till there is no place left, / And you dwell alone in the midst of the land!
In my ears Jehovah of hosts [i]has sworn:[/i] / Many houses shall indeed become desolate; / Great ones and fine ones [i]shall be[/i] without inhabitants.
For ten acres of vineyard will produce a [i]mere[/i] [note]1[/note]bath [i]of wine,[/i] / And a [note]2[/note]homer of seed will produce an [note]3[/note]ephah [i]of grain.[/i]
verse.note: A liquid measure equal to approximately six gallons, or twenty-two liters.
A dry measure equal to somewhere between four and eight bushels, or 140 and 280 liters.
One-tenth of a homer.

verse.text: Woe to those who rise early in the morning / That they may run after liquor, / To those who linger into the evening / That wine may inflame them!
Lyre and harp, tambourine and flute, / And wine are [i]the essence of[/i] their banquets; / And they do not consider what has been done by Jehovah, / Nor do they regard the work of His hands.
Hence, my people go into [xref]a[/xref]exile / For lack of knowledge; / Their [note]1[/note]nobility [i]become[/i] famished men, / And their multitudes, parched with thirst.
verse.note: Lit., glory.

verse.text: Hence, Sheol enlarges its appetite / And opens its mouth wide, without limit, / And [i]Jerusalem's[/i] splendor descends, and her din / And her uproar and the jubilant within her.
Thus the ordinary man is humbled, and the man of distinction is abased; / And the eyes of the [xref]a[/xref]haughty are abased;
But Jehovah of hosts is exalted in judgment, / And the holy God [note]1[/note]shows Himself [note]2[/note]holy in righteousness.
verse.note: Or, is sanctified.

Righteousness is the base for holiness, and on this base holiness is exhibited. Hence, holiness is higher than righteousness. With His righteousness as the base, God shows Himself as the holy God. In righteousness He exhibits His holiness.[br][br]God could expect only righteousness from the nations because they are not the sons of God. It is with His sons that God expects to see holiness ([link]Eph. 1:4-5[/link]). God's chastening and disciplining is to uplift us from righteousness to holiness ([link]Heb. 12:5-11[/link]). In His salvation He first justifies us to make us righteous in Christ ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]), and then He sanctifies us to make us holy ([link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]). To be righteous is to match God's way of doing things outwardly, but to be holy is to match God's nature inwardly.

verse.text: Then lambs will graze [i]there[/i] as in their pasture, / And strangers will eat the wastelands of [note]1[/note]fat men.
verse.note: I.e., rich men.

verse.text: Woe to those who draw iniquity with ropes of vanity, / And sin as with cart ropes;
Who say, He should hurry up; / He should hasten His work, / So that we may see [i]it;[/i] / And the counsel of the Holy One of Israel / Should draw near and happen, / So that we may know [i]it![/i]
Woe to those who [xref]a[/xref]call evil good, / And good evil; / Who put darkness for light, / And light for darkness; / Who put bitter for sweet, / And sweet for bitter!
Woe to those who are [xref]a[/xref]wise in their own eyes, / And prudent in their own sight!
Woe to those who are heroes in drinking wine, / And men of valor in mixing liquor;
Who acquit the criminal as a result of a bribe, / But refuse righteousness to the righteous!

Therefore as a tongue of fire consumes the stubble, / And the chaff sinks in flames, / Their root will be like decay, / And their bud will disappear like dust; / For they have rejected the instruction of Jehovah of hosts / And despised the speaking of the Holy One of Israel.

For this reason the anger of Jehovah burns against His people, / And He stretches out His [xref]a[/xref]hand over them and strikes them. / And the mountains quake, and their corpses are / Like garbage in the middle of the street. / In spite of all this His anger is not turned away; / Rather, His hand is still stretched out.

He also lifts up a [xref]a[/xref]standard to a distant [note]1[/note]nation, / And [xref]b[/xref]whistles to it from the [xref]c[/xref]ends of the earth; / And indeed it comes with [xref]d[/xref]swift speed.
verse.note: I.e., Babylon.

verse.text: None [i]of them[/i] is weary, and none stumbles among them; / No one slumbers or sleeps; / And their belts are not loosened at their waists, / Nor are their sandal thongs broken.
The arrows of these are sharpened, / And all their bows are drawn; / The hooves of their horses are considered to be like flint, / And their chariot wheels like a whirlwind.
Their roar is like a lion's, / And they roar like young lions; / When they growl and seize prey, / They carry [i]it[/i] away safe, and there is none to rescue [i]it.[/i]

And they will growl over it in that day, / Like the roaring of the sea. / When one will look upon the land, indeed, there will be darkness [i]and[/i] distress, / And the light will be darkened with its clouds.
In the year that King [xref]a[/xref]Uzziah died I saw the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Lord sitting on a high and lofty throne, and the train of His [note]2[/note]robe filled the temple.
verse.note: The One who appeared to Isaiah in his disappointment over the condition of the children of Israel was Christ as the Lord, the King, Jehovah of hosts ([link]v. 5b[/link]; [link]John 12:41[/link] and note). No matter what the situation might be on earth and regardless of the corruption and degradation among God's people, Christ is still on the throne in His glory. The people had become fallen, but Christ and His throne remained the same in His glory. On this earth everything changes and fluctuates, but Christ remains the same today and forever ([link]Heb. 13:8[/link]). Hence, we should not look down at the situation on earth but should look up to Christ on the throne ([link]Heb. 12:2[/link]).

Christ's long robe signifies Christ's splendor in His virtues, which is expressed mainly in and through His humanity. That Christ was wearing a long robe indicates that He appeared to Isaiah in the image of a man. Christ is the God-man with the divine glory expressed in His human virtues.

verse.text: Seraphim [note]1[/note]hovered over [note]2[/note]Him, each having six wings: With [xref]a[/xref]two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
verse.note: Lit., stood. The seraphim signify or represent the holiness of Christ ([link]v. 3[/link]). They were standing there for Christ's holiness.
Or, it; referring to the train of His robe.

verse.text: And one called to the other, saying:[br/][note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Holy, holy, holy, Jehovah of hosts; / The whole [xref]b[/xref]earth is filled with His glory.
verse.note: This was a praise rendered to Christ in His holiness. In this chapter Christ is seen in His divine glory (signified by the smoke — [link]v. 4[/link]) with His human virtues (signified by the train of His robe — [link]v. 1[/link]) held in His holiness (signified by the seraphim standing firmly — [link]v. 2[/link]). Christ's holiness is based on His righteousness (see note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]). Because Christ was always righteous, He was sanctified, separated from the common people ([link]Heb. 7:26[/link]). Cf. note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 4[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]foundations of the threshold [note]2[/note]shook at the voice of him who called, and the house was [xref]a[/xref]filled with [note]2[/note]smoke.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; the Septuagint translates this phrase as [i]lintel.[/i]
The shaking of the foundations signifies solemnity, whereas the temple being filled with smoke signifies glory burning in awe. The smoke signifies Christ's glory (cf. [link]4:5[/link]).

verse.text: Then I said,[br/]Woe is me, for I am finished! / For I am a man of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]unclean lips, / And in the midst of a people of [note]1[/note]unclean lips I dwell; / Yet my eyes have [xref]b[/xref]seen the King, Jehovah of hosts.
verse.note: Everyone who truly sees a vision of the Lord in His glory is enlightened in his conscience regarding his uncleanness (cf. [link]Luke 5:8[/link]).

verse.text: Then one of the seraphim flew to me with an [note]1[/note]ember in his hand, [i]which[/i] he had taken from the [xref]a[/xref]altar with a pair of tongs.
verse.note: The ember from the altar signifies the effectiveness of Christ's redemption accomplished on the cross.

verse.text: And he touched my [xref]a[/xref]mouth [i]with it[/i] and said,[br/]Now that this has touched your lips, / Your iniquity is taken away, and your sin is [note]1[/note]purged.
verse.note: Or, expiated. The more we see the Lord and are exposed, the more we are cleansed ([link]1 John 1:7[/link] and note 3). According to our enlightened conscience, we are clean, but according to the actual facts of our situation in the old creation, we are not clean, for the old creation is unclean (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 12[/link] and notes on [link]1 John 1:8[/link]). After our body is redeemed ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:21[/link]), we will no longer be in the old creation. At that time we will be completely clean.

verse.text: Then I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, Whom shall [note]1[/note]I send? Who will go for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Us? And I said, [xref]b[/xref]Here am I; send me.
verse.note: The words [i]I[/i] and [i]Us[/i] here indicate that the One speaking is triune, that this One is not merely Christ but Christ as the embodiment of the Triune God. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup], par. 1, in Gen. 1[/link].

verse.text: And He said to me, [note]1[/note]Go and say to this people,[br/][xref]a[/xref]Hear indeed, but do not perceive; / And see indeed, but do [xref]b[/xref]not understand.
verse.note: Isaiah was sent by the Christ who is full of the divine glory and the human virtues held in His holiness, to a people who were short of the divine glory, were violating the divine holiness, and were corrupt in the human virtues ([link]v. 5[/link]). After sending the prophets to Israel, God sent His Son and then sent the New Testament apostles, to bring His chosen people into a state of living Christ ([link]Phil. 1:21a[/link]) that they might express His divine glory with His human virtues in His holiness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Make the [xref]b[/xref]heart of this people numb; / Dull their ears, / And seal their [xref]c[/xref]eyes; / Lest they see with their eyes and hear with their [xref]d[/xref]ears, / And their heart perceive and return, and they are [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]healed.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 9-10[/link] indicates that there would be no way for the people of Israel to be healed and recovered. Except for the word concerning the holy seed in [link]v. 13[/link], the prophetic warning in [link]vv. 9-13[/link], given in approximately 758 B.C., has been fulfilled. It was fulfilled beginning in about 605 B.C. by the Babylonian invasion and captivity ([link]2 Kings 24-25[/link]). This warning was quoted by the Lord Jesus in [link]Matt. 13:14-15[/link], and again by the apostle Paul in [link]Acts 28:25-27[/link], as a reminder to the rebellious and stubborn Jews under their ministry. Both the Lord's reminding and the apostle's reminding were fulfilled in A.D. 70 by the Roman army under Titus ([link]Matt. 23:37-38[/link]; [link]24:2[/link]). Furthermore, after A.D. 70 this warning has been fulfilled throughout the centuries.

verse.text: And I said, For how long, Lord? And He said,[br/]Until cities lie devastated, / Without inhabitants, / And houses are without people, / And the land is [xref]a[/xref]devastated and a waste;
And Jehovah has sent men far away [i]from it,[/i] / And desolate places abound in the midst of the land.
But there will still be a tenth part in it; / And it in turn is to be burned / Like a terebinth or an oak, / Whose stump remains after its felling; / Its stump will be a [xref]a[/xref]holy seed.
verse.xref: Ezra 9:2; Isa. 65:9; Mal. 2:15; cf. Isa. 1:9; Rom. 11:5

verse.text: In the days of [xref]a[/xref]Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, the king of Judah, Rezin the king of Aram and Pekah the son of Remaliah, the king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to [i]wage[/i] war against it, but they were not able to prevail against it.
And it was reported to the house of David that Aram allied with [note]1[/note]Ephraim, and his heart and the heart of his people quivered as the trees of the forest quiver in the face of a wind.
verse.note: Representing the northern kingdom of Israel.

verse.text: Then Jehovah said to Isaiah, Go out to meet Ahaz, you and [note]1[/note]Shear-jashub your son, at the end of the conduit of the [xref]a[/xref]upper pool, on the road to the Fuller's Field;
verse.note: Meaning [i]a remnant will return.[/i]

verse.text: And say to him, Be careful and be quiet; do not fear, and do not be fainthearted because of these two smoking firebrand stubs, at the burning anger of Rezin and Aram, and the son of Remaliah.
Because Aram [i]and[/i] Ephraim and the son of Remaliah have planned evil against you, saying,
Let us go up against Judah and make it sick with terror and break it open for ourselves, and let us set the son of Tabel in its midst as king;
Thus says the Lord Jehovah, / It shall not stand, and it shall not happen;
For the head of Aram is Damascus, / And the head of Damascus is Rezin; / [xref]a[/xref]And in another sixty-five years / Ephraim will be shattered as a people.
And the head of Ephraim is Samaria, / And the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah; / If you do not believe, surely you will not remain standing.
Then Jehovah spoke further to Ahaz, saying,
Ask for a sign from Jehovah your God; [note]1[/note]make [i]it[/i] as deep as [note]2[/note]Sheol, or make it as high as high can go.
verse.note: Following some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, make the request deep.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: And Ahaz said, I will not ask, and I will not [xref]a[/xref]try Jehovah.
And he said, Hear now, O house of David, is it too small a thing for you to exhaust the patience of men that you will exhaust the patience of my God as well?

Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: [xref]a[/xref]Behold, the [xref]b[/xref]virgin will conceive and will [xref]c[/xref]bear a son, and she will call his name [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]Immanuel.
verse.note: Meaning [i]God with us.[/i] The actual fulfillment of this sign was the birth of a son by Isaiah's wife ([link]8:3[/link]). The ultimate fulfillment was the incarnation, in which Jesus Christ was born of the virgin Mary as a child of a dual nature, the divine nature and the human nature, issuing in Immanuel, i.e., God with us, for the salvation of God's people, including those of Israel and those of the church ([link]Matt. 1:20-23[/link] and notes). Christ, the God-man, the mingling of God and man, who is the Shoot of Jehovah and the fruit of the earth ([link]4:2[/link]), is Immanuel, God with us ([link]Matt. 18:20[/link]; [link]28:20[/link]). Immanuel is all-inclusive; He is first our Savior ([link]Luke 2:11[/link]), then our Redeemer ([link]John 1:29[/link]), then our Life-giver ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]), and then the all-inclusive indwelling Spirit ([link]John 14:16-20[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:9-11[/link]). Actually, the content of the entire New Testament is an Immanuel ([link]Matt. 1:23[/link]; [link]18:20[/link]; [link]28:20[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:3[/link]), and all the believers in Christ, as the members of Christ, are a part of this great Immanuel, the corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]). The sign of Immanuel consummates in the New Jerusalem, which will be the aggregate of Immanuel, the totality of God being with us.

verse.text: He will eat [xref]a[/xref]butter and honey [note]1[/note]until he knows how to refuse evil and choose good.
verse.note: This indicates that the lands of the two kings whom Ahaz dreaded would be abandoned, made desolate, by the king of Assyria ([link]v. 16[/link]). God sent the army from Assyria in the northeast to deal with the king of Aram and the king of Israel, who were threatening Ahaz ([link]7:17-25[/link]; [link]8:5-8[/link]).

verse.text: For before this boy knows how to refuse evil and choose good, the land whose two kings you dread will be abandoned.

Jehovah will bring upon you and your people and the house of your father such days as have not been [xref]a[/xref]since the days when Ephraim turned away from Judah; [i]He will[/i] [xref]b[/xref][i]bring upon you[/i] the king of Assyria.
And in that day Jehovah will [xref]a[/xref]whistle for the [note]1[/note]flies which are at the ends of the rivers of Egypt and for the [note]1[/note]bees which are in the land of Assyria.
verse.note: Signifying the soldiers.

verse.text: And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines and the clefts of the cliffs and on all the thornbushes and on all watering places.

In that day the Lord will shave with the [xref]a[/xref]razor hired from beyond the [note]1[/note]River, with the king of Assyria, the [note]2[/note]head and the [note]2[/note]hair of the legs; and it will take away the [note]2[/note]beard as well.
verse.note: I.e., the Euphrates.

The hair on the head signifies glory ([link]1 Cor. 11:7[/link], [link]15[/link]), the hair on other parts of the body signifies strength, and the beard signifies dignity. Thus, the glory, strength, and dignity of Judah would be removed through the "razor" of the king of Assyria.

verse.text: And in that day each man will keep alive [i]only[/i] a milk cow and two females of the flock.
And because of the abundance of milk produced, he will eat curds; for everyone left behind in the midst of the land will eat curds and honey.
And in that day every place where there could be a thousand vines, [i]worth[/i] a thousand shekels of silver, will become thorns and thistles.
[i]Men[/i] will come there with arrows and bow, for all the land will be thorns and thistles.
And to all the hills that once were hoed with the hoe you will not go for fear of thorns and thistles; but they will become a place for cattle to roam in and for sheep to trample.
Then Jehovah said to me, Take a large tablet and [xref]a[/xref]write on it in plain letters, For [note]1[/note]Maher-shalal-hash-baz;
verse.note: Meaning [i]swift is the booty, hastening is the prey.[/i] This name, given to Isaiah's son ([link]v. 3[/link]), indicates the carrying away of the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria before the king of Assyria ([link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And I will take faithful witnesses, [xref]a[/xref]Urijah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.
And I went to the prophetess, and she [note]1[/note]conceived and bore a son. And Jehovah said to me, Call his name Maher-shalal-hash-baz,
verse.note: This was the actual fulfillment of the sign spoken of in [link]7:14[/link]. See note there.

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]before this boy knows how to call, Father, and, Mother, they will carry off the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria before the king of Assyria.
Then Jehovah spoke further to me, saying,
Because these people have rejected / The gently flowing [note]1[/note]waters of [xref]a[/xref]Shiloah, and exult / In Rezin and the son of Remaliah,
verse.note: Signifying the tender blessings of the divine provision.

verse.text: Now therefore the Lord is bringing up upon them / The mighty and abundant [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]waters of the Euphrates, / The king of Assyria and all his glory; / And it will overflow all its channels, / And go over all its banks.
verse.note: Signifying the strong and great Assyrian army.

verse.text: It will sweep through Judah; it will overflow and rise / Until it reaches the neck; / And the spreading out of its wings / Will fill the breadth of Your [note]1[/note]land, O [xref]a[/xref]Immanuel.
verse.note: Indicating that the land of Judah, the Holy Land, is the territory of Christ, who is Immanuel, God with us. This land, which was invaded by the army of Assyria, is the land that Christ will inherit to build up His millennial kingdom with His two elect peoples, the chosen Jews as His earthly people and the chosen believers as His heavenly people. God's eternal economy is to gain for Himself these two peoples as a treasure.[br][br]Satan, God's enemy, uses the nations to frustrate the accomplishing of God's economy. The invaders and occupiers of the Holy Land, the land of Immanuel, are signified by the human image in [link]Dan. 2[/link], the head of which is Babylon. The enemies of God's people in the Old Testament began from Babylon ([link]2 Kings 24-25[/link]), which issued from Babel ([link]Gen. 11:1-9[/link]). In the New Testament the enemy of God's chosen people, the church, still is called Babylon — Babylon the Great ([link]Rev. 17-18[/link]). Eventually, both the religious Babylon (the apostate Roman Church) and the material Babylon (the city of Rome) will be destroyed, after which the kingdom will come. Even the termination of Babylon is included in the sign of a virgin bearing a son called Immanuel. The sign of Immanuel is still being fulfilled today. It is an all-inclusive sign that covers the Bible from [link]Gen. 11[/link] through [link]Rev. 22[/link]. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: Be broken, O peoples, and be shattered; / Hearken, all you distant places of the earth: / Gird yourselves, yet be shattered; / Gird yourselves, yet be shattered.
Take [xref]a[/xref]counsel, yet it will be frustrated; / Speak the word, yet it will not stand; / For [xref]b[/xref]God is with us.
For Jehovah spoke to me in this way with great force and instructed me not to walk in the way of this people, saying,
You shall not call it conspiracy / All that this people calls conspiracy; / And you shall not [xref]a[/xref]fear what they fear nor hold it in awe.
You shall [xref]a[/xref]sanctify Jehovah of hosts; / He shall be the One to fear and He shall be the One to hold in awe.

Then He will become a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctuary, yet a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stone to strike against / And a [note]1[/note]rock of [xref]c[/xref]stumbling / To both houses of Israel, / A trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verse.note: Christ the Immanuel becomes a sanctuary, i.e., the inner temple, the Holy of Holies, to God's chosen people, the place where they as God's priests live with God and worship and serve God ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:19[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]14:23[/link]; [link]15:5[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:22[/link]). He is also a smiting stone to the nations ([link]Matt. 21:44b[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:34-35[/link]), and He is a stone to strike against, a rock of stumbling, a trap, and a snare to the unbelieving ones and the opposers ([link]Matt. 21:44a[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:7-8[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:32-33[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:22-23[/link]). See notes on [link]Matt. 21:42[/link] and [link]44[/link].
verse.xref: Isa. 28:16; Matt. 21:44; Luke 20:18; Rom. 9:32; 1 Pet. 2:8[br/]See note 14[sup]1[/sup].

verse.text: And many will stumble [note]1[/note]at these, / And will fall and be broken to pieces, / And will be snared and taken captive.
verse.note: Or, among them.

verse.text: Bind up the [note]1[/note]testimony; seal the instruction among my disciples;
verse.note: I.e., the law. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link].

verse.text: And I will [xref]a[/xref]wait on Jehovah, who [xref]b[/xref]hides His face from the house of Jacob, and I will look eagerly for Him.
[xref]a[/xref]See, [note]1[/note]I and the [note]1[/note]children whom Jehovah has given me are for signs and wonders in Israel from Jehovah of hosts, who abides on Mount Zion.
verse.note: The prophet Isaiah and the children whom Jehovah had given to him typify Christ and His believers ([link]Heb. 2:13b[/link]).

verse.text: When they say to you, Inquire of the necromancers and the familiar spirits, who twitter and mutter; [i]say to them,[/i] Should not a people inquire of their God? [i]Should they go[/i] to the dead on behalf of the living —
To the law and to the testimony! If they do not speak according to this word, it is because in them there is no dawn.
And they go through it hard-pressed and hungry; and when they are hungry, they rage and curse their king and their God. They turn their faces upward,
And they look to the earth, but, there is [i]only[/i] distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish and being thrust into darkness.

But gloom [i]does[/i] not [i]remain in the place[/i] where there was anguish: formerly He treated the [xref]a[/xref]land of Zebulun and the land of [xref]b[/xref]Naphtali contemptibly, but afterward He treats the way of the [note]1[/note]sea, across the Jordan, with glory, [note]2[/note]Galilee of the nations.
verse.note: The Sea of Galilee.
See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link].

verse.text: The people who walked in the [xref]a[/xref]darkness / Have seen a great [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]light; / Upon those who dwell in the land of the [xref]c[/xref]shadow of death / [note]1[/note]Light has shined.
verse.note: This prophecy was fulfilled in [link]Matt. 4:12-16[/link], when Christ came to Galilee as the great light — the true light, the light of life ([link]John 1:9[/link], [link]4[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]) — to shine on the people who walked in darkness ([link]John 1:5[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:9b[/link]) and who dwelt in the shadow of death ([link]Luke 1:78-79[/link]). Christ's shining as the great light on God's people saves them from the darkness of death, releases them from bondage in darkness ([link]v. 3[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]), breaks the yoke that has been upon them ([link]v. 4[/link]; [link]10:26-27[/link]), and destroys their enemies with their armor ([link]v. 5[/link]).

verse.text: You have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]multiplied the nation; / You have increased their gladness; / They are glad before You as with the gladness of harvest, / As [i]men[/i] rejoice when they divide the spoil.
verse.note: This prophecy refers to the increase, spread, and growth of Christ on earth through all the New Testament believers, who are the farmers in the harvest and the fighters gaining the spoil, mentioned later in the verse.

verse.text: For You break the yoke of their burden / And the staff on their shoulder, / The rod of their oppressor, / As in the day of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Midian.
verse.note: By the shining of Christ, the Lord broke the yoke of the burden of the people of God, broke the staff on their shoulder, and broke the rod of their oppressor as in the day of Midian, when Gideon gained a great victory over the Midianites ([link]Judg. 7:22-25[/link]). The Assyrians came to invade Judah and to oppress them, but the Lord destroyed them as He had destroyed the Midianites through Gideon ([link]2 Kings 19:35-37[/link]).

verse.text: For all the boots / Of those who in boots trample in the battle-quake / And the garments / Rolled in [xref]a[/xref]blood / Are for burning; / [i]They are[/i] fuel for [xref]b[/xref]fire.

For a [note]1[/note]child is [xref]a[/xref]born [note]2[/note]to us, / A [note]1[/note]Son is [xref]b[/xref]given [note]2[/note]to us; / And the [note]3[/note]government / Is upon His shoulder; / And His name will be called / [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Wonderful Counselor, / [note]5[/note]Mighty [xref]d[/xref]God, / [note]5[/note]Eternal [xref]e[/xref]Father, / [note]6[/note]Prince of [xref]f[/xref]Peace.
verse.note: The child born of a human virgin ([link]7:14[/link]) is the Son given by the Eternal Father. Christ is the child born of both the divine and human natures ([link]Matt. 1:20-23[/link]), and He is also the Son in the divine nature given by the Eternal Father. Through the birth of the divine-human child, the Eternal Father gave us His divine Son as a gift. Through such a giving, everyone who believes in, i.e., receives, this dear Son receives eternal life ([link]John 3:16[/link]; [link]1 John 5:11-12[/link]). See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].
The phrase [i]to us,[/i] especially by its repetition, indicates emphatically that every aspect of Christ revealed in this verse is for our personal and subjective experience.
Or, rule, dominion. So also in the next verse. The divine administration is upon the shoulders of Christ, the wonderful One.

Lit., Wonder of a Counselor, or, Wonder, Counselor. Christ is wonderful ([link]Judg. 13:18[/link]), and He is also the Counselor. He gives us counsel, and then, as the Mighty God, He is the power and strength for carrying out the counsel ([link]1 Cor. 1:24[/link]).

As the child born to us, Christ is the Mighty God ([link]Matt. 2:11[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:8[/link]), and as the Son given to us, He is the Eternal Father ([link]63:16[/link]; [link]64:8[/link]; [link]John 5:43[/link]; [link]10:30[/link]; [link]14:7-10[/link]). See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 63[/link].
Christ is the Prince of peace to us ([link]Eph. 2:14[/link]) mainly by His ruling within us ([link]Col. 3:15[/link]).

verse.text: To the increase of [i]His[/i] [note]1[/note]government / And to [i]His[/i] [note]1[/note]peace there is [xref]a[/xref]no end, / Upon the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]throne of David / And over His kingdom, / To establish it / And to uphold it / In justice and righteousness / From now to eternity. / The [xref]c[/xref]zeal of Jehovah of hosts / Will accomplish this.
verse.note: From the time, in [link]Gen. 11[/link], when mankind gave up God as their Governor and made themselves the governors, the matter of government has been a great problem to man. But when the restoration comes ([link]Acts 3:21[/link]), Christ will be the unique Governor, and the government of the Triune God will be upon His shoulder ([link]v. 6[/link]). This government will increase and fill every corner of the earth ([link]Psa. 72:8[/link]; [link]Zech. 9:10b[/link]; see note [link]35[sup]3[/sup] in Dan. 2[/link]), causing the earth to be full of peace (cf. [link]2:4[/link]; [link]11:6-9[/link]).

Christ's ruling on the throne of David over His kingdom will be first in the millennium and then in the new heaven and new earth unto eternity. See [link]Luke 1:32-33[/link] and note [link]33[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: The Lord sends out a word against [note]1[/note]Jacob, / And it descends upon [note]1[/note]Israel.
verse.note: [link]Isaiah 9:8-10:34[/link] shows that both the oppressed, the kingdom of Israel, and the oppressor, the kingdom of Assyria, were under the judgment of God. These two judgments were actually one ([link]10:22-23[/link]). After the time of Solomon, the nation of Israel was divided into the northern kingdom of Israel and the southern kingdom of Judah ([link]1 Kings 11:26-12:20[/link]). Because the kingdom of Israel had fallen to the extent that it was on the level of the Gentile nations, even becoming an ally to the king of Aram ([link]7:1[/link]), Israel was not only under God's chastisement but also under His judgment. God's chastisement on Israel (Ephraim — [link]v. 9[/link]) became His judgment on Israel.

verse.text: And all the people know [i]it,[/i] / Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria, / Saying in pride and haughtiness of heart,
The bricks have fallen, but we will build with cut stone; / The sycamores have been felled, but we will put cedars in their place.
Then Jehovah exalts the adversaries of Rezin against them / And goads their enemies on.
Aram from the east and the Philistines from the west: / They devour Israel with an open mouth. / By all this His anger is not turned; / His hand is still outstretched.
Yet the people do [xref]a[/xref]not turn to Him who strikes them, / Nor do they seek Jehovah of hosts.
Then Jehovah cuts off from Israel head and tail, / Palm branch and marsh reed [xref]a[/xref]in one day.
The elder and the highly regarded — he is the head; / The prophet [i]and[/i] the teacher of falsehood — he is the tail.
And those who lead this people are those who [xref]a[/xref]mislead [i]them;[/i] / And those who are led are those who are confused.

Because of this the Lord will not rejoice in their young men, / And He will not have compassion on their orphans and widows; / For all of them are profane and evildoers, / And every mouth speaks foolishness. / By all this His anger is not turned; / His hand is still outstretched.
For wickedness burns like a fire; / It devours thorn and thistle, / And burns in the forest thickets; / And it rolls up [i]into[/i] a column of smoke.
At the overflowing wrath of Jehovah of hosts a land is burned up, / And the people are like fuel for fire; / No one spares [i]even[/i] his brother.
One carves on the right side, but is hungry; / And [i]another[/i] eats on the left side, but is not satisfied. / Each eats the flesh of his own arm:
Manasseh, Ephraim, and Ephraim, Manasseh; / These together against Judah. / By all this His anger is not turned; / His hand is still outstretched.
Woe to those who decree decrees of iniquity, / To the busy writers who are busy writing trouble,
In order to turn the poor away from judgment, / And to tear justice away from the afflicted among my people; / That widows may be their spoil, / And they may plunder orphans.

And what will you do for the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]day of visitation, / And for the devastation that comes from afar? / To whom will you flee for help? / And where will you leave your [note]2[/note]glory,
verse.note: Referring to the day of judgment.
Referring to their wealth.

verse.text: Unless one crouches behind prisoners, / And they fall behind the slain? / By all this His anger is not turned; / His hand is still outstretched.
Woe to Assyria, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rod of My anger! / The [note]1[/note]staff which is in their hand is My indignation.
verse.note: Because Israel had become corrupt, God used Assyria as a rod and a staff to judge Israel ([link]2 Kings 18:9-12[/link]). But Assyria, overstretching the limitation set by God, did not think of the matter in this way, nor did their heart conceive it in this way ([link]v. 7[/link]). Thus, Assyria acted excessively, and the king of Assyria became haughty ([link]vv. 12-15[/link]). Jehovah, therefore, judged the king of Assyria ([link]vv. 16-19[/link]). See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].

verse.text: Against a profane nation I send them out, / And against the people of My overflowing wrath I command them, / To make spoil of the spoil and to make plunder of the plunder, / To make them a trampling ground, like street mire.
But they do not think so, / And their heart does not conceive it so; / For destroying is in their heart, / And the cutting down of no few nations.
For they say, / Are not my princes all kings?
Is not Calno like [xref]a[/xref]Carchemish, / Or Hamath like Arpad, / Or Samaria like [xref]b[/xref]Damascus?
Since my hand has reached / The kingdoms of the idols, / And their graven images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria,
Shall I not do, as I have done / To Samaria and its idols, / The same to Jerusalem and its images?

But when the Lord has completed all His work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, [i]He says,[/i] I will punish the fruit of the king of [xref]a[/xref]Assyria's haughtiness of heart and the glory of his haughty eyes.

For he has said, / By the strength of my own hand I have done it, / And by my own wisdom; for I have understanding. / And I have [xref]a[/xref]removed the boundaries of the peoples; / And their stored possessions I have plundered. / And like a bull, I brought down those who sit [i]on thrones.[/i]

And my hand reached in, like in a nest, / For the wealth of the peoples; / And like one who gathers abandoned eggs, / I myself gathered in all the earth; / And none fluttered a wing, / Or opened a beak and chirped.

Should the ax glorify itself above [xref]a[/xref]him who chops with it? / Or should the saw magnify itself above him who wields it? / [i]It would be[/i] like the rod wielding him who lifts it up, / Like the staff lifting up him who is not wood.
Therefore the Lord Jehovah of hosts will send / Leanness to his fat ones; / And under his glory He will kindle a kindling, / Like the kindling of fire.
And the [xref]a[/xref]Light of Israel will become a fire, / And His Holy One a flame; / And it will burn and devour his thorns / And his thistles in one day.
The glory of his forest and of his garden land / He will destroy, both soul and body; / And he will be like a sick man wasting away.
And what is left of the trees of his forest will be so few in number / That a young boy could record them.

Then in that day the [xref]a[/xref]remnant of Israel and those of the house of Jacob who have [note]1[/note]escaped will no longer rely upon him who strikes them, but they will [xref]b[/xref]rely upon Jehovah, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
verse.note: After the judgment on Israel and the judgment on Assyria, there would be the return and release of a remnant of Israel ([link]vv. 20-27[/link]).

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.

[xref]a[/xref]For though your people, O Israel, are like the [note]1[/note]sand of the sea, [i]only[/i] a remnant among them will return. Annihilation is strictly decided, overflowing with righteousness.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 22[/link].

verse.text: For utter destruction and a strict decision is the Lord Jehovah of hosts performing in the midst of the whole land.
Therefore thus says the Lord Jehovah of hosts, O my people dwelling in Zion, do not fear Assyria, who strike with the rod and lift up their staff against you the way [xref]a[/xref]Egypt [i]did.[/i]
For in a very [xref]a[/xref]little while [i]My[/i] indignation will be [xref]b[/xref]completed, and My anger [i]will be turned[/i] toward their destruction.

And against them Jehovah of hosts will rouse up a whip like the stroke against [xref]a[/xref]Midian at the rock of Oreb; and His [xref]b[/xref]staff will be over the sea, and He will lift it up the way [i]He did in[/i] Egypt.
And in that day their burden will be removed from your [xref]a[/xref]shoulders, and their yoke from off your neck; and the yoke will be broken due to the fatness.
[note]1[/note]He [xref]a[/xref]comes against Aiath; / He passes through Migron; / At Michmash he deposits his gear.
verse.note: Referring to the Assyrian.

verse.text: They go through the pass, [i]saying,[/i] / Geba will be our lodging overnight. / Ramah is quaking; / Gibeah of Saul flees away.
Scream with your voice, O daughter of Gallim! / Listen carefully, Laishah! O poor Anathoth!
Madmenah flees; / The inhabitants of Gebim seek refuge.
[i]So it is[/i] this very day when he halts at Nob. / He swings his hand over the mountain of the [note]1[/note]daughter of [xref]a[/xref]Zion, / Over the hill of Jerusalem.
verse.note: Or, house of Zion.

verse.text: But now the Lord Jehovah of hosts / Is lopping off the boughs with an awful crash: / Those which are tall in height are hewn down, / And those which are lofty are laid low.
And He chops away the forest thickets with an iron ax; / And Lebanon falls at [i]the hands[/i] of a majestic One.
Then a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sprout will come forth from the stump of [xref]b[/xref]Jesse, / And a [note]1[/note]branch from his [xref]c[/xref]roots will bear [xref]d[/xref]fruit.
verse.note: In the restoration the coming Christ will be a sprout that comes forth from the stump of Jesse and a branch from his roots. Israel, especially the house of David, was like a tall tree. However, because of Israel's degradation, that tree was cut down, leaving only a stump with its roots. Both Mary and Joseph were descendants of David, part of the royal family (see note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]), but they had become poor and were people of a low class, living in Nazareth, a despised city, in Galilee, a despised region ([link]Luke 1:26-27[/link]). Christ as a sprout came forth from the stump of Jesse, above the earth, signifying that restoration is by life and of life. Furthermore, Christ as a branch came forth from Jesse's roots, underneath the earth, signifying the depths of the restoring life, to branch out God and bear much fruit. Christ as a sprout and a branch is full of restoring power, deepening power, growing power, and fruit-bearing power. Because of His branching out, the whole world is filled with His fruit. See notes [link]5[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link] and [link]23[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 2[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit of Jehovah will rest upon Him, / The Spirit of wisdom and understanding, / The Spirit of counsel and might, / The Spirit of knowledge and the fear of Jehovah.
verse.note: The branching out of Jehovah is altogether a matter of the Spirit. Christ was born of the Spirit ([link]Matt. 1:18[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]Luke 1:35[/link]); i.e., He was constituted of the Spirit as His divine essence. Moreover, He was baptized, anointed, with the Spirit ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18[/link]). The Spirit was with Him all the time and was one with Him ([link]Luke 4:1[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]10:21[/link]; [link]John 1:32[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:28[/link]). He walked by the Spirit and lived a life in, with, by, and through the Spirit. In His human living the Spirit was manifested with all the attributes mentioned in this verse. Thus, the Spirit is the reality of Christ ([link]John 14:16-20[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]).

verse.text: He will delight in the fear of Jehovah: / He will neither judge by [xref]a[/xref]what His eyes see, / Nor decide by what His ears hear.

But He will judge the poor in [xref]a[/xref]righteousness, / And decide with equity for the afflicted of the land. / And He will strike the land with the rod of His mouth, / And with the [xref]b[/xref]breath of His lips He will slay the wicked.
Righteousness will be that which [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]girds His loins, / And faithfulness will be that which [note]1[/note]girds His hips.
verse.note: Girding the loins (hips) gives one the strength to move, act, and especially to stand and to fight ([link]Eph. 6:13-14[/link]). Righteousness and faithfulness are two of Christ's virtues for standing and fighting. He stands with faithfulness and fights with righteousness ([link]Rev. 19:11[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the [note]1[/note]wolf will dwell with the lamb; / And the leopard will lie down with the kid, / And the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; / And a young boy will lead them about.
verse.note: When Adam fell, sin entered into him ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]). Since he, the head of all the creatures, became fallen, something of Satan also entered into the creatures. In the restoration Christ's restoring power will deliver all the creatures from the poisonous element of Satan, causing a change not only in outward action but also in inward nature ([link]Rom. 8:19-21[/link]). As a result, the situation among them will be pleasant, peaceful, and loving. The reason for this change is that the knowledge of God, i.e., the knowing of God, will fill the earth ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: The cow and the bear will graze; / Their young will lie down together; / And the lion will eat straw like the ox.
The nursing child will play by the cobra's hole, / And upon the viper's den / The weaned child will stretch his hand.
They will not harm nor destroy / In all [xref]a[/xref]My holy mountain, / For the [xref]b[/xref]earth will be filled with the knowledge of Jehovah, / As water covers the sea.

And in that day the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]root of Jesse, / Who stands as a [note]2[/note]banner to the peoples — / [xref]b[/xref]Him will the [note]3[/note]nations seek, / And His resting place will be the [note]4[/note]glory.
verse.note: Christ's being the root, the sprout, and the branch of Jesse ([link]v. 1[/link]) indicates that He is connected to humanity, whereas Christ's resting place being the glory indicates that He is very much related to God (see note [link]10[sup]4[/sup][/link]). He is both God and man, the God-man. Cf. note [link]16[sup]3[/sup] in Rev. 22[/link].

Through the restoration of Israel, Christ will become a banner to the peoples and a standard to the nations ([link]v. 12[/link]). The banner is mainly for designation, explanation, and instruction, and the standard is mainly for calling and gathering people ([link]5:26[/link]). In this chapter Isaiah couples Christ as the sprout and the branch ([link]v. 1[/link]) with Christ as the banner and the standard. When Christ as a sprout grows among God's people, this growing-up sprout becomes a banner, which describes, explains, designates, and even gives instructions to the peoples of the earth concerning what Christ is to God's people. This same Christ as a branch grows up to be a standard to call and gather the nations of the earth.
In the restoration all the nations on the earth will turn to seek Christ and will be willing to be His people ([link]2:2[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-22[/link]).

The divine glory, which is God Himself expressed, is Christ's resting place. This indicates that the divine glory is one with Christ ([link]John 17:5[/link], [link]24[/link]). It also implies Christ's divinity and indicates that Christ and God are one ([link]John 10:30[/link]).

verse.text: And in that day the Lord, / By His hand for the [note]1[/note]second time again, / Will [note]2[/note]recover the [xref]a[/xref]remnant of His people / Who remain, from Assyria and from Egypt, / From Pathros, Cush, and Elam, / From Shinar, Hamath, and the islands of the sea.
verse.note: The first time the Lord recovered Israel was in their exodus from Egypt.
Christ as the banner to the peoples and the standard to the nations will bring in the return of God's people and the submission of the Gentiles ([link]vv. 11[/link], [link]12b-16[/link]).

verse.text: He will lift up a [note]1[/note]standard to the nations, / And will [xref]a[/xref]gather the outcasts of Israel; / And the dispersed of Judah He will assemble / From the [xref]b[/xref]four corners of the earth.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Ephraim's jealousy will depart, / And the adversaries in Judah will be cut off; / Ephraim will not be jealous of Judah, / Nor will Judah be hostile to Ephraim.
verse.note: Ephraim was the northern kingdom of Israel, and Judah was the southern kingdom.

verse.text: And they will fly down upon the shoulders of the Philistines on the west; / Together they will plunder the children of the east. / Edom and Moab will come into the grasp of their hand, / And the children of Ammon will submit to them.

And Jehovah will [note]1[/note]utterly destroy the [note]2[/note]tongue of the sea of Egypt; / And will wave His hand over the [note]2[/note]River with the scorching of His wind, / And He will strike it into seven streams, / And march [i]men[/i] through it [xref]a[/xref]dryshod.
verse.note: Lit., devote (in this case, unto destruction).

The sea of Egypt is the Red Sea, and its tongue is the Gulf of Suez. The river is the Euphrates. For the return of His people to the Holy Land, God will destroy (or, dry up) the tongue of the sea of Egypt, dry up the Euphrates, and build a highway from Assyria ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: And there will be a [xref]a[/xref]highway from Assyria / For the remnant of His people which remain, / As there was for Israel / In the day that they [xref]b[/xref]came up from the land of Egypt.
And you will say [xref]a[/xref]in that day, / I will [note]1[/note]praise You, O Jehovah. You were angry with me, / [i]But[/i] Your anger has turned and You have consoled me.
verse.note: Or, give thanks to.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]God is now my [xref]a[/xref]salvation; / I will trust and not dread; / For [note]2[/note]Jah [note]1[/note]Jehovah is my [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]strength and song, / And He has become my salvation.
verse.note: This verse clearly reveals that salvation is God Himself. In the New Testament Jah Jehovah, who is salvation, is Jesus, the incarnated God ([link]Matt. 1:21[/link] and note; [link]Luke 2:30[/link] and note).
A shortened form of [i]Jehovah.[/i]
Strength and song both indicate experience. When God's salvation is experienced by us, it becomes our strength, and eventually it will be our song, our praising.

verse.text: Therefore you will draw [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]water with rejoicing / From the [note]2[/note]springs of salvation,
verse.note: The way to receive God as our salvation is to draw water from the springs of salvation, i.e., to drink Him ([link]Psa. 36:8[/link]; [link]John 4:14[/link]; [link]7:37[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:17[/link]). To be our salvation, the Triune God was processed to become the life-giving Spirit as the living water, the water of life ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:6[/link]; [link]22:1[/link], [link]17[/link]). When the living water enters into us, it permeates our entire being, causing us to be nourished, transformed, conformed, and glorified ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]8:29-30[/link]). Both the Old Testament and the New Testament show that God's practical salvation is the processed Triune God Himself as the living water.

The fountain is the source, the spring is the gushing up, the issue, of the source, and the river is the flow. The term [i]the springs of salvation[/i] implies that salvation is the source, i.e., the fountain. God as our salvation is the fountain ([link]v. 2[/link]); Christ is the springs of salvation for our enjoyment and experience ([link]John 4:14[/link]); and the Spirit is the flow of this salvation within us ([link]John 7:38-39[/link]).[br][br]Christ as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]) is the many springs of salvation gushing up from the fountain of the Triune God's salvation, from whom the believers may draw the water of life for their enjoyment ([link]v. 3a[/link]; [link]John 4:14[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:6[/link]). As God incarnated, Christ is the very embodiment of the Triune God ([link]John 1:14a[/link]; [link]Col. 2:9[/link]). Jesus, Jehovah our Savior and our salvation ([link]Matt. 1:21[/link]), has become the source of our eternal salvation through the process of His vicarious death for the accomplishing of God's eternal redemption ([link]Heb. 5:9[/link]; [link]9:12[/link]). Based on His redemption, He as our Redeemer becomes our Savior and our salvation.

verse.text: And you will say in that day, / [xref]a[/xref]Give thanks to Jehovah; [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]call upon His name! / [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Make His deeds known among the peoples; / Remind [i]them[/i] that His name is exalted.
verse.note: By calling on the name of the Lord with rejoicing and praising, we draw water out of the springs of salvation. See [link]Acts 2:21[/link] and notes.

This is a matter of preaching the gospel, of telling others of the deeds of Christ and reminding them that His name has been exalted ([link]Phil. 2:9[/link]), i.e., that He has ascended and is now in the heavens. Cf. [link]1 Pet. 2:9b[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Sing psalms to Jehovah, for He has done something majestic! / Let it be made known in all the earth!
Cry out and give a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ringing shout, O inhabitant of Zion, / For great in your midst is the [xref]b[/xref]Holy One of Israel.
verse.note: A ringing shout is a shout that continues to sound. Joy is inward, but rejoicing ([link]v. 3[/link]) involves some activity to express the joy that is within. This rejoicing is related to giving a ringing shout, that is, to rejoicing in a continuing way.

verse.text: The burden concerning [note]1[/note]Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw:
verse.note: The nations are used by God's enemy to disturb God's chosen people and to frustrate God from carrying out His economy. Thus, God is compelled to come in to judge them. All these judgments issue in one thing, that is, the ushering in of Christ.[br][br]The judgment of Jehovah upon the nations was to destroy Babylon by the Median army ([link]vv. 3-4[/link], [link]17-19[/link]; [link]14:22-23[/link]; [link]21:2[/link], [link]9a[/link]; [link]Dan. 5:30-31[/link]) because of its cruel destruction of many nations ([link]14:5-6[/link], [link]16-17[/link]) and because of its idols ([link]21:9b[/link]). Although Assyria, not Babylon, was the first nation to trouble God in His economy ([link]Jer. 50:17[/link]), in the sight of God all the nations, including Assyria, are a part of Babylon, which was considered by God to be the head of the great human image in [link]Dan. 2:32[/link], [link]37-38[/link].

verse.text: Upon a bare mountain raise up a standard; / Lift up [i]your[/i] voice to them. / Wave [i]your[/i] hand that they may enter / The gates of the nobles.
I Myself have commanded My sanctified ones; / I have also called My mighty ones to My wrath, / Those who exult in My majesty.
The sound of a tumult in the mountains, / Like that of many peoples! / The sound of an uproar of the kingdoms, / Of nations gathered together! / Jehovah of hosts is mustering / An army for battle.
They are coming from a distant land, / From the ends of heaven — / Jehovah and the instruments of His indignation — / To ruin all the land.
[xref]a[/xref]Howl, for the [note]1[/note]day of Jehovah has drawn [xref]b[/xref]near! / As destruction from the Almighty, it will come.
verse.note: See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 1[/link].

verse.text: Because of this all the hands will drop, / And every human heart will melt;

And [i]people[/i] will be dismayed. / [xref]a[/xref]Pangs and anguish will seize them; / Like a woman [xref]b[/xref]giving birth, they will writhe. / Each man will look toward his neighbor dumbfounded; / Their faces are inflamed.
Now the day of Jehovah is coming — / Cruel and [i]with[/i] overflowing wrath and burning anger — / To make the land a desolation; / And He will destroy its sinners off of it.
