For the stars of heaven and their constellations / Will not shine forth their light; / The sun will be [xref]a[/xref]dark at its rising, / And the moon will not let its light shine.
And I will punish the world for [i]its[/i] evil, / And the wicked for their iniquity; / I will stop the arrogance of the proud, / And the haughtiness of the terrible I will abase.
I will make mortal man rarer than pure gold, / And mankind [i]rarer[/i] than the gold of Ophir.
Hence, I will make the heavens [xref]a[/xref]shake, / And the earth will quake out of its place, / At the overflowing wrath of Jehovah of hosts, / In the day of His burning anger.
And like the hunted gazelle / And sheep without someone to gather [i]them,[/i] / Each man will turn to his own people, / And each will flee to his own land.
Everyone found will be pierced through, / And everyone caught will fall by the sword.
And their little ones will be dashed to pieces / Before their eyes; / Their houses will be plundered, / And their wives will be attacked.
Now [note]1[/note]I rouse up the Medes against them, / Who will not esteem silver highly, / Nor take delight in gold.
verse.note: Jehovah's judgment upon the nations shows His sovereign and just rule over the nations ([link]v. 17[/link]; [link]14:22[/link], [link]24-25[/link]; [link]19:1[/link]; cf. [link]Dan. 4:17[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5[/link]).

verse.text: [i]Their[/i] bows will shatter the young men; / And they will not have compassion on the fruit of the womb: / Their eyes will have no pity on children.
And Babylon, the beauty of kingdoms, / The [xref]a[/xref]glory of the Chaldeans' majesty, / [xref]b[/xref]Will be as when God overthrew / [xref]c[/xref]Sodom and Gomorrah:

It will not be [xref]a[/xref]inhabited forever; / It will not be dwelt in from generation to generation. / And the Arab will not set up his tent there, / Nor will the shepherds make [i]their flocks[/i] lie down there.
But desert [xref]a[/xref]animals will lie down there, / And their houses will be full of [note]1[/note]wild dogs; / There ostriches will dwell, / And [note]2[/note]wild goats will prance there;
verse.note: Others translate, owls.
Or, goat demons.

verse.text: Hyenas will respond in their [note]1[/note]citadels, / And jackals in [i]their[/i] exquisite palaces. / Her time is about to come, / And her days will not be prolonged.
verse.note: According to the reading of some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, widows.

verse.text: When Jehovah has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]compassion on Jacob and again chooses Israel and settles them in their land, the [xref]b[/xref]sojourners will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.
verse.note: An issue of Jehovah's judgment upon the nations is the restoring and establishing of His beloved Israel ([link]vv. 1-3[/link], [link]32b[/link]; [link]17:7[/link], [link]10[/link]) and His changing the heart of and blessing the judged nations ([link]16:1-4[/link]; [link]18:1[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]19:19-25[/link]). See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: And nations will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will take possession of them in the land of Jehovah as male and female servants; and they will lead captive those who were their captors and rule over those who oppressed them.
In the day when Jehovah gives you rest from your pain and turmoil and from the hard service that was done by you as slaves,
You will lift up this discourse concerning the king of Babylon and you will say:[br/]How the oppressor has ceased! / How the [note]1[/note]raging has ceased!
verse.note: Following the reading of the Dead Sea Scrolls and the ancient versions; the Hebrew text is unclear.

verse.text: Jehovah has broken the staff of the wicked, / The rod of rulers;
That struck the peoples in wrath, / With strikes that would not stop; / That ruled the nations in anger, / With pursuit that would not let up.
All the earth rests [i]and[/i] is undisturbed; / They break forth with a [xref]a[/xref]ringing shout.
Even the cypress trees rejoice over you, / [i]And[/i] the cedars of Lebanon: / Since you are brought down, no tree cutter / Will come up against us.

[xref]a[/xref]Sheol beneath is excited because of you, / That it will meet you when you come. / It rouses the dead because of you, / All the [note]1[/note]great ones of the earth. / It makes all the kings of the nations / Rise from their thrones.
verse.note: Lit., male goats.

verse.text: All of them will respond / And say to you, / Even you have been weakened, just as we have; / You have become like us.
Your majesty has been brought down to Sheol, / [i]Even[/i] the sound of your harps. / Beneath you maggots are spread; / Worms are your covering.
How you have [xref]a[/xref]fallen from heaven, / O [note]1[/note]Daystar, son of the dawn! / How you have been hewn down to earth, / You who made nations fall prostrate!
verse.note: The Latin Vulgate translates, Lucifer. This refers to Satan, who, as the Daystar, son of the dawn, was one of the earliest angels (the sons of God — [link]Job 38:7[/link], cf. [link]Job 1:6[/link]) created by God at the "dawn" of the universe. He was appointed by God to be the head of all the angels ([link]Ezek. 28:14[/link]; [link]Jude 9[/link]) and later became Satan, the adversary of God, after he rebelled against God (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Because of his rebellion, Lucifer as Satan was judged by God ([link]vv. 12-15[/link]; [link]Ezek. 28:16-19[/link]; [link]Luke 10:18[/link]).[br][br]In [link]vv. 12-15[/link] Isaiah identifies Lucifer with Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon ([link]v. 4[/link]), thus regarding Nebuchadnezzar as a figure of Satan, as one who was one with Satan (cf. [link]Ezek. 28:12[/link]). This unveils Satan's kingdom of darkness behind the nations ([link]Eph. 6:12b[/link]; cf. [link]Dan. 10:13[/link], [link]20[/link]) and his oneness with the rulers of the nations.

verse.text: But you, you said in your heart: / [note]1[/note]I will [xref]a[/xref]ascend to heaven; / Above the stars of God / I will [xref]b[/xref]exalt my throne. / And I will sit upon the mount of assembly / In the [note]2[/note]uttermost parts of the north.
verse.note: Satan's rebellion against God is revealed in [link]vv. 13-14[/link] and in [link]Ezek. 28:15-18[/link]. Satan's heart was lifted up because of his beauty, and he corrupted his wisdom by reason of his brightness ([link]Ezek. 28:17[/link]). In his arrogance Satan declared five times, "I will...," indicating that his intention in his rebellion was to overthrow God's authority and to exalt himself to be equal with God. Satan's ambition for position became the motivation of all the rebellions recorded in the Scriptures ([link]Gen. 11:4[/link]; [link]Num. 12:1-2[/link]; [link]16:1-3[/link]; [link]2 Sam. 15:10-12[/link]; etc.). Because of his rebellion Satan became God's adversary, God's enemy ([link]Zech. 3:1-2[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:9a[/link]; [link]20:2a[/link]).

The highest place, where God sits on His throne, in the place where He assembles with all the angels ([link]Job 1:6[/link]; [link]2:1[/link]). In his rebellion against God, Satan wanted to be on the same level as God.

verse.text: I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; / I will make myself [xref]a[/xref]like the Most High.
But you will be [xref]a[/xref]brought down to [note]1[/note]Sheol, / To the uttermost parts of the pit.
verse.note: This is Hades in the New Testament (see note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link]). Satan wanted to exalt himself to the uttermost parts of the north ([link]v. 13[/link]), but God judged the rebellious Satan, sentencing him to be cast from the heavens to the earth and into Sheol, to the uttermost parts of the pit ([link]vv. 12[/link], [link]15[/link]; [link]Ezek. 28:17[/link]). See [link]Luke 10:18[/link] and note; [link]Rev. 12:9[/link] and note 1. Because Satan's rebellion polluted not only the earth but also the heavens (see notes [link]20[sup]5[/sup] in Col. 1[/link] and [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 9[/link]), both the earth and the heavens were judged by God. As a result, the sun and the stars did not shine, and the earth was covered with darkness and buried under deep water ([link]Gen. 1:2[/link]; [link]Job 9:5-7[/link]).[br][br]According to [link]Rev. 12:4a[/link] and [link]9b[/link], one-third of the angels of heaven joined Satan in his rebellion. They too must have been judged by God (cf. [link]Matt. 25:41[/link]), and after being judged they became the fallen angels, Satan's subordinates as the rulers, the authorities, the world-rulers of this darkness, the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenlies ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link] and note 2; see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Dan. 10[/link]). The living creatures on the earth in the preadamic age also joined Satan in his rebellion. After being judged by God through water ([link]Gen. 1:2[/link]), they became disembodied spirits, the demons ([link]Matt. 8:28-32[/link]; [link]12:43-45[/link]), who lodge in the water with which they were judged (see notes [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link] and [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]) and work on earth for Satan's kingdom of darkness ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18a[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13a[/link]).

verse.text: Those who see you will gaze at you; / They will ponder concerning you, [i]asking,[/i] / Is this the man who made the earth tremble, / The one who shook kingdoms;
Who made the world like a wilderness / And tore down its cities; / Who did not release his captives to their homes?
All the kings of the nations, / All of them, lie in glory, / Each in his own house.

But you have been thrown out away from your tomb, / Like some shoot that is viewed with disgust; / [i]Or like[/i] the garments of the slain, of those pierced with the sword, / Who go down to the stones of the pit; / Like a corpse that has been trampled under.
You shall not be united with them in burial, / For you have destroyed your land, / You have slain your people; / The seed of evildoers / Will never be renowned.
Prepare a slaughterhouse for his children / Because of the iniquity of their fathers, / So that they do not rise up and possess the land, / And fill the surface of the world with cities.
And I will rise up against them, / Declares Jehovah of hosts. / And I will [xref]a[/xref]cut off from Babylon name and remnant, / And posterity and progeny, declares Jehovah.
And I will make it a possession for porcupines / And muddied pools of water, / And I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, / Declares Jehovah of hosts.
Jehovah of hosts has sworn, saying, / Surely just as I conceived it, so has it happened; / And just as I have purposed it, so shall this stand,

That I will break [xref]a[/xref]Assyria in [xref]b[/xref]My land, / And upon My mountains I will trample him. / Then his yoke will be taken off of them, / And his burden will be removed from off their shoulders.
This is the purpose that I have purposed over all the earth, / And this is the hand that is stretched out over all the nations.
For Jehovah of hosts has purposed [i]it,[/i] and who will frustrate [i]it?[/i] / And [i]thus[/i] His hand is stretched out, and who will turn it back?
In the year that King [xref]a[/xref]Ahaz died this burden came:

Do not rejoice, all of you, Philistia, / That the [xref]a[/xref]rod that strikes you is broken, / For from the serpent's root a viper will come forth, / And his [xref]b[/xref]fruit will be a flying fiery serpent.
And the poorest of the poor will feed, / And the needy will lie down securely. / And I will kill your root by famine, / And he will slay your remnant.
Howl, O gate! Cry out, O city! / The whole of you, Philistia, is melted away. / For from the north smoke has come, / And there are no stragglers in his ranks.
And what shall one answer [i]this[/i] nation's messengers? / That Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]founded Zion, / And in her the [xref]b[/xref]poor of His people take refuge.
The burden concerning Moab:[br/]Indeed in a night it is devastated — / Ar of Moab is cut off. / Indeed in a night it is devastated — / Kir of Moab is cut off.

They have gone up to their temple and to Dibon, / [i]That is,[/i] to their high places, to weep. / Over Nebo and over Medeba / Moab howls; / [xref]a[/xref]Upon all their heads is baldness; / Every beard is shaved off.
In their streets they have girded themselves with sackcloth; / On their roofs / And in their open squares everyone will howl, / Melting in tears.
And Heshbon and Elealeh cry out; / Their voice is heard as far as Jahaz. / Because of this the armed men of Moab raise a cry; / Their soul quivers within them.

My heart [xref]a[/xref]cries out for Moab; / Its fugitives [i]reach[/i] as far as Zoar, [i]as far as[/i] Eglath-shelishiyah: / By the ascent of Luhith / With weeping they will go up; / On the way [i]that leads to[/i] Horonaim / They will raise up a cry of destruction;
The waters of Nimrim / Will be a devastation; / The foliage will be dried up, the grass wasted away; / There will be nothing green.
As a result, the abundance they have produced / And placed in reserve / Will be carried off / To the poplar brook.
For the cry has gone about / The border of Moab; / Their howling [i]goes[/i] as far as Eglaim, / Even to Beer-elim their howling [i]reaches.[/i]
For the waters of Dimon are full of blood, / For I will bring upon Dimon additional things: / Lions upon those in Moab who escape / And upon the remnant of the land.
Send a lamb [i]of tribute[/i] / To the ruler of the land, / From Sela across the wilderness / To the mountain of the daughter of Zion.
Like wandering birds, / [i]Like[/i] a scattered nest, / Will the daughters of Moab be / At the fords of the Arnon.
Give [i]us[/i] counsel, / Make a judgment [i]concerning us.[/i] / Make your shadow at high noon / Like night [i]to us.[/i] / Hide the outcasts; / Do not expose him who wanders.

[note]1[/note]Let the outcasts of Moab / Dwell with you; / Be a hiding place to them / From the destroyer. / When the extortioner finishes / [i]And[/i] destruction ends, / [i]When[/i] the oppressor is completely [i]gone[/i] from the land,
verse.note: According to the reading of the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, Let my outcasts dwell with you, Moab.

verse.text: Then will a throne be [xref]a[/xref]established in lovingkindness, / And upon it [note]1[/note]One will sit in [note]2[/note]truth / In the tent of David, / Judging and pursuing justice / And hastening righteousness.
verse.note: The ultimate issue of Jehovah's judgment upon the nations is to provide the all-inclusive Christ as the Savior to meet the need of the beloved Israel and the judged nations ([link]v. 5[/link]; [link]19:20b[/link]; [link]22:20-25[/link]). Christ will reign as a king in the tent of David, i.e., in the kingdom of David, the Messianic kingdom ([link]Acts 15:16[/link]), in the coming age during the restoration of the nation of Israel ([link]Amos 9:11[/link] and note; [link]Luke 1:32-33[/link] and note [link]33[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Christ's reigning in the tent of David signifies consolation, encouragement, and restoration. According to [link]24:23[/link], the Christ who will reign in the millennium is actually Jehovah of hosts.
Or, faithfulness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]We have heard of the pride of Moab — / He is extremely proud — / Of his haughtiness and pride and insolence; / His boastings are [i]all[/i] untrue.
Therefore Moab will howl for Moab; / They all will howl. / For the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth / You will mourn, utterly stricken.

Because the fields of Heshbon have withered, / [i]And[/i] the vine of Sibmah, [i]too.[/i] / The lords of the nations / Have trampled under its choicest vines, / Which reached as far as Jazer, / Which meandered into the desert. / Its shoots spread abroad; / They crossed over [i]to[/i] the sea.

[xref]a[/xref]Therefore I will weep bitterly for Jazer, / For the vine of Sibmah; / I will soak you with my tears, / Heshbon and Elealeh. / For the harvest shout is hushed / Over your summer fruit and over your reapings.

Rejoicing is taken away, and exultation from the fruited field; / In the vineyards there will be no singing for joy; no shouts will be uttered. / The treader will not tread out wine in the presses — / I have made the harvest shout stop.
[xref]a[/xref]Therefore for Moab my bowels will moan like a lyre, / And my inward parts for Kir-heres.
And when Moab appears, / When they weary themselves at their high place, / And come to their sanctuary to pray, / It will not avail.
This is the word which Jehovah spoke concerning Moab long ago.

And now Jehovah has spoken, saying, Within three years, like the years of a hired man, the glory of Moab will be disgraced, with all its great multitude, and [i]its[/i] remnant will be small — a mere trifle, nothing great.
The burden concerning [xref]a[/xref]Damascus:[br/]See, Damascus — turned from [i]being[/i] a city, / It will become a heap of ruin.
The cities of Aroer will be forsaken; / They will be for flocks / That lie down with no one to frighten them.
And fortified cities will cease to be in Ephraim, / As well as the kingdom in Damascus; / And the remnant of Syria / Will be like the glory of the children of Israel, / Declares Jehovah of hosts.
In that day the glory of Jacob will fade, / And the fat of his flesh will become lean.
And it will be as when the reaper gathers the standing grain, / And his arms reap the ears; / And it will be as when one gleans the ears / In the valley of Rephaim.

Yet [xref]a[/xref]gleanings will be left in it, / Like at the shaking of an olive tree — / Two or three fruit at the very top, / Four or five in the boughs of the fruiting [i]tree[/i] — / Declares Jehovah the God of Israel.
In that day man will [xref]a[/xref]look to his [xref]b[/xref]Maker, / And his eyes will behold the Holy One of Israel.
And he will not look to the altars, the works of his hands; / And what his fingers have made he will not regard, / That is, the Asherahs and the images to the sun.
In that day his cities of protection will be / Like abandoned places of the forest and [i]like[/i] the mountaintop / Which was abandoned before the children of Israel; / And there will be desolation.

For you have forgotten the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God of your salvation, / And the [note]1[/note]Rock of your stronghold you have not remembered. / Therefore you plant plants of delight / And set them with plant cuttings to a strange [i]god.[/i]
verse.note: As the eternal Rock of our stronghold, Christ is the God of our salvation (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]), in whom we should trust. He is also the Rock of Israel for His people to contact Him as their joy ([link]30:29[/link]).

verse.text: On the day that you plant [i]them[/i] you fence [i]them[/i] in carefully, / And in the morning you bring your seed to blossom; / [i]But[/i] the harvest is a heap on a day of sickness / And incurable pain.
Woe! The roar of many peoples, / Who roar like the [xref]a[/xref]roaring of the seas; / The din of nations, / Who crash like the crashing of mighty [xref]b[/xref]waters!

The nations crash like the crashing of many waters. / But He will rebuke them; / And they will flee far away, / And will be chased like mountain chaff before the wind / And like a whirlwind of dust before storm wind.
At evening time, indeed, there is calamity; / Before the morning they are no more. / This is the portion of those who plunder us, / And the allotment of those who take us as spoil.
Woe to the land of the whirring of wings, / Which is beyond the rivers of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Cush,
verse.note: Or, Ethiopia.

verse.text: [i]The land[/i] that sends envoys on the sea, / Even in papyrus vessels upon the surface of the water. / Go, swift messengers, / To a nation tall and smooth [i]of skin,[/i] / To a people feared from there and beyond, / A nation of command upon command and of treading down [i]others,[/i] / Whose land the rivers cut through.
All you inhabitants of the world and dwellers on the earth, / When the standard is raised on the mountains, you will see [i]it;[/i] / And when the horn is blown, you will hear [i]it.[/i]
For thus has Jehovah spoken to me, / I will be quiet and observe in My lodging place, / Like glowing heat in the sunshine, / Like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.
For before the harvest, when the bud is full / And the flower becomes the ripening grape, / He will cut off the sprigs with pruning knives, / And the tendrils He will remove [i]and[/i] cut away.
They will be left together for the mountain birds / And for the beasts of the earth. / And the birds will spend summer on them, / And all the beasts of the earth will spend harvest time on them.

At that time a [xref]a[/xref]gift will be brought to Jehovah of hosts [note]1[/note]from a people tall and smooth [i]of skin,[/i] even from a people feared from there and beyond, a nation of command upon command and of treading down [i]others,[/i] whose land the rivers cut through, unto the place of the name of Jehovah of hosts, Mount Zion.
verse.note: [i]From[/i] is supplied from the Dead Sea Scrolls and some ancient versions.

verse.text: The burden concerning [xref]a[/xref]Egypt: / See, Jehovah is riding upon a swift [xref]b[/xref]cloud, / And He is coming to Egypt. / And the [xref]c[/xref]idols of Egypt will quiver at His presence, / And the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them.
Thus I will spur on Egyptian against Egyptian; / And each will fight against his brother, and each against his neighbor, / City against city, [i]and[/i] kingdom against kingdom.
The spirit of the Egyptians will fail within them, / And their counsel I will swallow up; / Then they will seek after idols and mediums, / And after spirits of the dead and familiar spirits.
And I will shut the Egyptians up under the hand of [xref]a[/xref]hard masters, / And a mighty king will rule over them, / Declares the Lord Jehovah of hosts.
And the waters from the sea will be [xref]a[/xref]dried up, / And the river will be desolate and dry.
The river canals will [xref]a[/xref]stink; / The streams of Egypt's Nile will diminish and be desolate. / The reeds and rushes will rot;
The plants at the Nile, at the mouth of the Nile, / And every place sown by the Nile / Will dry up, be driven away, and be no more.
The fishermen will mourn; / And all who cast the hook into the Nile will lament; / And those who spread nets upon the waters will languish.
Moreover, those who work with combed flax will be confounded, / As well as those who weave linen.
And the pillars of [i]the land[/i] will be crushed, / And every wage worker will be sullen in soul.

Mere fools are the princes of [xref]a[/xref]Zoan; / The counsel of the wisest of Pharaoh's counselors has become stupidity. / How can you say to Pharaoh, / I am a son of the wise men, a son of ancient kings?
Where are they? [xref]a[/xref]Where are your wise men? / Let them tell you and let them know / What Jehovah of hosts has purposed against Egypt.
The princes of Zoan have become fools; the princes of Memphis are beguiled; / They have misled Egypt, [i]who are[/i] the cornerstone of her tribes.
Jehovah has mixed within her a spirit of distortings, / And they have misled Egypt in all that it does, / As a drunken man staggers in his vomit.
And there will be no work for Egypt, / Which the head or the tail, the palm branch or the marsh reed, may do.
In that day the Egyptians will be like women, and they will tremble and be in dread before the waving of the hand of Jehovah of hosts, which He will be waving over them.

And the land of Judah will become a source of crazed terror to Egypt — everyone to whom it is mentioned will be in dread of it because of the purpose of Jehovah of hosts, which He purposes against them.
In that day five cities in the land of Egypt will be speaking the [xref]a[/xref]language of Canaan and swearing to Jehovah of hosts; one will be called the City of Destruction.
In that day there will be an [xref]a[/xref]altar to Jehovah in the midst of the land of Egypt and a pillar to Jehovah near its border;

And it will become a sign and a testimony to Jehovah of hosts in the land of Egypt; for they will cry unto Jehovah because of [i]their[/i] oppressors, and He will send them a [note]1[/note]Savior and Mighty One; and He will deliver them.
verse.note: In the coming age, for the Gentiles, especially for Egypt, Christ is a Savior, a Defender, who is the Mighty One.

verse.text: And Jehovah will make Himself known to the Egyptians, and the Egyptians will know Jehovah in that day; they will [note]1[/note]worship [i]Him[/i] with sacrifice and [xref]a[/xref]offering and will vow a vow to Jehovah and accomplish [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: Or, serve. So also in [link]v. 23[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah will strike Egypt, striking yet healing; and they will turn to Jehovah, and He will be entreated of by them and will heal them.
In that day there will be a [xref]a[/xref]highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrians will come to Egypt, and the Egyptians to Assyria; and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.
In that day Israel will be the third party with Egypt and Assyria, a [xref]a[/xref]blessing in the midst of the land,
With which Jehovah of hosts will bless, saying, Blessed be Egypt My people and Assyria the [xref]a[/xref]work of My hands and Israel My inheritance.
In the year that the [note]1[/note]Tartan came to Ashdod, when Sargon the king of Assyria sent him, and he fought against Ashdod and took it,
verse.note: A commander for the king of Assyria (cf. [link]2 Kings 18:17[/link]).

verse.text: At that time Jehovah spoke through Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, Go and loosen the sackcloth from your loins and take your sandals off your feet. And he did so, going about stripped and barefooted.
And Jehovah said, Just as My [xref]a[/xref]servant Isaiah has gone about stripped and barefoot for three years as a [xref]b[/xref]sign and a wonder against Egypt and Cush,
So shall the king of Assyria lead away the captives of Egypt and the exiles of Cush, young men and old men, stripped and barefoot, with their buttocks uncovered, to Egypt's shame.
And they will be dismayed and ashamed of Cush, their [note]1[/note]expectation, and of Egypt, their [note]1[/note]boast.
verse.note: Instead of trusting in God, Israel expected to receive help from Cush and to gain something from Egypt for their boasting. God hated this and judged Cush and Egypt for it.

verse.text: And the inhabitant of this coastland will say in that day, Such is now our expectation, to whom we fled for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria! And how shall we escape?
The burden concerning the wilderness of the sea:[br/]Like storm winds / In the [note]1[/note]Negev passing through, / It comes from the wilderness / From an awesome land.
verse.note: I.e., the dry southern desert of Canaan; the term is generally used to refer to the south.

verse.text: A harsh vision / Has been announced to me; / The unfaithful one deals unfaithfully, / And the destroyer destroys. / Go up, Elam; / Lay siege, Media; / I have put an end / To all her groaning.

Therefore my loins / Are full of anguish; / Pangs have taken hold of me / Like the pangs of a woman in labor. / I am bent over at the hearing [i]of it;[/i] / I am terrified at the seeing [i]of it.[/i]
My heart reels; / Shuddering overwhelms me. / The twilight that I love / Has become a [i]source of[/i] trembling to me.
Setting the table! / Spreading out the rug! / Eating! Drinking! / Rise, princes; / Oil the shields.
For thus says / The Lord to me, / Go, set a watchman; / Let him report what he sees.
And he saw riders, / A team of horsemen; / Riders of donkeys, / Riders of camels; / And he attends with attention, / With much attention.
And he calls out [i]like[/i] a lion: / On the watchtower, Lord, / I stand continually by day; / At my guardpost / I am stationed / Every night.

And now there come / Riding men, / A team of horsemen. / And one answers and says, / [xref]a[/xref]Fallen, fallen is Babylon! / And all the [xref]b[/xref]idols of her gods / Has He shattered to the ground.
My [xref]a[/xref]threshed ones, / And the son of the threshing floor! / What I have heard / From Jehovah of hosts, / The God of Israel, / I have declared to you.
The burden concerning [note]1[/note]Dumah: / Someone is calling to me from Seir: / Guard, what [i]remains[/i] of the night? / Guard, what [i]remains[/i] of the night?
verse.note: I.e., Edom.

verse.text: The guard says, / Morning is coming, / But so also is night; / If you will ask, ask; / Return, come.
The burden against Arabia: / In the thicket of Arabia you must spend the night, / You nomad clans of the Dedanim.
They bring water / To meet the thirsty; / The inhabitants of the land of Tema / Meet with bread those who flee;
For they flee from swords — / From the drawn sword, / From the bent bow, / And from the harshness of battle.
For thus has the Lord said to me, Within a year, like a wage worker's year, all the glory of Kedar will end,
And the remainder of the number of the archers, the mighty men of the sons of Kedar, will be few; for Jehovah the God of Israel has spoken.
The burden concerning the [note]1[/note]valley of vision:[br/]What then [i]troubles[/i] you / That all have gone up to the housetops?
verse.note: Even Jerusalem was included in Jehovah's judgment upon the nations. In His judgment Jehovah would trample down the city of Jerusalem — the valley of vision ([link]vv. 5-7[/link]) — because of its unforgivable iniquity: it did not look to the Lord and regard Him ([link]vv. 11b-14[/link]).

verse.text: You who are full of noise, you tumultuous city, / You exultant town, / Your slain were not slain with the sword, / Nor are they dead because of battle.
All your rulers have [xref]a[/xref]fled together; / Apart from the bow they have been captured. / All of you who were found have been captured together, / [i]Though[/i] they had fled far away.
Therefore I said, Look away from me! / Let me [xref]a[/xref]weep bitterly. / Do not hasten to comfort me / About the destruction of the daughter of my people.
For there is a day of [xref]a[/xref]turmoil and trampling down and confusion / With the Lord Jehovah of hosts / In the valley of vision, a breaking down of walls / And crying to the mountains.
And Elam took up the quiver, / With chariots of men [i]and[/i] horsemen; / And Kir uncovered the shield.
Then your choicest valleys / Were [xref]a[/xref]full of chariots, / And the horsemen firmly fixed themselves at the gate;
And he removed the covering of Judah. / And you looked in that day / To the weapons of the [xref]a[/xref]Forest House,
While the breaches of the city of David / You saw to be many. / So you gathered the [xref]a[/xref]water of the lower pool;
And the houses of Jerusalem you counted, / And tore down the houses to [xref]a[/xref]fortify the wall.
Then you made a [xref]a[/xref]reservoir between the walls / For the water of the old pool. / But you did not look to its very [xref]b[/xref]Maker, / And He who formed it long ago you did not regard.
Therefore the Lord Jehovah of hosts / Called [i]you[/i] in that day / To weeping and to [xref]a[/xref]mourning, / To [i]head[/i] shaving and to wearing sackcloth.
But now there is gladness and joy, / The slaying of cattle and the slaughtering of sheep, / The eating of meat and the drinking of wine; / [xref]a[/xref]Eating and drinking, for tomorrow we die!
But in my ears the Lord Jehovah of hosts revealed [i]this:[/i] / This iniquity shall by no means be covered for you until you die, / Says the Lord Jehovah of hosts.
Thus says the Lord Jehovah of hosts: / Get up, go to this steward, / To Shebna, who is over the king's house, [i]saying,[/i]

What are you doing here, and whom do you have here / That you have hewn a [xref]a[/xref]tomb for yourself here, / [i]As[/i] he who has hewn a tomb on the heights, / [i]As[/i] he who has cut out a resting place for himself in the rock?
Jehovah soon throws you far away, O mighty one, / And He grasps you firmly;

He will wind you up tightly; / Like a ball [i]He will toss[/i] you into a wide land. / There you will die; and there the chariots of your glory / [i]Will become[/i] the disgrace of the house of your master.
And I will drive you from your position, / And from your standing He will pull you down.
And in that day / I will call to My servant [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Eliakim the son of Hilkiah,
verse.note: Eliakim, the servant of Jehovah who replaced Shebna ([link]vv. 15-19[/link]), is a type of Christ as the Steward over God's house ([link]v. 22[/link], cf. [link]Rev. 3:7[/link]). God's house is the divine household ([link]Gal. 6:10[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]), including all the believers throughout the ages, over which Christ is the unique Steward, who takes care of God's household in every way. While Christ as God's Steward serves in God's house, He also governs, rules, and administrates God's children, who are under Christ's care.

verse.text: And I will clothe him with your tunic, / And I will strengthen him with your girding sash, / And I will put your dominion into his hand; / And he will become a [note]1[/note]father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem / And to the house of Judah.
verse.note: Christ is a Father to us, God's children (cf. [link]9:6[/link]). As the Father, He is the source and Supplier to support us in everything and in every way.

verse.text: And I will set the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]key of the house of David upon his shoulder — / When he opens, no one will shut; / When he shuts, no one will open.
verse.note: The all-inclusive Christ, as typified by Eliakim, is also the One upon whose shoulder the key of (the treasury of — [link]39:2[/link] and note) the house of God (typified by the house of David for the building up of the kingdom of God — [link]2 Sam. 7:16[/link]) is set ([link]Rev. 3:7[/link]). The church is both God's house ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]) and God's kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link]). The key set on Christ's shoulder is the key for the keeping of all the treasures of the house of God, which are all the riches of Christ for our enjoyment. Christ is the One who can open and shut the door to the treasury of God's riches, which are embodied in Him ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: And I will drive him as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peg into a sure place, / And he will become a [note]2[/note]throne of glory for his father's house.
verse.note: Christ has been driven by God as a peg, or nail, into a sure place ([link]v. 23a[/link]), which typifies the third heaven (cf. [link]2 Cor. 12:2b[/link]), where Christ was exalted by God after His resurrection ([link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]5:31[/link]). Because the Father is in the third heaven ([link]Matt. 6:9[/link]), to be exalted to the third heaven is to be exalted to God the Father (cf. [link]Luke 15:18[/link]). Christ today is in the heavens as a peg driven into God. See notes on [link]v. 24[/link].

Christ will become a throne of glory for His Father's house. The glory here is the children of God, who are vessels hanging upon Christ as the peg ([link]v. 24[/link] and notes). With the glory there is a throne, and this throne is actually Christ Himself. The throne signifies the administrative authority and the kingdom. Christ in His administrative authority is the throne that governs everything within the house of God.

verse.text: And they will hang upon him all the [note]1[/note]glory of his father's house, the offspring and the issue, all the smallest vessels, from the [note]2[/note]bowls to all the jars.
verse.note: Or, weight. In this verse [i]glory[/i] is in apposition with both [i]the offspring and the issue[/i] and [i]vessels.[/i] Thus, the glory of the Father's house that hangs on Christ as the peg is the children of God as the offspring and the issue (descendants) of God, and these children of God are the vessels of Christ, who hang on Him in order to contain Him and to minister Him to others. The children of God as the offspring and the issue are glory in the house of God, and they are also the vessels.

The bowls and jars typify the different ways and means for us to partake of Christ in His riches. Bowls, or cups, are small vessels to contain water, typifying the Spirit of Christ ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]), and jars, or pitchers, are large vessels to contain wine, typifying the divine life ([link]Matt. 9:17[/link] and note 1). This signifies that in the house of God all His children are vessels to contain His Spirit as water to quench people's thirst and His life as wine to cheer people unto rejoicing. All the riches of the bountiful supply for the enjoyment of God's children are hanging on Christ as the peg, the holder.

verse.text: In that day, declares Jehovah of hosts, the [note]1[/note]peg driven into the sure place will be removed, even cut away, and it will fall; and the burden that was upon it will be cut down; for Jehovah has spoken.
verse.note: Referring not to Eliakim (Christ) but to Shebna ([link]v. 15[/link]), who was replaced by Eliakim. In His judgment God discharged, or "fired," everyone and everything, including the kings of the nations, Shebna the steward, and all the bowls and jars in God's house, and replaced them all with Christ. God discharged everyone on the cross, and He is replacing everyone with Christ. Because Christ joined Himself to us, uniting Himself with us, when He died on the cross, we died with Him and were terminated ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:14[/link]). Now, in our organic union with Christ through our faith in Him, He replaces us by living in us, with us, by us, and through us ([link]John 15:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:19-21a[/link]). Furthermore, God has replaced everything in His Old Testament economy with Christ ([link]Matt. 17:3-5[/link]; [link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]; [link]Heb. 10:5-14[/link]). Thus, the all-inclusive Christ as Immanuel ([link]7:14[/link]) replaces everything and becomes everything in God's economy.

verse.text: The burden concerning [xref]a[/xref]Tyre: / Howl, O ships of Tarshish, / For [note]1[/note]it is destroyed — lacking house, / Lacking entrance. From [i]as far away as[/i] the land of [note]2[/note]Kittim / It is told to them.
verse.note: I.e., Tyre, the subject of this burden.
Probably modern-day Cyprus. So also in [link]v. 12[/link].

verse.text: Hush, you inhabitants of the coastland, / You, whom the merchants of Sidon, / Who cross the sea, have replenished.
And by [i]way of[/i] many waters / The grain of Shihor, the harvest of the Nile, was her revenue; / And she was profit to the nations.

Be ashamed, O Sidon, for the sea has spoken, / The stronghold of the sea, saying, / I have not been in labor nor given birth; / Neither have I brought up young men, / [i]Nor[/i] have I raised virgins.
When the report [i]reaches[/i] Egypt, / They will writhe in pain at the report concerning Tyre.
Cross over to Tarshish; / Howl, you inhabitants of the coastland.
Is this your jubilant [i]city,[/i] / Whose antiquity is from the days of antiquity, / Whose feet carried her off afar to sojourn?
Who has purposed this / Against Tyre, the giver of crowns, / Whose merchants were princes, / Whose traders were the honorable of the earth?
Jehovah of hosts has purposed it, / To defile the pride of all beauty, / To bring into contempt all the honorable of the earth.
Overflow your land like a river, O daughter of Tarshish; / There is no more restraint.
He has stretched out His hand over the sea; / He has shaken kingdoms. / Jehovah has given commandment concerning Canaan / To destroy its strongholds.
And He has said, You shall not continue to exult any longer, / O crushed virgin daughter of Sidon. / Arise; cross over to Kittim — / There also you will have no rest.

See the land of the [note]1[/note]Chaldeans, this people! They were not — the Assyrians assigned it to desert animals; they raised their siege towers; they stripped their citadels; they brought it to ruin.
verse.note: I.e., Babylonians.

verse.text: Howl, O ships of Tarshish, / For your stronghold is destroyed.
In that day Tyre will be forgotten for [xref]a[/xref]seventy years, like the days of one king. At the end of the seventy years Tyre will be like [i]her in[/i] the harlot's song:
Take a harp; / Compass the city, / Forgotten harlot. / Play well; / Abound in song, / That you may be remembered.
And at the end of the seventy years Jehovah will visit Tyre. And she will return to the wages of her harlotry and will be a harlot to all the kingdoms of the earth on land's surface.

And her profit and the wages of her harlotry will be dedicated to Jehovah; it will not be stored up, nor will it be hoarded, for her profit will be for those who dwell before Jehovah, as [i]their[/i] sufficient food and [i]their[/i] choice clothing.
Jehovah now makes the [xref]a[/xref]earth desolate and lays it waste; He distorts its surface and scatters its inhabitants:

As it is with the people, so will it be with the priest; / As it is with the servant, so will it be with the master; / As it is with the maid, so will it be with the mistress; / As it is with the buyer, so will it be with the seller; / As it is with the lender, so will it be with the borrower; / As it is with the creditor, so will it be with him to whom he gives credit.
The earth will be utterly desolated / And utterly spoiled, / For Jehovah has spoken this word.
The earth dries up and fades away; / The world languishes and fades away; / The exalted of the people of the earth languish.
And the earth is [xref]a[/xref]polluted under [i]the weight[/i] of its inhabitants; / For they have transgressed laws, they have violated statutes, / They have broken an eternal covenant.
Therefore a curse devours the earth / And the inhabitants of it are held guilty; / Therefore the inhabitants of the earth are burned, / And few men are left.
The new wine mourns; the vine languishes; / All the merryhearted sigh.
The mirth of the tambourines [xref]a[/xref]ceases; / The noise of those who exult stops; / The mirth of the lyre ceases.
[i]Men[/i] do not drink wine in song; / Liquor is bitter to those who drink it.
The city of chaos is broken down; / Every house is shut up that none may enter.
A cry for wine is in the streets; / All joy is darkened; / The mirth of the land is departed.
In the city desolation remains, / And the gate is crushed to ruins.
For thus will it be in the midst of the earth, / Among the peoples: / Like the shaking of an olive tree, / Like the gleanings when the grape harvest is completed.
They will lift up their voice; they will give a ringing shout; / Because of the majesty of Jehovah they will cry out from the west.
Therefore in the east glorify Jehovah, / Even the [xref]a[/xref]name of Jehovah the God of Israel in the coastlands of the sea.

From the ends of the earth we hear songs: / [note]1[/note]Glory to the righteous One! / But I say, Leanness to me! Leanness to me! Woe to me! / The unfaithful deal unfaithfully! / Indeed the unfaithful deal most unfaithfully!
verse.note: Or, Beauty, honor.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Dread, pit, and [xref]b[/xref]snare / Are upon you, O inhabitant of the earth.

And he who flees from the sound of dread / Will fall into the pit, / And he who comes up out of the pit / Will be taken in the snare; / For the windows from on high are open, / And the foundations of the earth shake.
The earth is broken asunder; / The earth is split through and through; / The earth is shaken violently.
The earth staggers back and forth like a drunkard / And sways about like a field hut. / And its transgression weighs heavily upon it; / It will fall and will not rise again.
And in that day Jehovah will punish / On high the [note]1[/note]host on high, / And the [xref]a[/xref]kings of the earth on the earth.
verse.note: Here [i]the host on high[/i] refers to Satan and his angels in the air (cf. [link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]). Jehovah's reaction to the nations' excessive action on Israel deals both with Satan's army in the air and with the kings on the earth. See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].

verse.text: And they will be gathered together, / [i]Like[/i] prisoners gathered in a dungeon; / And will be shut up in prison, / And after many days they will be punished.
Then the [xref]a[/xref]moon will be abashed, and the sun will be ashamed; / For Jehovah of hosts will reign / In Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, / And [i]His[/i] glory will be before His elders.
O Jehovah, You are my God; / I will exalt You, I will give thanks to Your name, / For You have done wonderful [i]things[/i] — / Counsels of old, in faithfulness, [i]perfect[/i] faithfulness.
For You have made of a city a heap, / Of a fortified town a ruin. / A palace of strangers [i]becomes[/i] no city [i]at all;[/i] / It will never be rebuilt.
Therefore a strong people will glorify You; / The cities of terrifying nations will fear You.

For You have been a stronghold to the weak, / A stronghold to the needy in his distress, / A [xref]a[/xref]refuge from the storm, a shade from the heat; / For the breath of those who terrify is like a tempest against a wall.
Like the heat in a drought, / You will subdue the uproar of strangers; / [i]Like[/i] the heat through the shadow of a cloud, / The song of those who terrify will be brought low.

And Jehovah of hosts will make on this [xref]a[/xref]mountain / For all the [note]1[/note]peoples / A feast of fat things, / A feast of wine [i]matured[/i] on the lees, / Of fat things full of marrow, / [i]And[/i] of filtered wine [i]matured[/i] on the lees.
verse.note: Here [i]peoples[/i] refers to the nations. In the restoration God will make a satisfying feast for the nations. At that time Jerusalem with Mount Zion will be the most joyful place on earth. It will be a center to which all the peoples of the earth will come to find enjoyment and satisfaction ([link]2:2-3[/link]).

verse.text: And on this mountain He will swallow up / The [note]1[/note]covering that covers up all the peoples, / Even the [xref]a[/xref]veil that veils all the nations.
verse.note: Lit., the face of the covering that covers up. Today the people on earth are covered with a veil that keeps them from seeing God's economy (cf. [link]2 Cor. 3:15[/link]; [link]4:4[/link]), but in the restoration God will take away this covering. Then all the people will see something concerning God's eternal economy.

verse.text: He will swallow up [xref]a[/xref]death [note]1[/note]forever; / And the Lord Jehovah will wipe away the [xref]b[/xref]tears from all faces; / And the reproach of His people He will remove from all the earth; / For Jehovah has spoken.
verse.note: Lit., unto perpetuity. The Hebrew phrase, however, also contains the notion of eminence; thus, the Septuagint translated it [i]having prevailed,[/i] and Paul freely rendered it [i]unto victory[/i] ([link]1 Cor. 15:54[/link]).

verse.text: And it will be said in that day, / Here, this is our God, / For whom we have [xref]a[/xref]waited that He may save us. / This is Jehovah, for whom we have waited; / Let us be glad and [xref]b[/xref]rejoice in His salvation.
For the hand of Jehovah will rest on this mountain, / And Moab will be threshed in his place, / Even as straw is threshed in the water of a dung heap.
And he will spread out his hands in the middle of it, / As a swimmer spreads out [i]his hands[/i] to swim; / But [i]Jehovah[/i] will abase his pride together with the trickery of his hands.
And the lofty fortification of your walls He will bring down, / Lay low, [i]and[/i] cast to the ground, [i]even[/i] to the dust.
In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:[br/]We have a strong city; / He will set up salvation as walls and a rampart.
[xref]a[/xref]Open the gates / So that the righteous nation may enter, / They who maintain faithfulness.
You will keep the steadfast of mind / In perfect [xref]a[/xref]peace / Because he trusts in You.
Trust in Jehovah forever and ever, / For in Jah Jehovah [i]we have[/i] an eternal [xref]a[/xref]rock.
For He has brought down those who dwell on high, / The lofty city; / He lays it low, He lays it low to the ground; / He casts it into the dust.
The foot will trample it, the foot of the poor, / The steps of the weak.
The path of the righteous is smoothness; / O You who are upright, You make the path of the righteous level.
Indeed in the [note]1[/note]path of Your judgments, / O Jehovah, we have [xref]a[/xref]waited for You. / Your name, that is, Your memorial, / Is the desire of [i]our[/i] soul.
verse.note: While the Lord is chastening us, we should wait for Him in the path of His judging in order to learn the lesson that He would give us. God's judgments always teach us lessons in righteousness ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: My soul desires You in the [xref]a[/xref]night; / Indeed my spirit within me seeks You at the dawn; / For when Your judgments are in the earth, / The inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.
[i]Though[/i] the wicked is shown grace, / He does not learn righteousness; / In the land of straightforwardness he deals unjustly / And does not perceive the majesty of Jehovah.
O Jehovah, Your hand is lifted up, / [i]But[/i] they do not see it. / They will see [i]Your[/i] zeal for the people and will be put to shame; / Indeed fire will [xref]a[/xref]devour Your adversaries.
O Jehovah, You will ordain [xref]a[/xref]peace for us, / For You have also performed all our works for us.
O Jehovah our God, other [note]1[/note]lords besides You have been master to us, / [i]But[/i] through You alone do we [xref]a[/xref]mention Your name.
verse.note: Because Israel had become rebellious, God used the nations to discipline them. But the action of the nations was excessive; they went too far, overstepping the limit set by God. In assuming to be lords and acting as if they were the master, the nations went too far. Thus, God judges them and punishes them ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]24:21-22[/link]; [link]25:2-3[/link]; [link]27:1[/link]).[br][br]God's chastising of Israel and His judgment on the nations who exercise excessive action upon Israel issues in three things: (1) Israel is brought back to God; (2) the created things are restored; and (3) the all-inclusive Christ is ushered in. When Israel turns to God, there will be the restoration of all things. Then the all-inclusive Christ will be ushered in. This is the basic and governing principle of Isaiah's prophecy, especially in the first thirty-nine chapters.

verse.text: The dead will not live, / The deceased will not rise; / Therefore You have visited and destroyed them, / And You have caused all memory of them to perish.

[xref]a[/xref]You have [note]1[/note]increased the nation, O Jehovah; / You have increased the nation — You are [xref]b[/xref]glorified; / You have far [note]1[/note]extended all the edges of the land.
verse.note: To increase the nation is to increase the people, and to extend the edges is to enlarge the territory. In the restoration the Holy Land will extend from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates ([link]Deut. 11:24[/link] and note).

verse.text: O Jehovah, in distress they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sought You; / They whispered out a prayer, [i]for[/i] Your chastening was upon them.
verse.note: Jehovah's reaction to Israel's degradation issues in their turning to Jehovah ([link]24:14-16a[/link]; [link]25:1[/link], [link]4-5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]26:8-9[/link]) and their return to the Holy Land for restoration ([link]vv. 1-4[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]24:23[/link]; [link]25:6-7[/link]; [link]27:2-9[/link], [link]12-13[/link]).

verse.text: As a [xref]a[/xref]pregnant woman draws near to giving birth, / She writhes [i]and[/i] cries out in her pain; / So we have been before You, O Jehovah.
We were pregnant; we writhed; we gave birth, as it were, to wind. / We have not accomplished deliverance for the earth, / Nor have the inhabitants of the world been born.

Your dead will [xref]a[/xref]live; my corpses will [xref]b[/xref]rise. / [xref]c[/xref]Awake and give a ringing shout, you who dwell in dust, / For your dew is like the dew of the dawn, / And the earth will bring forth the deceased.
Come, my people, enter your rooms, / And [xref]a[/xref]shut your doors behind you; / Hide for a short moment / Until the indignation has passed;

For Jehovah is now [xref]a[/xref]coming forth from His place / To punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity; / And the earth will reveal her bloodshed / And will no longer conceal her slain.

In that day Jehovah will punish, / With His harsh, great, and mighty sword, / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Leviathan the fleeing serpent, / And leviathan the crooked serpent; / And He will slay the dragon that is in the sea.
verse.note: Toward Israel the nations were like leviathan, the fleeing and crooked serpent, and like the dragon in the sea. In His reaction to the nations' excessive action on Israel (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link]), Jehovah punished leviathan and slew the dragon in the sea.

verse.text: In that day: / A [xref]a[/xref]vineyard of [note]1[/note]wine, [xref]b[/xref]sing of it!
verse.note: Some MSS read, delight.

verse.text: I, Jehovah, am its [xref]a[/xref]keeper; / Every moment I water it. / Lest anyone visit harm upon it, / By night and by day I guard it.
I have no wrath. / Oh that I had thorns [i]and[/i] thistles! / In battle I would march against them; / I would burn them completely.
Or let him grasp at My strength; / Let him make peace with Me; / Let him make peace with Me.
In the days to come Jacob will [xref]a[/xref]take root; / Israel will blossom and bud; / And they will fill the surface of the world with [i]their[/i] produce.
Has He struck them like those who struck them? / Have they been slain like those slain by Him?
By expulsion [i]and[/i] by banishing them, You contended with them; / He sent [i]them[/i] away with His harsh wind in the day of the east wind.

Thus by this the iniquity of Jacob will be expiated, / And this is all the fruit of the [xref]a[/xref]removal of their sin; / When they make all the stones of [i]their[/i] altar / Like chalk stones beaten to powder — / Asherahs and sun images will not stand.
For the fortified city is isolated; / The habitation is given up and abandoned like a wilderness. / There the calf will feed, / And there he will lie down and consume its branches.

When its boughs are withered, they will be broken off; / Women come [i]and[/i] make a fire with them; / For they are [xref]a[/xref]not a people of understanding. / Therefore He who made them will not have compassion on them, / And He who formed them will not show favor to them.

And in that day Jehovah will beat out [i]the[/i] [note]1[/note][i]grain[/i] from the flowing stream of / the [note]2[/note]River / Unto the brook of Egypt; / And you will be [xref]a[/xref]gleaned / One by one, O you children of Israel.
verse.note: The grain here denotes the scattered people of Israel. The fulfillment of the prophecy in [link]vv. 12-13[/link], concerning the gathering of all the outcast, lost, and scattered Israelites back to the Holy Land, began with the return of the captives from Babylon; it is continuing today, and it will be fully accomplished at the time of the Lord's second coming.
I.e., the Euphrates.

verse.text: And in that day a great [xref]a[/xref]trumpet will be blown, / And the ones lost in the land of Assyria will come, / As well as the outcasts in the land of Egypt, / And they will worship Jehovah / On the holy mountain in Jerusalem.
Woe to the proud crown of the drunkards of [note]1[/note]Ephraim / And to the fading flower of its glorious beauty, / Which is at the head of the fat valley of those who are overcome by wine.
verse.note: Representing the northern kingdom of Israel.

verse.text: Indeed the Lord has [note]1[/note]someone strong and mighty; / As a [xref]a[/xref]hailstorm [i]and[/i] a tempest of destruction, / As a storm of mighty overflowing waters, / He will cast down to the earth with [i]His[/i] hand.
verse.note: Probably first the king of Assyria and then the king of Babylon ([link]2 Kings 17:3-18[/link]; [link]24:10-16[/link]).

verse.text: The proud crown of the drunkards of Ephraim / Will be trodden under foot;

And the fading flower of its glorious beauty, / Which is at the head of the fat valley, / Will be like the first-ripe [i]fig[/i] before the summer, / Which when someone looks upon it he sees it, / [i]And[/i] in an instant it is in his hand, and he swallows it up.
In that day Jehovah of hosts / Will become a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]crown of glory and a [note]1[/note]diadem of beauty to the [xref]b[/xref]remnant of His people,
verse.note: Jehovah's punishing of Israel issues in His restoration. Jehovah of hosts as Christ will be a crown of beauty and a diadem of glory to the remnant of Israel, God's chosen people, in the age of restoration after all God's dealing with Israel is completed.

verse.text: And a spirit of justice for him who sits in judgment / And strength to those who turn away the battle at the gate.

But these also reel with wine / And stagger from liquor: / The priest and the prophet stagger from liquor; / They are swallowed up with wine; / They stagger from liquor, / They reel in [i]their[/i] visions, / They totter in [i]their[/i] judgments.
For all the tables are full of vomit [i]and[/i] filth; / There is no place [i]clean.[/i]
Whom will he teach knowledge? / And whom will he instruct with the report? / Those weaned from [xref]a[/xref]milk? / Those drawn from the breasts?
For [i]his words are:[/i] [note]1[/note]Rule upon rule, rule upon rule; / Line upon line, line upon line; / Here a little, there a little.
verse.note: These rules were parts of the law. Ephraim was bothered by the fact that Jehovah's rules and statutes were scattered repeatedly in pieces.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For with stammering lips / And with a [note]1[/note]foreign tongue / He will speak to this people,
verse.note: The tongue of the Gentile invaders, which became a bothering and a shame to Ephraim (cf. [link]1 Cor. 14:21[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: He who said to them, / This is rest; give rest to the weary; / And, This is repose. / But they would not hear.

Therefore Jehovah's word to them will be: / [note]1[/note]Rule upon rule, rule upon rule; / Line upon line, line upon line; / Here a little, there a little; / That they may go and stumble backward, / And be broken, snared, and taken.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Therefore hear the word of Jehovah, / You scoffing men, / Who rule this people / Who are in [note]1[/note]Jerusalem:
verse.note: Jehovah destroyed the northern kingdom of Israel by the Assyrian army ([link]vv. 14-15[/link], [link]17-20[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]2 Kings 17:3-18[/link]). This was done as a warning to Jerusalem, which represents the southern kingdom of Judah.

verse.text: Because you have said, We have made / A covenant with [xref]a[/xref]death, / And with Sheol / We have made an agreement: / When the overflowing scourge passes through, / It will not come upon us; / For we have made falsehood our refuge / And have hidden ourselves in deception.

Therefore thus says / The Lord Jehovah: / [xref]a[/xref]Indeed I lay a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stone in Zion as a foundation, / A tested stone, / A precious [note]1[/note]cornerstone [i]as a[/i] foundation firmly established; / [xref]c[/xref]He who believes will not hasten away.
verse.note: Jehovah's punishment over Ephraim's drunkards will also usher in the trustworthy Christ as a foundation stone and a precious cornerstone for God's building ([link]Psa. 118:22-24[/link] and notes). The complete fulfillment of Christ as the stone will be in the next age, the age of restoration ([link]Psa. 118:26[/link] and note; cf. [link]Matt. 23:38-39[/link] and note [link]39[sup]1[/sup][/link]).[br][br]In contrast to the priest and the prophet described in [link]v. 7[/link], the trustworthy Christ is the faithful High Priest and the trustworthy Prophet to God's redeemed ([link]Heb. 7:26[/link]; [link]Acts 3:22-23[/link]).

verse.text: And I will make justice the line / And righteousness the plummet; / And the hail will sweep away the refuge of lies, / And the waters will overflow the secret place.
And your covenant with death will be annulled, / And your agreement with Sheol will not stand; / When the [xref]a[/xref]overflowing scourge passes through, / You will be a trampling ground to it.

As often as it passes through, / It will take hold of you. / For morning by morning it will pass through, / By day and by night; / And it will be nothing but terror / To understand the report [i]of it.[/i]
For the bed is too short for a man to stretch on, / And the sheet is too narrow for him to wrap himself in.

For Jehovah will [note]1[/note]rise as on Mount [xref]a[/xref]Perazim, / He will be agitated as in the valley of [xref]b[/xref]Gibeon, / To do His deed, His strange deed, / And to do His work, His most different work.
verse.note: This is Jehovah's reaction of fighting against the Assyrians, who had destroyed Israel excessively (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link]).

verse.text: Now therefore do not be mockers, / Lest your fetters become stronger; / For I have heard from the Lord Jehovah of hosts / Of complete and decisive [xref]a[/xref]destruction upon the whole earth.
Hearken and hear my voice; / Attend and hear my speech.
Does the [note]1[/note]plowman plow all day long to sow his seed? / Does he open and harrow his ground [i]continually?[/i]
verse.note: In [link]vv. 24-29[/link] Jehovah, as a farmer, deals with people as His crops by different utensils according to His extraordinary counsel and His great wisdom.

verse.text: Does he not, once he levels the surface, / Scatter dill and broadcast cummin, / And put the wheat in rows and the barley in [i]its[/i] appointed place / And the rye where it belongs?
For his God instructs him toward [i]such[/i] discretion / And teaches him [i]so.[/i]
For dill is not threshed with a sharp tool, / Nor is the cart wheel turned upon the cummin; / But dill is beaten out with a rod, / And cummin with a stick.
Bread grains are ground, / Yet one does not thresh and thresh forever. / And once the wheel of his cart and his horses drive over [i]it,[/i] / One does not grind it.
This also comes forth from Jehovah of hosts, / He who makes [i]His[/i] counsel [xref]a[/xref]extraordinary and [i]His[/i] sound wisdom great.
Woe to [note]1[/note]Ariel, to Ariel, / The city where David camped! / Add year to year; let the feasts run their course.
verse.note: Meaning [i]a lion of El.[/i] A symbolic name for Jerusalem, and representing the southern kingdom of Judah.

verse.text: But I will distress Ariel, / And she will become mourning and lamentation / And will be like an Ariel to me.
And I will [xref]a[/xref]encamp in a circle against you, / And will besiege you with palisades, / And will raise up siegeworks against you.

And you will be brought down; from the ground you will speak, / And your speech will [i]come[/i] from low in the dust. / And your voice will be like that of a departed spirit from the ground, / And your speech will twitter from the dust.
But the multitude of your enemies will be like fine dust, / And the multitude of those who terrorize will be like chaff that passes / away; / And it will happen in an instant, suddenly.
From Jehovah of hosts you will be visited, / With thunder and earthquake and great noise, / With whirlwind and tempest and the flame of consuming fire.
And the multitude of all the nations that fight against Ariel, / Even all who fight against her and her stronghold and who distress her, / Will be like a dream, [i]like[/i] a vision in the night.

And as when a hungry man dreams and [i]finds himself[/i] eating, / But he awakens and what he desires is not there; / Or as when a thirsty man dreams and [i]finds himself[/i] drinking, / But he awakens and is indeed faint and what he desires is far from him; / So will the multitude of all the nations be / That fight against Mount Zion.
Linger and be astounded, / Blind yourselves and be blind. / They are drunk, but not with wine; / They stagger, but not with liquor.
[xref]a[/xref]For Jehovah has poured out upon you / A spirit of deep sleep / And has shut your [xref]b[/xref]eyes, the prophets; / And your heads, the seers, He has covered.

And all the vision will be to you like the words of a book that has been sealed, which when they give to him who is literate, saying, Please read this, he will say, I am not able to, for it is sealed.
Then the book will be given to him who is illiterate, saying, Please read this, and he will say, I am illiterate.

And the Lord said, / [xref]a[/xref]Because this people [note]1[/note]draws near with their mouth, / And with their lips they honor Me, / Yet they remove their heart far from Me, / And their fear for Me / Is a commandment of men [i]merely[/i] learned;
verse.note: The northern kingdom of Israel was full of drunkards ([link]ch. 28[/link]), and the southern kingdom of Judah was full of hypocritical worshippers. These two conditions characterize the condition of fallen mankind on the earth. First, people are drunk by loving things other than the Lord, and second, they are not true but false. The kind of hypocritical worship described in this verse continued until the time of Christ ([link]Matt. 15:1-14[/link]; [link]John 4:20-24[/link]). As revealed in [link]vv. 1-12[/link], [link]14-16[/link], Jehovah judged the hypocrisy of the worshippers in Jerusalem.

verse.text: Therefore, indeed, I will once again / Do something [xref]a[/xref]wondrous with this people, something wondrously marvelous; / And the wisdom of their wise men will [xref]b[/xref]perish, / And the understanding of those who understand will be hidden.
Woe to those who [note]1[/note]hide deeply / Their counsel from Jehovah, / And whose deeds are in the dark / And who say, Who sees us? And, Who knows us?
verse.note: With the hypocritical worship spoken of in this chapter, there was vanity but no reality ([link]v. 13[/link]) and blindness but no wisdom ([link]vv. 9-12[/link], [link]15-16[/link]). Through His incarnation Christ brought to us the very reality of the universe — the Triune God, the Divine Trinity, embodied in a person, Jesus Christ ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]). When we realize the embodied reality, the Divine Trinity in Christ, our eyes, our ears, and our understanding are opened, and we have wisdom. Christ is the reality and wisdom to God's redeemed people ([link]John 14:6a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:24[/link], [link]30[/link]) that makes them true worshippers of God ([link]John 4:23-24[/link]).

verse.text: You turn things upside down! / Shall the potter be considered to be like the clay, / That [xref]a[/xref]what is made should say of him who made it, He did not make me, / Or what is formed should say of him who formed it, He has no understanding?
[note]1[/note]Is it not yet a little while / Before Lebanon will be turned into a fruitful field, / And the fruitful field will be considered to be a forest.
verse.note: Jehovah's judgment on the hypocrisy of Jerusalem's worshippers issues in the restoration ([link]vv. 17-24[/link]).

verse.text: And in that day the [xref]a[/xref]deaf will hear the words of the book, / And out of gloom and darkness the eyes of the blind will see,
And the [xref]a[/xref]afflicted will increase their joy in Jehovah, / And the needy of mankind will exult in the Holy One of Israel.
For he who terrorizes will cease to be, and the scorner will be consumed, / And all who watch for iniquity will be cut off,
Those who make a man sin by his words / And ensnare him who judges at the gate / And turn aside the righteous with an empty argument.
Therefore thus says Jehovah, who [xref]a[/xref]redeemed Abraham, concerning the house of Jacob,[br/]Jacob will not now be ashamed, / Nor will his face now turn pale;
But when he sees his children, the work of My hands, in his midst, / They will [xref]a[/xref]sanctify My name / And sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, / And hold the [xref]b[/xref]God of Israel in awe.
And those who have erred in spirit will come to understand, / And the murmurers will learn teaching.
Woe to the rebellious children, / Declares Jehovah, / Who devise counsel, but not of Me, / And who [note]1[/note]make an alliance, but not of My Spirit, / In order to add / Sin upon sin;
verse.note: Lit., pour out a libation. These were drink offerings that the Gentiles poured out to their idols in making an alliance.

verse.text: Who go down to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Egypt, / Yet do not [xref]b[/xref]ask of My mouth, / To take refuge in the refuge of Pharaoh, / And to take shelter in the shadow of Egypt.
verse.note: Egypt typifies the world. Whenever God's people are in a fallen condition or low estate, they go to Egypt ([link]Gen. 12:10[/link]; [link]42:1-3[/link]). To make an alliance with the world or to rely on the world is sin, and it always issues in humiliation, shame, and reproach ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore the refuge of Pharaoh will be your shame, / And shelter in the shadow of Egypt, [i]your[/i] humiliation.
For their princes are at Zoan, / And their ambassadors have come to Hanes.
All are ashamed / Of a people that cannot profit them, / Nor be a help or profit [i]to them,[/i] / But rather a shame and also a reproach.

The burden concerning the beasts of the [note]1[/note]Negev: / Through the land of distress and anguish, / From which [i]come[/i] lioness and lion, / Viper and flying fiery serpent, / They carry their riches upon young donkeys' backs / And their treasures upon camels' humps / To a people that cannot profit [i]them;[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].

verse.text: For Egypt [xref]a[/xref]helps in a vain and empty way. / Therefore I call her / Rahab, who sits still.
Go now; write it on a tablet before them, / And inscribe it on a scroll, / That it may be, for the time to come, / [note]1[/note]As a witness forever.
verse.note: According to some MSS and most ancient versions; otherwise read, Forever and ever.

verse.text: For this is a rebellious people, / False children, / Children who refuse to hear / The instruction of Jehovah;
Who say to those who see, Do not see; / And to those who have visions, Do [xref]a[/xref]not give us true visions; / Speak pleasant things to us; / Give [i]us[/i] illusions as your visions;
Get out of the way; / Turn aside from the path; / Cause the Holy One of Israel / To cease from before us.
Therefore thus says the Holy One of Israel, / Because you despise this word / And trust in oppression and guile, / And rely on them,
Therefore this iniquity / Will be to you / Like a breach ready to fall, / Sticking out on a high wall, / Whose crashing comes / In an instant, suddenly.

And its crashing will be like the crashing of the potters' [xref]a[/xref]vessel: / Crushed — he will not spare; / And there will not be found / Among the crushed pieces a shard / [i]With which[/i] to take fire from the hearth / Or to draw water from the cistern.

For thus says the Lord Jehovah, the Holy One of Israel, / In [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]returning and [xref]b[/xref]rest you will be saved; / In quietness and in trust will be your strength; / But you were [xref]c[/xref]not willing,
verse.note: Jehovah's dealing with Israel's reliance on Egypt and His dealing with the nations issue in Israel's turn to Jehovah ([link]v. 15[/link]; [link]31:6-7[/link]) and in Jehovah's return to Israel ([link]v. 18[/link]; [link]31:4-5[/link], [link]9b[/link]) with the restoration ([link]vv. 19-26[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Acts 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: And said, No, for we will flee on horses; / Therefore you will flee. / And, We will ride upon the swift; / Therefore those who chase you will be swift.

One thousand [i]will[/i] [xref]a[/xref][i]flee[/i] at the rebuke of one; / At the rebuke of five you will flee, / Until you are left / Like a [i]bare[/i] mast upon a mountaintop / And a standard on a hill.

And therefore Jehovah waits to be gracious to you, / And therefore He remains on high to have compassion on you; / For Jehovah is a God of justice; / [xref]a[/xref]Blessed are those who [xref]b[/xref]wait for Him.
For a people will [xref]a[/xref]dwell in Zion at Jerusalem — / You will weep no more; / He will be most gracious to you at the sound of your cry; / When He hears it, He will answer you.

And though the Lord has given you / The [xref]a[/xref]bread of adversity and the water of oppression, / Your [note]1[/note]Teacher will no longer [xref]b[/xref]hide Himself in a corner, / But your eyes will see your Teacher.
verse.note: In the Old Testament age Christ hid Himself in a mystery, but in the age of restoration, the millennium, He will be manifested to Israel. In the New Testament age of grace Christ is already manifested to His believers as their Teacher ([link]Matt. 23:8[/link], [link]10[/link]).

verse.text: And your ears will hear a word behind you, saying, / This is the [xref]a[/xref]way, walk in it, / When you turn to the right or turn to the left.
And you will defile the silver covering of your graven images / And the gold plating of your molten idols; / You will scatter them like some dirty thing; / You will say to it, Go away!

Then He will give rain for your seed, / Which you will sow in the ground, / And the bread of the increase of the ground; / And it will be fat and plenteous. / Your livestock will feed in that day / In a vast pasture.
And the oxen and donkeys that work the ground / Will eat salted fodder that has been winnowed with shovel and fork.
And upon every high [xref]a[/xref]mountain / And upon every prominent hill / There will be brooks [i]and[/i] [xref]b[/xref]streams of water / In the day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall.

And the [xref]a[/xref]light of the moon will be like the light of the sun, / And the light of the sun will be [note]1[/note]sevenfold, like the light of seven days, / On the day when Jehovah binds up the breach of His people / And heals the wound [i]left[/i] from His stroke.
verse.note: In the consideration of the godly people, mainly the prophets, there was the expectation that the Messiah would come to restore not only the kingdom of Israel (cf. [link]Acts 1:6[/link]) but also the entire universe, especially the sun, the moon, and the stars, for the growing of the living things on the earth, that the earth might be very rich in produce. In the restoration the light of the sun will be sevenfold not for scorching but for shining, for giving sunshine to grow the living things on earth. This means that the heavens will answer the earth and cause it to grow things in a rich way ([link]Hosea 2:21-22[/link]). The sun's shining seven times brighter indicates that the produce of the earth will be seven times richer than it is in this age. At that time there will be no scarcity but rather plenitude. See notes [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Hosea 6[/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Joel 3[/link].

verse.text: Behold, the name of Jehovah comes from a distance, / Burning with His anger and heavy with smoke; / His lips are full of indignation, / And His tongue is like a devouring fire;

His breath, like an overflowing stream, / Reaches up to the neck, / To [xref]a[/xref]sift the nations with the sieve of [note]1[/note]nothingness; / And a bridle that leads them to err is in the jaws of the peoples.
verse.note: Referring to the result of destruction. After Jehovah deals with Israel, He deals with the nations, sifting them with the sieve of destruction ([link]vv. 27-33[/link]; [link]31:8-9a[/link]).

verse.text: You will have a song / As in the night when the feast is sanctified, / And gladness of heart as when one marches to the flute / To go to the [xref]a[/xref]mountain of Jehovah, to the Rock of Israel.

And Jehovah will cause the majesty of His voice to be heard / And the descending of His arm to be seen, / With the blasting of anger and the flame of devouring fire, / In cloudburst, downpour, and hailstones.
For at the voice of Jehovah, [xref]a[/xref]Assyria will be dismayed; / With a staff He will strike.
And every pass of the appointed rod, / Which Jehovah will lay upon him, / Will be with tambourines and harps; / And in battles of brandishing weapons He will fight against them.

For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Topheth has been arranged since long ago; / Indeed it has been prepared for the king; / He made [i]it[/i] deep; He made [i]it[/i] large. / The pile in it is of fire and much wood; / The breath of Jehovah, like a stream of [xref]b[/xref]brimstone, / Sets it on fire.
verse.note: A place in the valley of Hinnom, south of Jerusalem. See note [link]22[sup]8[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: Woe to those who go down to [xref]a[/xref]Egypt for help; / They rely on horses / And trust in [xref]b[/xref]chariots because they are many / And in horsemen because they are very strong; / But they do not look to the Holy One of Israel, / Nor [xref]c[/xref]seek Jehovah!
But He also is wise and will bring ill [i]upon them;[/i] / And He does not turn back His words, / But will rise up against the house of evildoers / And against the help of the workers of iniquity.

The Egyptians are [i]mere[/i] men and not God, / And their horses are [i]mere[/i] flesh and not spirit; / Thus Jehovah will stretch out His hand, / And he who helps will stumble and he who is helped will fall, / And all of them will be consumed together.

For Jehovah has spoken thus to me, / As the lion or the lion cub / [xref]a[/xref]Roars over its prey / [i]And[/i] because of it a crowd of shepherds / Is called out, / [i]But[/i] it is not frightened by their voice, / Nor overcome by their noise; / So Jehovah of hosts will descend / To [xref]b[/xref]wage war on Mount Zion and on its hill.
Like flying birds / So Jehovah of hosts will [xref]a[/xref]protect Jerusalem; / He will protect and deliver [i]it;[/i] / He will pass over and rescue [i]it.[/i]
Return to Him from whom [i]men[/i] have deeply revolted, O children of Israel.
For in that day each man will cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold, which your hands have made for you as a sin.
And the [xref]a[/xref]Assyrian will fall by the sword not of a man, / And the sword not of man will devour him. / Thus he will flee from a sword, / And his young men will be forced into labor.
And his rock will pass away in terror, / And his princes will be dismayed by the standard, / Declares Jehovah, whose [xref]a[/xref]fire is in Zion / And whose furnace is in Jerusalem.
Indeed a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]King will reign according to [note]2[/note]righteousness, / And the [note]1[/note]rulers will rule according to [note]2[/note]justice.
verse.note: Christ as Jehovah and also as man is the King for supplying, caring for, and covering God's people ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]; [link]33:22[/link]). He rules not directly by Himself but indirectly through the rulers. In the millennium Christ will be the King, and many of those who love Him will be the rulers, His co-kings ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:2[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]; [link]12:5[/link]; [link]20:4[/link]).

Righteousness is to be right, whereas justice is righteousness with a judgment. Christ will reign according to righteousness, and He will rule through His helpers, the rulers, to judge the people according to justice.
verse.xref: Psa. 45:1; Jer. 23:5; Hosea 3:5; Zech. 9:9; cf. Heb. 7:2
