verse.text: And a [note]1[/note]man will be like a [xref]a[/xref]refuge from the wind / And a covering from the tempest, / Like [xref]b[/xref]streams of water in a dry place, / Like the shadow of a massive rock in a wasted land.
verse.note: On the one hand, Christ will be the King ruling ([link]v. 1[/link]); on the other hand, He will be a man protecting, covering, supplying, and overshadowing. Under Him there will be righteousness, protection, and enjoyment. This is a picture of the millennial kingdom.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]eyes of those who see will [xref]a[/xref]not be dim, / And the ears of those who hear will attend.
verse.note: As the King ([link]v. 1[/link]), Christ will bring in the restoration for Israel ([link]vv. 3-4[/link], [link]15-18[/link]; [link]33:2[/link], [link]5-6[/link], [link]20-22[/link]; [link]35:1-2[/link], [link]5-10[/link]).

verse.text: And the heart of the hasty will understand knowledge, / And the tongue of those who stammer will hasten to speak elegantly.
The fool will no longer be called noble, / Nor will the cheat be said to be generous;

For the fool will speak foolishness, / And his heart will commit iniquity / By committing profaneness / And by speaking error against Jehovah, / By leaving the soul of the hungry empty / And by causing drink for the thirsty to fail.
And as for the cheat, his tools are evil; / He devises wicked schemes / To destroy the poor with false words / Even when the needy speaks rightly.
But the noble man devises noble things, / And upon noble things he stands.
Rise up, O women who are at ease, / And hear my voice; / O daughters of complacency, / Hearken to my words.
In a year and some days / You will be troubled, O complacent ones; / For the vintage is at its end; / The ingathering will not come.
Tremble, O women at ease; / Be troubled, O complacent ones. / Strip yourselves and be bare, / And gird your loins [i]with sackcloth.[/i]
They beat their breasts / For the pleasant fields, / For the fruitful vine.
Upon the land of my people / Will come up thorns [i]and[/i] briers, / Indeed upon all the jubilant houses / In the exultant city.

Because the palace will be abandoned; / The multitude of the city will be forsaken; / The [note]1[/note]Hill and the watchtower / Will become caves forever, / A joy for wild asses, / A pasture for flocks;
verse.note: The fortified slope to the south of the temple area.

verse.text: Until the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit is poured upon us from on high, / And the wilderness becomes a fruitful field, / And the fruitful field is considered to be a forest.
Then justice will dwell in the wilderness, / And righteousness will remain in the fruitful field;
And the [xref]a[/xref]work of righteousness will be peace, / And the result of righteousness, quietness and assurance forever.
And my people will live in a peaceful habitation / And in secure dwellings and carefree resting places.
And it will hail when the forest comes down, / And the city will be utterly laid low.
Blessed are you who sow beside all the water, / Who send [i]there[/i] the feet of the ox and the donkey.

Woe to you who destroy and were not destroyed, / And to him who deals unfaithfully and was not dealt with unfaithfully! / When you have finished destroying, you will be destroyed; / And when you cease to deal unfaithfully, they will deal unfaithfully with you.
O Jehovah, be gracious to us; we have [xref]a[/xref]waited for You; / Be [note]1[/note]our arm every morning, / [xref]b[/xref]Our salvation also in the time of distress.
verse.note: Following some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, their.

verse.text: At the noise of the tumult the peoples flee; / At the lifting up of Yourself the nations were scattered.
And your spoil will be gathered [i]as[/i] the caterpillar gathers; / As locusts rush to and fro, [i]men[/i] will rush to and fro upon it.
Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]exalted, for He dwells on high; / He has filled Zion with justice and righteousness.
And there will be stability for your times: / A wealth of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge; / The fear of Jehovah is his treasure.
Indeed their heroes cry in the streets; / The ambassadors of peace weep bitterly.
The highways are desolate; / The traveler ceases [i]to travel.[/i] / He has broken the covenant; he despises the cities; / He does not regard man.
The land mourns [i]and[/i] languishes; / Lebanon is ashamed [i]and[/i] withers away; / Sharon is like a desert, / And Bashan and Carmel shake off [i]their leaves.[/i]
Now I will arise, says Jehovah, / Now I will be exalted; now I will be lifted up.
You will conceive chaff; you will give birth to stubble; / Your own breath, like fire, will devour you;
And the peoples will be like the burning of lime, / Like cut down thorns that are burned in the fire.
Hear, you who are far off, what I have done; / And know, you who are near, My might.
The sinners in Zion are terrified; / Trembling has seized the profane: / Who among us can dwell with consuming fire? / Who among us can dwell with [xref]a[/xref]everlasting burning?

He who walks in righteousness and speaks uprightness; / He who rejects gains seized by extortion; / He who shakes his hands lest they hold on to a bribe, / Who stops his ears so as not to hear of bloodshed / And shuts his eyes so as not to look at evil.
This one will dwell on the heights; / His lofty retreat will be the rocky strongholds; / His bread will be given [i]to him;[/i] his water will be sure.
Your eyes will see the [xref]a[/xref]King in His beauty; / They will behold a land that is very far away.
Your heart will meditate on terror: / Where is he who counts? Where is he who weighs? / Where is he who counts the towers?
You will not see a fierce people, / A people of unintelligible speech, hardly audible, / Of a stammering tongue which cannot be understood.

Look upon Zion, the [xref]a[/xref]city of our appointed feasts; / Your eyes will see Jerusalem, / A secure [xref]b[/xref]habitation, a tent that will not be removed; / Its stakes will never be pulled up, / And none of its cords will be torn apart.
But there the Majestic, Jehovah, will be for us / A place of [xref]a[/xref]rivers [i]and[/i] broad streams, / On which no boat with oars will go / And no majestic ship will pass.
For [note]1[/note]Jehovah is our [xref]a[/xref]Judge, / Jehovah is our [xref]b[/xref]Lawmaker, / Jehovah is our [xref]c[/xref]King; He will save us.
verse.note: In the restoration the all-inclusive Jehovah as Christ (cf. [link]32:1[/link]) will be the entire divine government, including the King, the Lawmaker, and the Judge, for the saving of His people.

verse.text: Your tackle has been slackened; / It does not support its mast firmly, / Nor does it spread out the sail. / Then the prey of abundant spoil is divided; / The lame take the plunder.
And the inhabitant will not say, I am sick; / The people who dwell there will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven [i]their[/i] iniquity.
Draw near, O nations, to hear; / And listen, O peoples! / Let the earth and all that fills it hear, / The world and all that springs forth from it.
For Jehovah's indignation is upon all the nations, / And [i]His[/i] wrath is upon all their [xref]a[/xref]armies; / He has utterly destroyed them; / He has delivered them unto the slaughter.
Thus their slain are cast away, / And [i]from[/i] their corpses their [xref]a[/xref]stench will come up; / And the mountains will be melted with their blood.

And all the armies of heaven will be dissolved, / And the [xref]a[/xref]heavens will be rolled up like a scroll, / And all their host will wither away, / As the leaf withers from the vine, / Or [xref]b[/xref]like a [i]leaf[/i] withering from the fig tree.
For My [xref]a[/xref]sword has drunk its fill in heaven. / Now it will descend in judgment upon [xref]b[/xref]Edom / And upon the people whom I have devoted to judgment.

Jehovah's sword is full of blood; / It has fattened itself with fat, / With the blood of lambs and goats, / With the fat of the kidneys of rams; / For Jehovah has a [note]1[/note]sacrifice in [xref]a[/xref]Bozrah / And a great slaughter in the land of Edom.
verse.note: This sacrifice in Bozrah and slaughter in the land of Edom will be fulfilled in full in the great war at Armageddon, which will take place in a region that extends to Bozrah ([link]63:1-6[/link] and note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: Wild oxen will also go down with them, / The young bulls with the bulls; / And their land will drink its fill of [i]their[/i] blood, / And their dust will become fat with [i]their[/i] fat.
For Jehovah has a [xref]a[/xref]day of vengeance, / A year of recompense for Zion's contention.
And [note]1[/note]its streams will be turned into pitch, / And its dust into brimstone; / And its land will become burning pitch.
verse.note: I.e., Edom's.

verse.text: It will not be quenched by night or by day; / Its [xref]a[/xref]smoke will go up forever; / It will be desolate from generation to generation; / No one will pass through it forever and ever.
But the pelican and the porcupine will inherit it, / And the owl and the raven will dwell in it; / And He will stretch over it / The line of nothingness and the plummet weights of emptiness.
As for its nobles, there is no one there whom they may call to [i]assume[/i] the kingdom, / And all its princes will be nothing.
And thorns will come up in its citadels, / Nettles and thistles in its fortified cities; / And it will be a [xref]a[/xref]habitation for jackals, / And an abode for ostriches.
[xref]a[/xref]Desert animals will meet with hyenas; / And the [note]1[/note]demon will call to his kind, / Indeed there [note]2[/note]Lilith will settle / And find a resting place for herself.
verse.note: Or, hairy goat.
The name of a female deity; lit., creature of the night.

verse.text: There the owl will make its nest and lay eggs, / And hatch [i]them[/i] and gather [i]them[/i] under its protection; / Indeed there the vultures will be gathered together, / Each with its kind.

[xref]a[/xref]Seek from the [xref]b[/xref]book of Jehovah and read. / Not one of these will be missing; / Not one will lack her mate; / For His mouth has commanded [i]it,[/i] / And it is His Spirit who has gathered them.
And He has cast the lot for them, / And His hand has divided it by line unto them; / They will inherit it forever; / From generation to generation they will dwell in it.
The [xref]a[/xref]wilderness and the desert will be glad; / And the [note]1[/note]desert will exult and blossom / Like the rose.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Arabah;[/i] i.e., the plain that runs from north of the Dead Sea south to the Gulf of Aqaba. So also in [link]v. 6[/link].

verse.text: It will blossom and blossom, / And even exult with exultation and a ringing shout. / The glory of Lebanon will be given to it, / The splendor of Carmel and Sharon; / They will see the glory of Jehovah, / The splendor of our God.
Strengthen the weak [xref]a[/xref]hands, / And confirm the shaking knees.
Say to those who are of anxious heart, / Be strong; fear not; / Indeed your God / Will come with vengeance, / With the recompense of God; / He will come and save you.
Then the eyes of the [xref]a[/xref]blind will be [note]1[/note]opened, / And the ears of the [xref]b[/xref]deaf will be unstopped;
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 10[/link].

verse.text: Then the [xref]a[/xref]lame will leap like a hart, / And the tongue of the [xref]b[/xref]dumb will give a ringing shout; / For water will [xref]c[/xref]break forth in the wilderness, / And streams in the desert.
And the desert mirage will become a pool, / And the thirsty ground, springs of water; / In the habitation of jackals, their resting place, / There will be grass with reeds and rushes.

And a highway will be there, and a way, / And it will be called, The Way of Holiness. / The unclean [xref]a[/xref]will not pass on it, / But it will be for him who walks on the way; / No fools will err [i]in it.[/i]
There will be no lion there, / Nor will any ravenous animal go up on it; / They will not be found there; / But the redeemed will walk [i]on it.[/i]

[xref]a[/xref]And the ransomed of Jehovah will return / And will come to Zion with a ringing shout, / And eternal joy will be upon their heads. / They will lay hold on gladness and joy, / And sorrow and [xref]b[/xref]sighing will flee away.
[xref]a[/xref]In the fourteenth year of King [note]1[/note]Hezekiah, Sennacherib the [xref]b[/xref]king of Assyria went up against all the fortified cities of Judah and took them.
verse.note: The first thirty-five chapters of this book concern God's loving chastisement on His beloved Israel and His righteous judgment on the nations, in order that His elect might turn to Him so that the created things might be restored and the all-inclusive Christ might be brought in. At this point, everyone and everything have been discharged by God, and Christ, the only One who is qualified, has come. In [link]chs. 36-39[/link] Isaiah provides an example in the person of Hezekiah, the king of Judah. In this example Isaiah shows how a person such as Hezekiah, who was appointed a king in God's kingdom, who was godly, and who prayed and received miraculous answers from God, eventually became not a success but a failure because of his self-glory and self-interest. Hence, he too was eventually discharged by God. See notes in [link]chs. 37-39[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the king of Assyria sent the Rab-shakeh from Lachish to Jerusalem to King Hezekiah with a great force. And he stood at the conduit of the upper pool, on the road to the Fuller's Field.
[xref]a[/xref]Then [xref]b[/xref]Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the scribe and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came out to him.
And the Rab-shakeh said to them, Say now to Hezekiah, [xref]a[/xref]Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria, What is this confidence in which you trust?
I say, [i]It is[/i] but a vain word [i]that you say,[/i] There is counsel and strength for war. Now in whom do you trust, that you rebel against me?

You now have put [i]your[/i] trust in the staff of this broken [xref]a[/xref]reed, in Egypt, which, if a man should lean on [i]it,[/i] will go into his hand and pierce it, for so is Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, to all who trust in him.

And if you say to me, We trust in Jehovah our God; is it not He whose high places and altars [xref]a[/xref]Hezekiah has taken away and has said to Judah and Jerusalem, You shall worship [i]only[/i] before [xref]b[/xref]this altar?
Now therefore give pledges to my master, the king of Assyria, and I will give you two thousand horses, if [i]indeed[/i] you are able to set riders on them.
How then can you refuse one official of the least of my master's servants and put your trust in [xref]a[/xref]Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
And have I now come up apart from Jehovah against this land to destroy it? Jehovah said to me, Go up against this land and destroy it.

And Eliakim and Shebna and Joah said to the Rab-shakeh, Please speak to your servants in [xref]a[/xref]Aramaic, because we understand [i]it;[/i] and do not speak to us in the [xref]b[/xref]Jews' language, in the ears of the people upon the wall.

But the Rab-shakeh said, Has my master sent me [i]only[/i] to your master and to you to speak these words, [i]and[/i] not to the men who sit on the wall, that they may eat their own dung and drink their own urine with you?
Then the Rab-shakeh stood and cried out with a loud voice in the Jews' language, and said, Listen to the words of the great king, the king of Assyria:
Thus says the king, Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, because he is not able to deliver you;
Neither let Hezekiah cause you to trust in Jehovah, saying, Jehovah will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.

Do not listen to Hezekiah; for thus says the king of Assyria, Make your peace with me, and come out to me, and let each eat from his own [xref]a[/xref]vine and each from his own fig tree, and let each drink the waters of his own cistern;
Until I come and take you away to a land like your land, a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
[xref]a[/xref][i]Be careful[/i] lest Hezekiah persuade you, saying, Jehovah will deliver us. Have any of the gods of the nations delivered their land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? And have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
Who among all the gods of these lands have delivered their land out of my hand, that Jehovah should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?
But they were silent and did not answer him a word, because of the commandment of the king that said, You shall not answer him.

Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the scribe and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rab-shakeh.
[xref]a[/xref]And when King Hezekiah heard, he [note]1[/note]tore his clothes, and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of Jehovah.
verse.note: Hezekiah's response here and his prayers in [link]vv. 15-20[/link] and [link]38:2-3[/link], [link]9-20[/link] show that he was a godly person.

verse.text: And he sent Eliakim, who was over the household, and Shebna the scribe and the elders of the priests, who had covered themselves in sackcloth, to [xref]a[/xref]Isaiah the son of Amoz, the prophet.
And they said to him, Thus says Hezekiah, This day is a day of affliction, rebuke, and contempt, for children have come to the point of birth, and there is no strength to bring [i]them[/i] forth.

It may be that Jehovah your God will hear the words of the Rab-shakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria sent to reproach the living God, and will reprove the words which Jehovah your God has heard. Therefore lift up a prayer for the [xref]a[/xref]remnant which is left.
So the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah.
And Isaiah said to them, Thus you shall say to your master, Thus says Jehovah, Do not be afraid of the words which you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.
Indeed I will put a spirit in him, so that he will hear a report and return to his land. And I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.
And the Rab-shakeh returned and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, because he had heard that [i]the king[/i] had departed from Lachish.
And he heard [i]a report[/i] about Tirhakah the king of Ethiopia which said, He has come forth to make war with you. And when he heard [i]it,[/i] he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
In this way you shall speak to Hezekiah the king of Judah, saying, Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you, saying, Jerusalem will not be delivered into the hand of the king of Assyria.
Indeed you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the lands, destroying them utterly. And will you be delivered?
Have the gods of the nations, whom my fathers destroyed, delivered them: Gozan and Haran and Rezeph and the children of Eden, who were in Telassar?
Where are the king of Hamath and the king of Arpad and the king of the city of Sepharvaim, of Hena and Ivvah?
And Hezekiah took the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it, and Hezekiah went up to the house of Jehovah and spread it before Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]And Hezekiah prayed to Jehovah, saying,

O Jehovah of hosts, God of Israel, You who are enthroned [i]between[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]cherubim, You alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth; You [xref]b[/xref]made the heavens and the earth.
Incline Your ear, O Jehovah, and hear; open Your eyes, O Jehovah, and see; and listen to all the words of Sennacherib, who has sent [i]messengers[/i] to reproach the living God.
Truly, O Jehovah, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the countries and their land,
And have cast their gods into the fire, because they were [xref]a[/xref]not gods, but the work of men's hands, wood and stone; so they destroyed them.
And now, O Jehovah our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone are Jehovah.
Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent [i]a message[/i] to Hezekiah, saying, Thus says Jehovah the God of Israel, Because you have prayed to Me concerning Sennacherib the king of Assyria,

This is the word which Jehovah has spoken concerning him:[br/]The virgin [xref]a[/xref]daughter of Zion / Has despised you [i]and[/i] laughed at you; / The daughter of Jerusalem / Has shaken [i]her[/i] head behind you.
Whom have you reproached and reviled? / Against whom have you lifted up [i]your[/i] voice / And lifted up your eyes haughtily? / Against the Holy One of Israel.

By your servants you have reproached the Lord, / And you have said, In the multitude of my chariots, / I have come up to the heights of the mountains, / To the sides of Lebanon. / And I will cut down its tall cedars, / [i]And[/i] the choicest of its cypresses: / I will enter into its farthest height / [i]And[/i] its luxuriant forest.
I have dug; / I have drunk water; / With the sole of my foot I have dried up / All the rivers of [note]1[/note]Egypt.
verse.note: Or, besieged places.

verse.text: Have you not heard / [i]That[/i] long ago I did it; / And from the days of old I had formed it? / Now I have brought it to pass, / That [i]you[/i] should destroy fortified cities, / [i]And make them into[/i] ruinous heaps.

Therefore their inhabitants were short of strength; / They were dismayed and felt ashamed; / And they were [i]like[/i] vegetation of the field / And green shoots of tender grass, / [i]Like[/i] grass [i]which grows[/i] on the housetops / And [note]1[/note]is scorched before it has grown up.
verse.note: Following the reading of the Dead Sea Scrolls and [link]2 Kings 19:26[/link]; other MSS read, a plowed field.

verse.text: But I know your sitting down, / And your going out and your coming in, / And your raging against Me.

Because your raging against Me / And your arrogance has come up into My ears, / I will put My hook in your nose / And My bridle in your lips, / And [xref]a[/xref]turn you back on the way by which you came.

This shall be the sign to you: This year you shall eat that which grows up of itself, and the second year that which shoots up from the same, and in the third year sow and reap and plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
And the [xref]a[/xref]remnant of those who have escaped of the house of Judah will again take [xref]b[/xref]root downward and bear fruit upward.
For a remnant will go forth out of Jerusalem, and from Mount Zion those who have escaped. The [xref]a[/xref]zeal of Jehovah of hosts will perform this.

Therefore, thus says Jehovah concerning the king of Assyria,[br/]He shall not come to this city, / Nor shoot an arrow there; / Neither shall he come against it with shields, / And build up a mound against it.
By the way on which he came, / By the same shall he return, / And into this city he shall not come, / Declares Jehovah.
And around this city I will put an [xref]a[/xref]enclosure / To save it, / For My [note]1[/note]own sake / And for the sake of [note]1[/note]David, My servant.
verse.note: That God would answer the prayer not for Hezekiah's sake but for His own sake and for the sake of David indicates that in God's consideration Hezekiah had very little credit before Him. All the credit was given either to God Himself or to Hezekiah's forefather David (cf. [link]38:5a[/link]).

verse.text: Then the [xref]a[/xref]angel of Jehovah went out and struck the Assyrians' camp, a hundred and eighty-five thousand; and when they arose early in the morning, all of them were corpses, dead.
Then Sennacherib the king of Assyria departed and went back to dwell in Nineveh.

And when he was worshipping in the house of his god Nisroch, Adrammelech and Sharezer his sons slew him with the sword; and they escaped to the land of Ararat. And Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.

[xref]a[/xref]In those days Hezekiah became mortally ill; and Isaiah the son of Amoz, the prophet, came to him and said to him, Thus says Jehovah, [xref]b[/xref]Put your house in order, for you are about to die and will not live.
And Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to Jehovah,
And said, Now, O Jehovah, please remember how I have walked before You in truth and with a perfect heart and have done that which is good in Your sight. And Hezekiah wept many tears.
Then the word of Jehovah came to Isaiah, saying,
Go and speak to Hezekiah, Thus says Jehovah, the God of David your father, I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; I will now add to your life [note]1[/note]fifteen years.
verse.note: For God to give Hezekiah another fifteen years meant that he would live until the age of only fifty-four ([link]2 Kings 18:2[/link]). The reason God extended Hezekiah's life by only fifteen years was that, in the sight of God, Hezekiah was not a person who could be trusted to carry out God's purpose. During his last fifteen years Hezekiah made a mistake that was so serious that it caused God's kingdom on earth to be lost ([link]ch. 39[/link]).

verse.text: And I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria, and I will put an [xref]a[/xref]enclosure around this city.
[xref]a[/xref]And this will be the [xref]b[/xref]sign from Jehovah to you, that Jehovah will do this thing which He has spoken.

Behold, I will cause the shadow on the steps, which has gone down with the sun on the steps of Ahaz, to go back ten steps. So the sun's [i]shadow[/i] went back ten steps on the steps on which it had gone down.
The writing of Hezekiah the king of Judah when he had been sick and had recovered from his sickness:
I said, In the middle of my days, / I will go into the [xref]a[/xref]gates of Sheol; / I have been deprived of the rest of my years.
I said, I will not see Jah, / Jah in the land of the living; / I will not look on man any longer, / [i]While I am[/i] with those who dwell where everything has ceased.

Like a shepherd's tent, / My [xref]a[/xref]dwelling has been pulled up and removed from me. / Like a weaver, I have rolled up my life. / He will cut me off [note]1[/note]from the loom; / From day until night You make an end of me.
verse.note: Or, with a languishing sickness.

verse.text: I have stilled myself until the morning; / Like a lion, so He breaks all my bones; / From day until night You make an end of me.
Like a swallow [i]and[/i] a crane, so I twitter; / Like a dove, I mourn; / My eyes look languishingly above; / O Lord, I am oppressed; be my surety.
What shall I say? He has both spoken to me, / And He Himself has done it; / I will walk [note]1[/note]deliberately all my years, / Because of the bitterness of my soul.
verse.note: Hezekiah's use of this word indicates that he realized that he had been too hasty in the past and that his walk had not been proper in the sight of God. Thus, in his prayer he said that he would walk deliberately all his years. But when the visitors from Babylon came ([link]39:1-2[/link]), instead of walking in a deliberate way, he walked in a hasty way. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 39[/link].

verse.text: O Lord, upon these things [i]men[/i] live; / And in all of these things is the life of my spirit; / Therefore may You restore my strength / And make me live.
Indeed for peace I had bitterness, yes, bitterness; / But You have lovingly delivered my soul from the pit of destruction, / Because You have [xref]a[/xref]cast behind Your back / All my sins.
For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sheol cannot thank You, / And Death cannot praise You; / They that go down to the pit / Cannot hope in Your truth.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link]. In [link]vv. 18-19[/link] Hezekiah asked Jehovah in a selfish way to put him among the living so that he could praise Him. This indicates that he was for God, but in a selfish way. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 39[/link].

verse.text: The living, the living, he will praise You, / As I do today; / A father shall make known / Your truth to [i]his[/i] [xref]a[/xref]children.
Jehovah [i]is ready[/i] to save me; / Therefore we will sing my songs, / With stringed instruments, / All the days of our life, / In the house of Jehovah.
[xref]a[/xref]Then Isaiah said, Let them take a cake of figs and rub it upon the boil, and he will live.
Hezekiah had also said, What is the sign that I shall go up to the house of Jehovah?
[xref]a[/xref]At that time Merodach-baladan the son of Baladan, the king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah because he had heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

And Hezekiah was glad for them and showed them [note]1[/note]his treasury, the silver and the gold, and the spices and the fine oil, and his whole armory and everything which was found among his treasures; there was nothing in his house or in all his dominion that Hezekiah did not show them.
verse.note: Hezekiah's showing the visitors from Babylon his treasury, his whole armory, and everything in his dominion was a foolish act and a great mistake. The showing of these riches became a temptation to Babylon. A little over one hundred years later, the king of Babylon came and took away those riches ([link]2 Kings 24-25[/link]). Hezekiah did not consider his action carefully, nor did he pray about it. He did not take thought concerning what the king of Babylon might do. This shows that Hezekiah was hasty and not very considerate or careful. Furthermore, his making a show offended God, who hates man's pride ([link]1 Pet. 5:5[/link]).

verse.text: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah and said to him, What did these men say? And from where have they come to you? And Hezekiah said, They have come to me from a distant land, from Babylon.
And he said, What have they seen in your house? And Hezekiah said, They have seen everything that is in my house; there is nothing among my treasures that I have not shown them.
Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, Hear the word of Jehovah of hosts:

The days are now coming when everything that is in your house and that your fathers have laid up as a treasure unto this day will be carried away to [xref]a[/xref]Babylon; nothing will be left, says Jehovah.
And they will take away some of your sons who will issue from you, whom you will beget, and they will become [xref]a[/xref]eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.
And Hezekiah said to Isaiah, The word of Jehovah which you have spoken is [xref]a[/xref]good. He said moreover, Indeed there will be peace and truth in [note]1[/note]my days.
verse.note: Hezekiah's response to Isaiah's word indicates that he was selfish, caring only for himself. The kingdom of Judah, over which Hezekiah became king, was actually God's kingdom on earth, and Hezekiah should not have regarded it as his own kingdom (cf. note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Sam. 31[/link]). For Hezekiah to lose his kingdom was a small thing, but for God to lose His kingdom was a great thing. Hezekiah's response in this verse indicates that he had no thought for God and God's kingdom, nor did he care even for his own children. He was altogether for himself.[br][br]The factors of Hezekiah's failure include (1) making a show of what he had, according to his flesh, (2) not being watchful, (3) not seeking the Lord, (4) not praying, (5) not considering the result of his actions, and (6) caring only for himself and not for God's kingdom on the earth.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Comfort, oh, comfort My people, / Says your God.
verse.note: Isaiah is a book of two main sections. The first section ([link]chs. 1-39[/link]) concerns God's governmental dealing with His beloved Israel and His punishing judgment on the nations so that Israel may be brought back to God and the all-inclusive Christ may be ushered in with the expected restoration of all things ([link]11:6-9[/link]; [link]35:5-6[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]10:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:19-23[/link]). The last section of Isaiah ([link]chs. 40-66[/link]) is the kind word of Jehovah spoken to the heart of Israel, His beloved people. This word unveils the prophet's vision concerning the redeeming and saving Christ as the Servant of Jehovah and reveals the all-inclusive salvation brought in by Christ to Israel and the nations, with the full restoration of all things, consummating in the new heaven and new earth.[br][br]The first thirty-nine chapters of Isaiah, corresponding to the thirty-nine books of the Old Testament, focus mainly on the old creation, whereas the last twenty-seven chapters, corresponding to the twenty-seven books of the New Testament, center on the new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:15[/link]). Both this chapter and the New Testament begin with the coming of John the Baptist, who ushered in the expected Christ for the initiation of the new creation ([link]v. 3[/link]; [link]Mark 1:1-11[/link]). The coming of the new creation does not immediately end the old creation; rather, the old creation remains for a time, until it is terminated at the end of the millennium (cf. [link]2 Pet. 3:7[/link], [link]10-12[/link]). The end of the thousand-year kingdom will be the termination of the old creation as well as the completion, the consummation, of the new creation, which is signified by the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth ([link]2 Pet. 3:13[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:1-2[/link]).

verse.text: Speak unto the heart of Jerusalem, / And cry out to her, / That her warfare has finished, / That [i]the penalty[/i] for her iniquity has been accepted; / For she has received from the hand of Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]double / For all her sins.

[xref]a[/xref]The voice of one who cries / In the wilderness: [xref]b[/xref]Make clear / The way of [note]1[/note]Jehovah; / Make straight in the [note]2[/note]desert / A [xref]c[/xref]highway for our [note]1[/note]God.
verse.note: In this chapter the all-inclusive Christ is revealed as Jehovah the Savior. To make clear the way of Jehovah is to make clear the way of Jesus, who is the New Testament Jehovah (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]). Moreover, the way of Jesus is a highway for our God, indicating that Jesus is our God. See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 35[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Every valley will be lifted up, / And every mountain and hill will be made low, / And the crooked places will become straight, / And the [xref]b[/xref]rough places, a broad plain.
Then the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory of Jehovah will be revealed, / And all flesh will see [i]it[/i] together, / Because the mouth of Jehovah has [note]2[/note]spoken.
verse.note: In this chapter the speaking of the word of comfort to the heart of Jerusalem ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]) is actually the announcing of the gospel (cf. [link]61:1-2[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18-19[/link]). The first thing announced is the coming of John the Baptist ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]). This is followed immediately by the appearing of Christ, the One recommended by John, as the glory of Jehovah ([link]v. 5[/link]). The glory of Jehovah is the center of the gospel for the new creation ([link]2 Cor. 4:4-6[/link]). Christ is the effulgence of God's glory ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]), and this effulgence is like the shining of the sun ([link]Luke 1:78-79[/link]). Thus, when Christ appeared, the glory of Jehovah was revealed to be seen by the God-seekers and Christ-believers ([link]Matt. 17:1-2[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]Luke 2:25-32[/link]; [link]9:32[/link]; [link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:16-18[/link]). To those on whom Christ has shined, Christ is the glory of God and the hope of glory within them ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]).[br][br]In this chapter the coming Christ as the glad tidings is to be announced as Jehovah our God ([link]v. 3[/link]); as Jehovah of glory ([link]v. 5[/link]); as the Lord Jehovah coming with might to rule with His arm, having His reward with Him and His recompense before Him ([link]vv. 9-10[/link]); and as a Shepherd feeding His flock, gathering the lambs in His arms, carrying them in His bosom, and leading those who are nourishing the young ([link]v. 11[/link]).

Jehovah is revealed through His speaking. Jesus was sent by God for the purpose of speaking the word of God for God's expression ([link]John 3:34a[/link]; [link]7:16[/link]; [link]14:24[/link]). In the word, the speaking, of Jesus, God is unveiled and presented to men that they may see God ([link]John 14:7-10[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:1-2[/link]).

verse.text: A voice said, Cry out. / And he said, What shall I cry? / [xref]a[/xref]All [note]1[/note]flesh is [xref]b[/xref]grass / And all its glory is like the flower of the field;
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 1[/link].

verse.text: The grass withers, the flower fades, / Because the breath of Jehovah blows upon it. / Surely the people are grass.
[xref]a[/xref]The grass withers and the flower fades, / But the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]word of our God will stand forever.
verse.note: The word of God is actually Christ, the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), as the gospel of God ([link]Rom. 10:6-8[/link]). This word is abiding, and as the word of life ([link]1 John 1:1[/link]), it is also living. All men of flesh, all withering and fading human beings, should receive Christ, the glory of God ([link]v. 5[/link]), who comes to people as the living and abiding word of God. Those who receive Christ as this word of God are regenerated ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]12-13[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:23[/link]) that they may become a part of the new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]) and may have eternal life to live forever ([link]John 3:15-16[/link]). The Lord's word will stand forever ([link]1 Pet. 1:25[/link]) to enliven men that they may partake of His eternal life for their enjoyment.

verse.text: Go up to a high mountain, / O Zion, who brings [xref]a[/xref]glad tidings; / Lift up your voice with power, / O Jerusalem, who brings glad tidings; / Lift it up, Do not be afraid. / Say to the cities of Judah, / [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Behold your God!
verse.note: This is the revealing of the Lord Jehovah, the appearing of the very God as the Lord Jesus Christ, the Savior, in His becoming a man through incarnation ([link]Matt. 1:18-23[/link]; [link]Luke 1:35[/link]; [link]John 1:1[/link], [link]14[/link]). Such a brief word — Behold your God! — is the glad tidings.

verse.text: Behold, the Lord Jehovah will come as a mighty One, / And His [xref]a[/xref]arm will [note]1[/note]rule for Him. / Behold, His [xref]b[/xref]reward is with Him, / And His [note]1[/note]recompense before Him.
verse.note: The Lord Jehovah as Jesus Christ is the Ruler who comes as a mighty One to rule over us ([link]Matt. 2:6[/link]). He is also the Judge who will either reward us or punish us ([link]Matt. 25:14-30[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]). This is His recompense, which is His judgment.

verse.text: He will feed His [xref]a[/xref]flock as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Shepherd; / In His arm He will gather the lambs; / In His bosom He will carry [i]them.[/i] / He will lead those who are nursing [i]the young.[/i]
verse.note: As the mighty One, the ruling and judging One ([link]v. 10[/link]), Christ comes to be a Shepherd ([link]Matt. 2:6[/link]; [link]9:36[/link]; [link]John 10:2-4[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]14[/link]). He cares for His flock by ruling and correcting His sheep and by feeding His flock, gathering the lambs in His arm, carrying them in His bosom, and leading those who are nursing the young.

verse.text: Who has measured the [xref]a[/xref]waters in the hollow of his hand, / Who has calculated [i]the extent of[/i] the heavens with a handspan, / And measured out the dust of the earth by a measure, / And weighed the mountains in scales / And the hills in balances?
Who has [xref]a[/xref]directed the Spirit of Jehovah, / Or who has made [i]matters[/i] known to Him as His [xref]b[/xref]counselor?
With whom did He consult and who instructed Him, / And taught Him in the path of justice, / And taught Him knowledge, / And caused Him to know the way of understanding?
Indeed the nations are like a [note]1[/note]drop from a bucket, / And are accounted as specks of dust on the scales. / Indeed He takes up the islands as very fine powder.
verse.note: The proper preaching of Jesus as the glad tidings, the gospel, causes people to realize that they are nothing and that Christ is everything ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]17[/link]; cf. [link]Phil. 3:7-8[/link]).

verse.text: And Lebanon is not sufficient to burn, / Nor are its beasts sufficient for a burnt offering.
All the nations are as [xref]a[/xref]nothing before Him; / They are counted by Him as less than nothing and [xref]b[/xref]vanity.
To whom then will you [xref]a[/xref]liken God? / Or what likeness will you compare to Him?
When the workman has cast an idol, / A goldsmith overlays it with gold / Also refining chains of silver [i]for it.[/i]
He that is [i]so[/i] impoverished [i]that he lacks[/i] an offering / Chooses wood that will not rot, / And seeks a skillful craftsman for himself / To prepare an idol that will not be moved.
[xref]a[/xref]Do you not know? Have you not heard? / Has it not been told to you from the beginning? / Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

It is He who sits above the circle of the earth, / And its inhabitants are like grasshoppers; / Who [xref]a[/xref]stretches out the heavens like a curtain, / And spreads them out like a tent to dwell in;
Who brings the princes to nought; / He makes the judges of the earth as nothing.

They have scarcely been planted; / They have scarcely been sown; / Their stem has scarcely taken root in the earth; / Nevertheless He blows on them and they are withered, / And the storm wind carries them away like stubble.
To whom will you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]liken Me, / That I should be compared? Says the Holy One.
verse.note: Our Savior, Jesus, is the Holy One, the eternal God, Jehovah, and the Creator of the heavens and the earth, who sits above the circle of the earth ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]25-26[/link], [link]28a[/link]). As the Holy One, Jesus is unlimited, unsearchable, incomparable, and high ([link]vv. 12-14[/link], [link]17-18[/link], [link]28b[/link], [link]22a[/link]). There is no comparison between Him and anyone or anything else.

verse.text: Lift up your eyes on high, / And see who has created these [note]1[/note]things, / Who brings out their host by [xref]a[/xref]number; / He calls all of them by name. / Through the greatness of His might and the strength of His power / Not one of them is missing.
verse.note: I.e., the stars and the planets.

verse.text: Why do you say, O Jacob, / And why do you speak, O Israel, / My way is hidden from Jehovah, / And my judgment has been passed over by my God?

Do you not know, / Or have you not heard, / That the eternal God, Jehovah, / The [xref]a[/xref]Creator of the ends of the earth, / Does not faint and does not become weary? / There is [xref]b[/xref]no searching out of His understanding.
He gives [xref]a[/xref]power to the faint, / And to those who have no vigor He multiplies strength.
Although youths will faint and become weary, / And young men will collapse exhausted;

Yet those who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wait on Jehovah will renew [i]their[/i] strength; / They will mount up with [note]2[/note]wings like [xref]b[/xref]eagles; / They will run and will not faint; / They will walk and will not become weary.
verse.note: To wait on the eternal God ([link]v. 28[/link]) means that we terminate ourselves, i.e., that we stop ourselves with our living, our doing, and our activity, and receive God in Christ as our life, our person, and our replacement. Such a waiting one will be renewed and strengthened to such an extent that he will mount up with wings like eagles. He will not only walk and run but also soar in the heavens, far above every earthly frustration. This is a transformed person. This chapter leads us to a comparison between Hezekiah, a godly man who was still in the old creation ([link]chs. 36-39[/link]), and a regenerated and transformed person in the new creation.[br][br]In [link]Isa. 40[/link] there are the announcing of the gospel (corresponding to the four Gospels — [link]vv. 1-5[/link]), salvation through regeneration (corresponding to the Acts — [link]vv. 6-8[/link]), and transformation (corresponding to the Epistles — [link]vv. 28-31[/link]).

The eagles' wings signify the resurrection power of Christ, God's power in life, becoming our grace (cf. [link]1 Cor. 15:10[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]; [link]12:9a[/link]). Those who stop themselves and wait on Jehovah will experience the power of resurrection, will be transformed, and will soar in the heavens (cf. [link]Phil. 4:13[/link]; [link]Col. 1:11[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Listen to Me in silence, O coastlands. / Let the people renew [i]their[/i] strength; / Let them approach, then let them speak; / Let us come together for judgment.
verse.note: In [link]chs. 41-66[/link] three parties are used by Isaiah to typify Christ as the Servant of Jehovah ([link]Matt. 12:15-21[/link]): Cyrus king of Persia, Israel, and Isaiah the prophet. These three servants and the all-inclusive Christ are one, serving Jehovah God for His good pleasure in releasing and raising up God's elect to build God's temple and God's city and to set up God's kingdom, which will be enlarged to consummate in the New Jerusalem.[br][br]In the first forty chapters of this book Isaiah unveiled in a hidden way God's economy, which is to have a people so that Christ as the embodiment of God can be expressed as everything, that He may be the centrality and the universality of everything in God's economy (see note [link]25[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 22[/link]). God in Christ and Christ with God have reached this point, i.e., to have Christ expressed as God's centrality and universality, to such an extent that these three parties — Cyrus the Gentile king, the pitiful Israel, and Isaiah — became one with Christ that God might have a corporate expression. Everyone who is one with Christ, including the New Testament believers, is a type of Christ, who is the Servant of God, and such persons also are servants of God because they are part of Christ. All other persons have been terminated, put aside by God. Those who are one with Christ have become a great corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]), the same as the individual Christ in being the testimony and servant of God.

verse.text: Who has stirred up [i]someone[/i] from the [xref]a[/xref]east, / Called [note]1[/note]him in righteousness to His feet? / He gave up the nations before [xref]b[/xref]him, / And caused [i]him[/i] to have dominion over kings. / He made [i]them[/i] like dust with his sword, / Like driven stubble with his bow.
verse.note: Referring to Cyrus king of Persia. In [link]chs. 41-48[/link] Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is typified by Cyrus in the following aspects: He was raised up by Jehovah ([link]vv. 2a[/link], [link]25a[/link]; [link]45:13a[/link]; [link]Acts 3:26a[/link]), anointed by Jehovah ([link]45:1a[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18a[/link]), and loved by Jehovah ([link]48:14b[/link]; [link]Matt. 3:17[/link]). He did God's pleasure in destroying Babylon ([link]48:14b[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:1-19:4[/link]). He was God's counselor ([link]46:11b[/link]) to subdue the nations and have dominion over the kings ([link]vv. 2b[/link], [link]25c[/link]; [link]45:1b[/link]; [link]Ezra 1:2a[/link]; [link]Acts 5:31a[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]). He was also Jehovah's shepherd for the fulfilling of His desire in building up the city (symbolizing the kingdom) and the temple of God and in releasing God's captives ([link]44:28[/link]; [link]45:13b[/link]; [link]Ezra 1:2-3[/link]; [link]John 10:11[/link]; [link]5:30b[/link]; [link]2:19[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18b[/link]).

verse.text: He pursues them [i]and[/i] passes on in safety, / He will not come on a way [i]known[/i] to his feet.
Who has wrought [i]this[/i] and done [i]this,[/i] / Calling the generations from the beginning? / I, Jehovah, am the [xref]a[/xref]first, / And with the last, I am [note]1[/note]He.
verse.note: The pronoun has the force of a proper name here: Jehovah is "He."

verse.text: The coastlands saw it and were afraid; / The ends of the earth trembled; / They drew near and came.
Each one helps his neighbor, / And [i]each one[/i] says to his brother, Be strong.

So the [xref]a[/xref]craftsman encourages the goldsmith, / [i]And[/i] he who smoothes [i]metal[/i] with a hammer [i]encourages[/i] him who strikes the / anvil, / Saying that the soldering is good; / And he fastens it with nails so that it should not be moved.
But you, [note]1[/note]Israel, My [xref]a[/xref]servant, / Jacob, whom I have [xref]b[/xref]chosen, / The seed of Abraham My [xref]c[/xref]friend;
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 8-20[/link], Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is typified by Israel for the carrying out of the kind word of comfort spoken by Jehovah to Israel ([link]40:1-2[/link]). As a type of Christ, the Servant of Jehovah, Israel was chosen by Jehovah and upheld with the right hand of His righteousness ([link]vv. 8-10[/link]; [link]42:1a[/link], [link]6[/link]). Like Christ, Israel overcame the enemies by Jehovah and rejoiced and gloried in Him, the Holy One of Israel ([link]vv. 11-16[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:21[/link]; [link]Matt. 11:25-26[/link]). Israel also typifies Christ as the Witness of Jehovah ([link]43:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]). Just as the Spirit was poured out on Christ, the Spirit of Jehovah was poured out on Israel for the blessing of his offspring ([link]44:1-5[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]42:1b[/link]; [link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18-19[/link]). Also, in Israel Jehovah was glorified, just as God was glorified in Christ ([link]43:7[/link]; [link]49:3[/link]; [link]46:13b[/link]; [link]John 17:1[/link]; [link]12:28[/link]).

verse.text: You whom I have taken from the [xref]a[/xref]ends of the earth, / And from its extremities have called, / And said to you, You are My servant; / I have chosen you and have not cast you away.

Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid, for I am [xref]b[/xref]with you; / Do not be dismayed, for I am your God. / I will strengthen you; surely I will help you; / Surely I will uphold you with the right hand of My righteousness.
Indeed all those who were incensed against you / Will be ashamed and confounded; / The men who strive against you / Will be as nothing and will perish.
You will seek but not find / The men who contend with you; / The men who war with you / Will be as nothing and as without existence.
For I am Jehovah your God, / Who takes hold of your right hand, / Who says to you, Do [xref]a[/xref]not be afraid; / I will help you.
Do not be afraid, you worm Jacob, / You [xref]a[/xref]few men of Israel; / I will help you, declares Jehovah, / Even your [xref]b[/xref]Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.
Now I will make you into a sharp threshing instrument, / [i]One that is[/i] new and possessing teeth. / You shall thresh the mountains and make them powder, / And you shall make the hills like chaff.
You shall winnow them, and the wind will carry them away / And the storm wind will scatter them. / And you will rejoice in Jehovah, / You will glory in the Holy One of Israel.
When the poor and needy seek for water, and there is none, / And their tongue is dry from thirst, / I, Jehovah, will answer them; / [i]As[/i] the God of Israel I will [xref]a[/xref]not forsake them.

I will open up [xref]a[/xref]rivers on the bare heights, / And in the midst of the valleys, springs. / [xref]b[/xref]I will make the wilderness into a pool of water, / And the dry land into springs of water.
I will plant in the wilderness the cedar, / The acacia, the myrtle, and the olive tree; / I will place in the desert the fir tree, / The pine tree, and the box tree together;
That they may see and know, / And consider and understand together, / That the hand of Jehovah has done this, / And the Holy One of Israel has created it.
Present your [note]1[/note]case, says Jehovah; / Bring forward your arguments, says the King of Jacob.
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 21-29[/link], Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is for the exposing of the falsehood and vanity of the idols, the head of which is Satan. Everything except Christ is false, vain, and an idol (see note [link]21[sup]3[/sup], par. 1, in 1 John 5[/link]).

verse.text: Let them bring forth and declare to us / What will take place; / Let them show what the former things were, / That we may consider [i]them,[/i] / And may know the end of them; / Or let us hear the things that are coming.
Declare [i]to us[/i] the things that are coming afterward, / That we may know that you are gods; / Indeed do good or do evil, / That we may look at one another anxiously and be afraid together.
You are indeed nothing, / And your work is of no consequence; / He who chooses you is an abomination.

I have raised up [xref]a[/xref]one from the north and he has come; / From the [xref]b[/xref]rising of the sun he will call upon My name. / He will come upon rulers as [i]upon[/i] mortar, / As the potter treads the clay.

Who has declared [i]it[/i] from the beginning that we may know, / And in advance that we may say, [i]He is[/i] right? / Indeed there was no one who declared [i]it;[/i] indeed no one who let [i]us[/i] hear; / Indeed no one who heard your words.
Formerly [i]I said[/i] to Zion, Here, here they are; / And to Jerusalem, I will give someone who preaches [xref]a[/xref]glad tidings.
But I looked and there was no man, / And from among these there was no counselor, / Who, when I asked, would give Me an answer.
Indeed all of them are vanity; / Their works are of no consequence; / Their molten images are a wind and a waste.

[xref]a[/xref]Here is My [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Servant, whom I uphold, / My [xref]c[/xref]chosen One [xref]d[/xref][i]in whom[/i] My soul delights; / I have put My [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]Spirit upon Him, / And He will bring forth [note]3[/note]justice to the nations.
verse.note: [link]Isaiah 42[/link] reveals Christ ([link]Matt. 12:15-21[/link]), the Servant of Jehovah ([link]Mark 10:45[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:5-11[/link]), as a covenant for God's chosen people, Israel, and a light for the Gentile nations (see notes [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link]). The source of Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is His divinity, His deity ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]49:5[/link], [link]7-8[/link]), whereas His qualification is in His humanity, in His human virtues ([link]vv. 2-4[/link]). Christ's commission is to raise up the tribes of Jacob; to bring Jacob back to Jehovah so that Israel would be gathered to Him ([link]49:5b[/link], [link]6a[/link]); to be a covenant of the people, i.e., of Israel ([link]v. 6d[/link]; [link]49:8d[/link]); to restore the land ([link]49:8e[/link]); to be a light to the nations ([link]v. 6e[/link]; [link]49:6c[/link]); to bring forth justice for salvation in truth to the nations ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3b[/link]; [link]49:6d[/link]); to open the eyes of the blind that they may see the divine and spiritual things concerning God's eternal economy ([link]v. 7a[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18b[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18a[/link]); and to bring the prisoner out from the prison, those who dwell in darkness out from the prison house, that they may be released from the dark kingdom of Satan into the kingdom of God's beloved Son ([link]v. 7[/link]; [link]Col. 1:12-13[/link]).

Jehovah's Spirit is Jehovah Himself. Hence, Jehovah's putting His Spirit upon Jesus ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18a[/link]; [link]John 1:33[/link]) meant that He gave Himself to Jesus and that Jehovah and Jesus, His Servant, are one.
See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup][/link]. So also for [link]v. 3[/link].

verse.text: He will not [note]1[/note]cry out, nor lift up [i]His voice,[/i] / Nor make His voice heard in the street.
verse.note: In His ministry the Lord did not strive with others ([link]Matt. 12:19[/link]), and He did not promote Himself. He did not seek to make Himself known to people on the streets (cf. [link]John 7:3-9[/link]).

verse.text: A [note]1[/note]bruised reed He will not break; / And a [note]1[/note]dimly burning flax He will not extinguish; / He will bring forth justice in truth.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 12[/link].

verse.text: He will not [note]1[/note]faint, nor will He [note]2[/note]be discouraged, / Until He has established [note]3[/note]justice in the earth; / And the coastlands will wait for His instruction.
verse.note: Or, burn dimly; from the same root as [i]dimly burning[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link]. Christ does not extinguish the dimly burning flax ([link]v. 3[/link]), but He Himself never burns dimly.
Or, be crushed; from the same root as and an allusion to [i]bruised[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link].

Justice ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3-4[/link]) is righteousness passing through judgment. It is the verdict of the judgment on righteousness. In this book it refers to salvation as the result of God's judgment on Christ, the righteous One, which was executed according to God's righteous law and completely fulfills all the requirements of that law (cf. [link]Gal. 2:19[/link] and note 1). To establish justice in the earth means to establish God's salvation as the issue of God's judgment on Christ. God's salvation is of two aspects — justification as the judicial aspect and the impartation of life as the organic aspect ([link]Rom. 5:10[/link], [link]18[/link]). God justifies and imparts life to the believers based on Christ's redemption accomplished through God's righteous judgment; this is justice. Christ will come again when He finishes the establishing of God's justice, God's salvation, in this earth.

verse.text: Thus says God Jehovah, / Who created the [xref]a[/xref]heavens and stretched them out, / Who spread forth the [xref]b[/xref]earth and what springs up from it, / Who gives [xref]c[/xref]breath to the people upon it / And [note]1[/note]spirit to those who walk on it:
verse.note: For His chosen people to receive Christ as a covenant and as light ([link]v. 6[/link]), God as the Creator of the heavens and the earth and as the One who gives breath to men, gives also spirit to them ([link]Gen. 2:7[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:1[/link]) that they may be able to enjoy Him, the Triune God, who is Spirit ([link]John 4:24a[/link]), as their inheritance and life.

verse.text: I am Jehovah; I have [xref]a[/xref]called You in righteousness; / I have held You by the hand; / I have kept You and I have given You / As a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant for the people, as a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]light for the nations;
verse.note: Christ has been called by Jehovah to be a covenant for the people, i.e., for Israel ([link]v. 6b[/link]; [link]49:8b[/link]; [link]Heb. 7:22[/link]). The covenant is the legal agreement between God and His people (cf. [link]Jer. 31:31-34[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:8-12[/link]). Through the death of Christ, the covenant became a testament, a will ([link]Heb. 9:16-17[/link] and note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Christ enacted the new covenant (which became the new testament — the will) with His blood according to God's righteousness through His redeeming death ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]Luke 22:20[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:15[/link]). In resurrection Christ became the reality of all the bequests of the new testament and the Mediator, the Executor, to execute the new testament according to God's righteousness ([link]Heb. 8:6[/link]; [link]9:15[/link]; [link]12:24[/link]). Therefore, Christ is the new covenant as the new testament.[br][br]Christ, as the embodiment of the riches of the Godhead ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]; [link]1:19[/link]) and as the crucified and resurrected One, has become the covenant of God given to His people. He is the reality of all that God is and of all that God has given us. God's salvation, God's righteousness, God's justification, God's forgiveness, God's redemption, God's riches, and all God has and will do have been covenanted to us. As the reality of all the bequests in the new testament, Christ, who is the all-inclusive, life-giving, indwelling, consummated Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:9-11[/link]), is in our spirit and has become one spirit with us ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). As a covenant Christ is the surety ([link]Heb. 7:22[/link]), and the Spirit is the pledge ([link]2 Cor. 1:22[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:14[/link]), to guarantee that God embodied in Christ is the inheritance to His people ([link]Rom. 8:17a[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18[/link] and note 6).

Christ has also been called by Jehovah to be a light for the nations ([link]v. 6b[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:13-16[/link]). He is the light of life, the true light, that shines over the world and enlightens every man to enliven man for regeneration ([link]John 1:4[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]12-13[/link]). He is the divine, marvelous light to open the eyes of the blind ([link]v. 7a[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18[/link]; [link]John 9:14[/link]) and to deliver God's chosen people out of the darkness of death, the death-realm, the authority of Satan, into God's life-realm of light ([link]v. 7b[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:9b[/link]; [link]Acts 26:18a[/link]; [link]Col. 1:12-13[/link]). Christ as the covenant is for God's people to gain God with His riches as their inheritance (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link]), whereas Christ as the light is for God's people to receive God as life. See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 49[/link].

verse.text: To open the eyes of the [xref]a[/xref]blind, / To bring the prisoner out from the [xref]b[/xref]prison, / Those who dwell in darkness from the prison house.
I am Jehovah, that is My name, / And I will not [xref]a[/xref]give My glory to another, / Nor My praise to idols.
Indeed, the former things have come to pass, / And [xref]a[/xref]new things I am telling [i]you;[/i] / Before they spring forth / I will let you hear [i]them.[/i]
Sing a [xref]a[/xref]new song to Jehovah; / [i]Sing[/i] His praise from the end of the earth; / You who go down to the sea and [i]all[/i] that fills it, / You coastlands and their inhabitants.

Let the wilderness and its cities, / The villages which Kedar inhabits, lift up [i]their voices;[/i] / Let the inhabitants of [note]1[/note]Sela sing for joy; / Let them shout from the tops of the mountains.
verse.note: Or, the high rock, or, the cliff; the name of a city in Edom.

verse.text: Let them give glory to Jehovah, / And declare His praise in the coastlands.
Jehovah will go forth as a mighty man, / Like a [xref]a[/xref]man of war He will stir up [i]His[/i] jealousy; / He will raise a war cry; He will even roar. / He will prevail over His enemies.
For a long time I have been silent; / I have kept still, I have restrained Myself. / [i]Now[/i] I will cry like a woman in travail; / I will [note]1[/note]gasp and pant at the same time.
verse.note: Some MSS read, destroy and devour.

verse.text: I will lay waste the mountains and hills, / And all of their vegetation I will dry up; / And I will make the rivers into islands; / I will dry up the pools.

I will bring the blind on a way they do not know; / I will guide them in paths they do not know; / I will make the [xref]a[/xref]darkness into light before them, / And [xref]b[/xref]crooked things straight. / These are the things / I will do for them and will not forsake them.
They who have turned back will be utterly put to shame, / [i]That is,[/i] those who trust in graven images, / Those who say to molten images, / You are our gods.
You who are [xref]a[/xref]deaf, Hear; / And you who are blind, Look, that you may see.
Who is blind except My [note]1[/note]servant, / And as deaf as My messenger, [i]whom[/i] I will send? / Who is as blind as the one at peace [i]with Me,[/i] / And as blind as the servant of Jehovah?
verse.note: Referring to Israel, typifying Christ as the Servant of Jehovah in the restoration (see [link]vv. 22-24[/link]). Israel was blind and deaf, having no understanding or power of perception. Therefore, Israel could not hear God's word nor see His vision. However, in the restoration Israel will become one with Christ and thus, being able to see and hear, will have the power to perceive and the ability to understand.

verse.text: You have seen many things and do not observe [i]them;[/i] / [i]His[/i] ears are open, but he does [xref]a[/xref]not hear.
Jehovah is well pleased for His righteousness' sake; / He will magnify the law and make [i]it[/i] honorable.

But this is a people plundered and spoiled: / All of them are trapped in holes, / And they are hidden in prison houses; / They have become plunder, and there is no one to deliver; / [i]They have become[/i] spoil, and there is no one to say, Restore [i]them.[/i]
Who among you will give ear to this? / [i]Who will[/i] pay attention and listen to the coming things?

Who gave Jacob to the plunderers, / And Israel to the robbers? / Was it not Jehovah, against whom we have sinned, / And in whose ways they were not willing to walk, / And whose law they would not obey?

Therefore He poured out upon them the heat of His anger / And the strength of battle; / And set them on fire round about, yet they did not realize [i]it;[/i] / And He burned against them and they did not take [i]it[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]heart.

But now thus says Jehovah / Who created you, O Jacob, and who [xref]a[/xref]formed you, O Israel: / Do [xref]b[/xref]not fear, because I have [xref]c[/xref]redeemed you; / I have [xref]d[/xref]called [i]you[/i] by your name; you are Mine.

When you [xref]a[/xref]pass through the waters, I will be [xref]b[/xref]with you, / And through the rivers, they will not flow over you. / And when you [xref]c[/xref]walk through the fire, you will not be burned, / And the flame will not consume you.
Because I am Jehovah your God, / The Holy One of Israel, your Savior, / I have given Egypt as your ransom, / [note]1[/note]Cush and Seba instead of you.
verse.note: Or, Ethiopia.

verse.text: Since you were precious in My eyes, / [i]Since[/i] you have been honorable and I have loved you, / I will give up men in your place, / And peoples in exchange for your life.
Do [xref]a[/xref]not fear, because I am with you; / I will bring your seed from the east, / And [xref]b[/xref]gather you from the west.
I will say to the north, Give [i]them[/i] up, / And to the south, Do not keep [i]them[/i] back. / Bring My [xref]a[/xref]sons from afar, / And My daughters from the end of the earth,
Everyone who is called by My [xref]a[/xref]name, / Whom I have created, [xref]b[/xref]formed, and even made [xref]c[/xref]for My [note]1[/note]glory.
verse.note: Israel is God's servant in the sense of fulfilling God's desire in His economy to have a corporate expression of Himself for His glory ([link]41:8[/link]; [link]45:4[/link]; [link]49:3[/link]). The people of Israel were to be used by God to express Him in a corporate way for His glorification. In this sense Israel was one with Christ as God's servant ([link]Hosea 11:1[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 2:15[/link]). The servant of Jehovah is corporate, and Israel was part of this corporate servant. See notes [link chapter="41"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].[br][br]In the present age the church is the testimony of God in the sense of being one with Christ as God's testimony ([link]Rev. 1:2[/link] and note). In being such a testimony, the church serves God. Thus, all God's elect can be considered servants of God with Christ for the expression of God's glory (cf. [link]John 17:22[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:21[/link]). The glorification of God is the purpose of our service. The highest service we can render to God is to express His glory.

verse.text: Bring out the people who are blind yet have eyes, / And those who are [xref]a[/xref]deaf yet have ears.

Let all the nations be gathered together, / And let the peoples assemble. / Who among them can declare this / And relate to us the former things? / Let them bring forth their witnesses, that they may be justified, / And let them hear and say, [i]It is[/i] true.

You are My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]witnesses, declares Jehovah, / And My [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]servant whom I have chosen, / In order that you may know and believe Me / And understand that I am He. / Before Me there was no [note]2[/note]God formed, / Neither will there be any after Me.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].
That Jehovah is the unique God can be proved only by a group of people who are His witnesses ([link]44:8[/link]; [link]Acts 1:8[/link]).

verse.text: I, [i]even[/i] I, am Jehovah; / And there is [xref]a[/xref]no Savior besides Me.
I have declared, and I have saved, and I have let [i]them[/i] hear; / There is [xref]a[/xref]no strange [i]god[/i] among you. / And you are My witnesses, declares Jehovah, / And I am God.
Indeed, [note]1[/note]before the day [i]was,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]I am He, / And there is no one who can deliver [note]2[/note]from My hand. / I will work and who will reverse it?
verse.note: Or, from eternity.
Or, apart from My hand.

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / Your [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel, / For your sake I have sent to Babylon, / And I will bring down all of them as fugitives, / Even the Chaldeans, whose rejoicing is in the ships.
I am Jehovah, your Holy One, / The [xref]a[/xref]Creator of Israel, your King.
Thus says Jehovah, / Who has made a way in the sea, / And a path in the mighty waters,
Who brings forth the chariot and the horse, / The army and the powerful together. / They will lie down, they will not rise; / They are extinct, they are quenched like flax.
Do not call to mind the former things, / Nor consider the things of old.
Indeed, I am doing a [xref]a[/xref]new thing; / It will now spring forth; / Do you not know it? / I will even make a way in the wilderness, / [xref]b[/xref]Rivers in the desert.

The animals of the field will honor Me, / The jackals and the ostriches, / Because I have given [i]them[/i] water in the wilderness, / Rivers in the desert, / To give a drink to My people, My chosen ones.
This people I have [xref]a[/xref]formed for Myself; / They will show forth My praise.
But you have [xref]a[/xref]not called upon Me, O Jacob, / But you have grown weary of Me, O Israel.
You have not brought Me a sheep for your burnt offerings, / And you have not honored Me with your sacrifices; / I have not made you serve Me with a meal offering, / Nor wearied you with incense.

You did not buy [xref]a[/xref]calamus for Me with money, / And you did not fill Me with the fat of your sacrifices. / Indeed, you have burdened Me with your sins; / You have wearied Me with your iniquities.
I, [i]even[/i] I, am He who [xref]a[/xref]wipes away your transgressions for My own sake, / And I will not remember your [xref]b[/xref]sins.
Put Me in remembrance; let us plead [i]in judgment[/i] together: / Declare [i]your case[/i] that you may be justified.
Your first father sinned, / And your mediators transgressed against Me.
Therefore I profaned the princes of the sanctuary, / And I delivered up Jacob to destruction, / And Israel to reviling.
But now hear, O Jacob, My [xref]a[/xref]servant, / And Israel, whom I have chosen.

Thus says Jehovah your [xref]a[/xref]Maker / And the One who [xref]b[/xref]formed you from the womb, who will help you, / Do not fear, O Jacob, My servant, / And [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Jeshurun whom I have chosen,
verse.note: From the Hebrew root meaning [i]upright.[/i]

verse.text: For I will pour [xref]a[/xref]water upon the thirsty land, / And streams upon the dry ground; / I will [xref]b[/xref]pour out My Spirit upon your seed, / And My blessing upon your offspring.
verse.xref: Isa. 32:15; Ezek. 39:29; Joel 2:28; Zech. 12:10; Mark 1:8; Acts 2:17

verse.text: They will spring up among the grass, / Like poplars beside the flowing streams of water.

One will say, I am Jehovah's; / Another will call [i]himself[/i] by the name of Jacob; / Another will write [i]with[/i] his hand, [i]I am[/i] Jehovah's; / He will name [i]himself[/i] with the name Israel.
Thus says Jehovah the King of Israel, / And his [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer, Jehovah of hosts, / I am the [xref]b[/xref]First and I am the Last, / And apart from Me there is no God.

And who can proclaim as I [i]can?[/i] / Then let him declare it and recount it in order for Me, / Since I set forth the people of ancient times. / Let them declare to them both the coming things / And the things which will take place.

Do not tremble and do not be afraid. / Have I not related to you from that time and declared [i]it?[/i] / And you are My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]witnesses. Is there a God besides Me? / Or is there any [i]other[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Rock? I do not know of [i]any.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 43[/link].

verse.text: All those who make idols are a waste. / And the things they delight in will not profit [i]them.[/i] / And those who are witnesses for them do not see, / And they do not know, that they may be put to shame.
Who has formed a [xref]a[/xref]god or cast an [xref]b[/xref]idol / That is of no profit?
Indeed, all those joined to him will be put to shame, / For the craftsmen are only men. / Let all of them be gathered together, let them stand up; / Let them be afraid and be put to shame together.

The ironsmith [note]1[/note]sharpens a cutting tool, / And works over the coals, / And forms [note]2[/note]the idol with hammers, / And he works it with the strength of his arm. / Yet he becomes hungry and has no strength; / If he does not drink water, he faints.
verse.note: Supplied from the Septuagint text.
Lit., it.

verse.text: The carpenter stretches out a line; / He marks it out with a marking tool; / He works it with planes, / And marks it with a compass. / He makes it according to the likeness of a man, / Like the beautiful appearance of man, to dwell in a house.
[i]Someone prepares[/i] to cut down cedars for himself, / Or he takes a cypress or an oak; / He lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest; / He plants an ash, and the rain nourishes it.

It is also [i]something[/i] for a man to burn; / He takes [i]one[/i] of them and warms himself; / He even kindles a fire and bakes bread. / [i]With the same[/i] he also makes a god and worships [i]it;[/i] / He makes it into a graven image and bows down before it.
Half of it he burns in a fire; / Over this half he eats flesh, / [i]And[/i] he roasts a roast and is satisfied. / He also warms himself and says, Ha! / I am warm, I have seen fire.
The rest of it he makes into a god, into his idol; / He bows down to it and worships [i]it[/i] / And prays to it and says, / Deliver me, for you are my god.
They do not know, and they do not understand, / For He has covered their eyes so that they cannot see, / And their minds so that they cannot understand.

And no one considers in his heart, / And there is no knowledge or understanding to say, / I have burned half of it in the fire, / And I have even baked bread over its coals; / I have roasted flesh and eaten [i]it.[/i] / Then shall I make the rest of it into an abomination? / Shall I fall down before a block of wood?
He feeds on ashes; / A deceived heart has led him astray; / And he cannot deliver his soul; / Nor does he say, Is this not a lie in my right hand?
Remember these things, O Jacob, / And Israel, for you are My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]servant. / I have [xref]b[/xref]formed you; you are My servant; / O Israel, you will not be forgotten by Me.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].

verse.text: I have [xref]a[/xref]wiped away, like a thick cloud, your transgressions, / And like a cloud, your sins. / Return unto Me, for I have redeemed you.

[xref]a[/xref]Sing for joy, O heavens, for Jehovah has accomplished [i]it.[/i] / Shout, O [xref]b[/xref]lower parts of the earth; / Break forth with singing, O mountains, / The forest and every tree in it; / For Jehovah has redeemed Jacob / And is [note]1[/note]glorified in Israel.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 43[/link].

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah who redeemed you / And [xref]a[/xref]formed you from the womb, / I am Jehovah who makes all things, / Who alone [xref]b[/xref]stretches out the heavens, / Who spread out the earth (Who was with Me?);
Who frustrates the signs of liars, / And makes fools of the diviners; / Who turns back the wise men, / And makes their knowledge [xref]a[/xref]foolish;

Who confirms the word of His servant, / And fulfills the counsel of His messengers; / Who says to Jerusalem, She will be inhabited, / And to the cities of Judah, They will be built, / And I will raise up their ruins;
Who says to the depths, Be dried up, / And I will dry up your rivers;

Who says to [xref]a[/xref]Cyrus, [i]He is[/i] My [note]1[/note]shepherd, / And he will fulfill all My desire, / Even by saying of Jerusalem, She will be built, / And of the temple, [i]Her foundations[/i] will be laid.
verse.note: In [link]chs. 43-45[/link] Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is typified by Cyrus king of Persia, who was Jehovah's Shepherd and who fulfilled all the desires of Jehovah. Cyrus served God by defeating Babylon, God's enemy ([link]48:14[/link]), which had captured His people and destroyed the temple ([link]2 Kings 24-25[/link]), by declaring the release of Israel from captivity, and by issuing a decree allowing the Jews to rebuild their temple in Jerusalem ([link]45:13[/link]; [link]Ezra 1:2-3[/link]). These three things are types, signifying Christ's defeating Satan ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]), releasing His believers from Satan's captivity ([link]Luke 4:18b[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:8[/link]), and building up the church as God's temple ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:21[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah to His anointed, / To [note]1[/note]Cyrus, whose right hand I have grasped, / To subdue the nations before him; / And I will loosen the loins of kings; / To open before him double doors / So that the gates will not be shut:
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].

verse.text: I will go before you / And make level the [xref]a[/xref]rough places; / I will shatter the doors of bronze / And cut through the bars of iron,
And give to you the treasures of darkness / And the hidden riches of secret places, / That you may know that I am Jehovah, who calls [i]you[/i] by your name, / The God of Israel.
For the sake of My [xref]a[/xref]servant, Jacob, / And Israel, My [xref]b[/xref]chosen one, / I have also called you by your name; / I have surnamed you, although you do not know Me.
I am Jehovah and there is no one else; / Besides Me there is no [xref]a[/xref]God; / I girded you, although you do not know Me;
That they might know from the rising of the sun and from the west / That there is no one [xref]a[/xref]besides Me. / I am Jehovah and there is no one else;
He who forms the [xref]a[/xref]light and creates darkness, / He who makes peace and creates evil, / I am Jehovah who makes all these things.

Drip down, O heavens, from above, / And let the clouds [note]1[/note]flow down [xref]a[/xref]righteousness; / Let the earth [note]1[/note]open / And [xref]b[/xref]bring forth salvation and righteousness; / Let them spring forth together; / I, Jehovah, have created it.
