verse.note: The clouds flowing down righteousness means that the Spirit will flow down to dispense Christ as righteousness into the people on earth, who are signified here by the earth. On the one hand, God causes the Spirit to flow down from heaven to impart Christ as righteousness into people; on the other hand, God causes people as the earth to open and bring forth salvation and righteousness, both of which are Christ Himself ([link]Luke 2:30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). God carries out His salvation by using His Spirit to bring down Christ as righteousness and by opening people to receive Christ as salvation and righteousness.

verse.text: Woe to him who strives with the One who formed him — / The potsherds among the earthen potsherds. / [xref]a[/xref]Shall the [xref]b[/xref]clay say to the One who forms it, What are You making? / And your work say, He has no hands?
Woe to him who says to [i]his[/i] father, What are you begetting? / Or to a woman, What are you bringing forth?

Thus says Jehovah, / The Holy One of Israel and the One who formed him, / Ask Me about the things to come concerning My [xref]a[/xref]sons, / And concerning the [xref]b[/xref]work of My hands, command Me.
I have [xref]a[/xref]made the earth, / And [xref]b[/xref]created man upon it; / My own hands [xref]c[/xref]stretched out the heavens, / And I commanded all of their host.

I [xref]a[/xref]raised [note]1[/note]him up in righteousness, / And will make straight all his ways; / He will [xref]b[/xref]build My city, / And send away My captives, / Neither for a price nor for a reward, / Says Jehovah of hosts.
verse.note: Referring to Cyrus in [link]v. 1[/link]. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link].

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / The wealth of Egypt, and the merchandise of [note]1[/note]Cush, / And the Sabeans, men of stature, / Will pass to you and will be yours. / They will walk behind you; they will come over in chains / And bow down to you [i]and[/i] petition you, [i]saying,[/i] / Surely God [xref]a[/xref]is with you, and there is no one else; / [i]There is[/i] [xref]b[/xref]no other God.
verse.note: I.e., Ethiopia.

verse.text: Surely You are a God who [xref]a[/xref]hides Himself, / O God of Israel, the Savior.
All of them will be ashamed and even confounded; / Those who make idols go in confusion together.
Israel has been saved by Jehovah / With an [xref]a[/xref]eternal salvation; / You will not be ashamed or confounded / Forever and ever.

For thus says Jehovah, / Who [xref]a[/xref]created the heavens — / He is the God / Who formed the earth and made it; / He established it; / He did not create it [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]waste, / [i]But[/i] He formed it to be inhabited: / I am Jehovah and there is no one else;
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Job 38[/link].

verse.text: I have not spoken in secret, / In a dark place of the earth; / I did not say to the seed of Jacob, / Seek Me in vain. / I, Jehovah, speak righteousness, / Declaring things that are right.
Gather yourselves together and come; / Draw near together, / You who have escaped from the nations. / Those who set up their wooden idol / And pray unto a god who cannot save / Have no knowledge.

Declare and present [i]your case;[/i] / Indeed, let them take counsel together. / Who related this long ago; / Who declared [i]it[/i] [xref]a[/xref]from that time? / Was it not I, Jehovah? / And there is [xref]b[/xref]no other God besides Me; / A righteous God and Savior, / And there is no one except Me.
Turn to Me and be saved, / All the [xref]a[/xref]ends of the earth, / For I am God and there is no one else.
I have [xref]a[/xref]sworn by Myself; / A word has gone out of My mouth in righteousness / And will not return, / That [xref]b[/xref]every knee shall bow to Me, / And every tongue shall swear.

It shall be said of Me, Only in Jehovah / Is there [note]1[/note]righteousness and [note]1[/note]strength. / To Him shall [i]men[/i] come, / And all those who are burning in anger against Him shall be ashamed.
verse.note: Here [i]righteousness[/i] refers to salvation, and [i]strength,[/i] to life.

verse.text: In Jehovah all the seed of Israel / Shall be [note]1[/note]justified and shall glory.
verse.note: Here to be justified is to be saved. In Jehovah all the seed of Israel will be saved ([link]Rom. 11:26-27[/link]) and will glory.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bel has bowed down; [note]2[/note]Nebo stoops; / Their idols are on beasts and cattle; / The things which you carry are a [note]3[/note]burden, / A load for a weary [i]beast.[/i]
verse.note: One of the gods of the Babylonians, supposed by some to be the Babylonian name of Baal.
A Babylonian idol.

When Israel was captured by the Babylonians, God's people still would not give up their idols and had to carry them from the good land to Babylon. Anything that replaces God or occupies the position of God is an idol that becomes a burden to the worshipper.

verse.text: They stoop and have bowed down together; / They are not able to escape the burden; / But they themselves have gone into [xref]a[/xref]captivity.
Listen to Me, O house of Jacob, / And all the [xref]a[/xref]remnant of the house of Israel, / [i]You[/i] who have been [xref]b[/xref]borne from birth, / Who have been carried from the womb,
Even unto old age, [xref]a[/xref]I am He; / Even unto [i]your[/i] gray-haired [i]years,[/i] I will bear [i]you.[/i] / I have made and I will carry, / And I will bear and deliver.
[xref]a[/xref]To whom will you liken Me, / And [i]with whom[/i] will you make [i]Me[/i] equal / And compare Me, that we should be [i]considered[/i] alike?
Those who lavish [xref]a[/xref]gold from the purse / And weigh silver in scales / And hire a goldsmith, and he makes a god — / They bow down [i]and[/i] even worship [i]it;[/i]

They lift it up on their shoulder; they carry it / And set it in its place and stand [i]it[/i] up. / It will not move from its place; / [i]Someone[/i] even cries out to it, and it does not answer, / Nor save [i]him[/i] from his distress.
Remember this and stand fast; / Put this in your heart, O transgressors.
Remember the former things of old, / That I am God and there is no one else; / I am God and there is no one like Me,
Who declares the end from the beginning / And things which have not been done from ancient times, / Saying, My [xref]a[/xref]counsel will stand, / And all My desire I will accomplish;

Who calls [i]for[/i] a [note]1[/note]bird of prey from the [xref]a[/xref]east, / And from a distant land a man [i]to be[/i] My counselor. / Indeed, I have spoken; surely I will bring it to pass. / I have purposed; surely I will do it.
verse.note: Referring to Cyrus in [link]44:28[/link] and [link]45:1[/link]. In [link]chs. 46-48[/link] Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is typified by Cyrus to release Jehovah's captives of the beloved Israel from Babylon. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 41[/link]. Cyrus was a "bird of prey" called by God to subdue the nations.

verse.text: Listen to Me, O hardhearted ones, / [i]Who are[/i] far from righteousness.
I will bring My righteousness [xref]a[/xref]near — it is not far off; / And My salvation will not delay; / And I will give salvation in Zion, / [i]And[/i] to Israel My glory.

Come down and sit in the dust, / O virgin daughter of Babylon; / Sit on the ground [i]where[/i] there is no throne, / O daughter of the Chaldeans; / For you will no longer be called / Tender and delicate.
Take millstones and [xref]a[/xref]grind meal; / Remove your veil; / Strip off [i]your[/i] flowing skirt; uncover [i]your[/i] thigh; / Cross over the rivers.
Your nakedness will be uncovered; / Your shame will also be seen; / I will take vengeance and will not spare any man.
Our [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer, Jehovah of hosts is His name, / The Holy One of Israel.
Sit in silence and go in darkness, / O daughter of the Chaldeans; / For you will no longer be called / The [xref]a[/xref]queen of kingdoms.

I was angry with My people; / I profaned My inheritance, / And I have delivered them up into your hand. / You have not shown any mercy to them; / You have made your yoke / Very heavy upon the elderly.
You have said, I will be / A [xref]a[/xref]queen forever; / You did not put these things into your heart; / You did not remember the end of [note]1[/note]them.
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: And now hear this, O lover of pleasure, / Who dwells securely / [xref]a[/xref]And says in [note]1[/note]your heart, / I am, and there is none besides me; / I will not [note]2[/note]dwell as a [xref]b[/xref]widow, / And I will not know loss of children.
verse.note: Lit., her.
Or, sit, as in [link]Rev. 18:7[/link].

verse.text: But these two things will come upon you / Suddenly, in [xref]a[/xref]one day: / Loss of children and widowhood; / In full measure they will come upon you / In spite of the multitude of your [xref]b[/xref]sorceries; / In spite of the great power of your spells.
And you felt secure in your wickedness; / You said, No one sees me. / Your wisdom and your knowledge / Have seduced you, / And you said in your heart, / I am, and there is none besides me.

But evil will come upon you, / And you will not know its origin; / Disaster will fall upon you / Which you cannot expiate for; / Desolation will come upon you suddenly, / [i]About which[/i] you do not know.
Stand now with your enchantments / And the multitude of your [xref]a[/xref]sorceries, / With which you have labored from your youth; / Perhaps you can profit; / Perhaps you will inspire terror.
You are wearied with the multitude of your counsels. / Let the astrologers, who gaze at the stars, / Who predict according to the new moons, / Stand up and save you from what is coming upon you.

Indeed, they are like stubble; / Fire consumes them; / They cannot deliver themselves / From the power of the flame; / There is no coal for warming themselves, / [i]Nor[/i] the light [i]of a fire[/i] to sit before.

So will those with whom you have labored be to you, / Those who have [xref]a[/xref]traded with you from your youth; / Each one will wander off in his own direction; / There will be no one to save you.

Hear this, O house of Jacob, / Who are called by the name of [xref]a[/xref]Israel; / And who came out from the [note]1[/note]waters of Judah, / Who swear by the name of Jehovah / And make mention of the God of Israel, / [i]But[/i] not in truth nor in righteousness.
verse.note: Some versions read, loins.

verse.text: For they call themselves after the holy city / And lean upon the God of Israel; / Jehovah of hosts is His name.
I have [xref]a[/xref]declared the former things from the beginning; / And they went out from My mouth, and I let [i]them[/i] hear them; / I did [i]them[/i] suddenly, and they came to pass.
Because I knew that you are obstinate, / And your [xref]a[/xref]neck is an iron sinew, / And your forehead bronze;
Therefore I declared [i]them[/i] to you long ago; / Before things came to pass I let you hear; / Lest you should say, My idol has done them, / And my graven image and my molten image commanded them.
You have heard; look at all this. And will you not declare it? / From this time I will let you hear [xref]a[/xref]new things / And hidden things which you have not known.
They have been created now, and not long ago; / And before [i]this[/i] day you have not even heard them; / Lest you should say, Indeed, I knew them.
You also have not heard and have not known; / Your ears were not even open from that time; / For I knew that you would deal very treacherously / And would be called a transgressor from the womb.
For My name's sake I will defer My anger, / And [i]for the sake of[/i] My praise I will restrain [i]it[/i] for you, / In order not to cut you off.
Indeed, I have [xref]a[/xref]refined you but not like silver; / I have tried you in the furnace of affliction.
For My own sake, [i]yes,[/i] for My own sake, I will do [i]it,[/i] / For how can [i]My name[/i] be profaned? / And I will not give My glory to another.
Listen to Me, O Jacob, / And Israel, whom I called; / I am He; I am the [xref]a[/xref]First, / I am also the Last.
Indeed, My hand [xref]a[/xref]laid the foundations of the earth, / And My right hand [xref]b[/xref]spread out the heavens; / When I call to them, / They stand together.

Assemble yourselves, all of you, and hear! / Who among them has declared these things? / Jehovah loves [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]him; he will do His pleasure / On Babylon, and His arm [i]will be upon[/i] the Chaldeans.
verse.note: Referring to Cyrus in [link]44:28[/link] and [link]45:1[/link], typifying Christ as the Servant of Jehovah. God loves Israel, loves His kingdom, signified by the city of Jerusalem, and loves His house, signified by the temple. In subduing Babylon and releasing the captives of Israel, and in charging Israel and supporting them to build up the temple and the city of their God ([link]Ezra 1[/link]), Cyrus did God's pleasure. Thus, God loved Cyrus. It was a matter of love for God to use a Gentile king to do what was in His heart.

verse.text: I, [i]even[/i] I, have spoken; indeed, I have called him; / I have brought him, and his way will prosper.

Draw near to Me and listen to this: / From the beginning I have not spoken in secret; / From the time it took place, I was there. / And now the Lord Jehovah / Has [xref]a[/xref]sent [note]1[/note]me and His [note]2[/note]Spirit.
verse.note: Referring to the prophet Isaiah.
Isaiah was sent by God with God the Spirit. In the New Testament the Father sent the Lord Jesus with the Spirit of God ([link]Luke 3:22[/link]).

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, your [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer, / The Holy One of Israel, / I am Jehovah your God, / Who teaches you to do that which is profitable, / Who [xref]b[/xref]leads you in the way that you should go.
If only you had hearkened to My commandments! / Then your [xref]a[/xref]peace would have been like a river, / And your righteousness like the waves of the sea,
And your seed would have been like the [xref]a[/xref]sand, / And the offspring of your bowels like the gravel; / His name would not have been cut off / Or destroyed before Me.

[xref]a[/xref]Come out from [note]1[/note]Babylon; / Flee from the Chaldeans; / With a voice of shouting declare; / Let them hear this, / Send it out unto the end of the earth; / Say, Jehovah has redeemed / His [xref]b[/xref]servant Jacob.
verse.note: In [link]Rev. 17[/link] and [link book="Rev."]18[/link] Babylon has two aspects: the religious aspect, signifying the Roman Catholic Church, and the material, physical aspect, signifying the city of Rome, the capital of Antichrist's kingdom (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 18[/link]). God's people need to come out of Babylon in its two aspects ([link]Rev. 18:4[/link]).

verse.text: And they did not thirst / When He led them through the dry places; / He caused water to flow / From the [xref]a[/xref]rock for them; / And He split the rock, / And the waters gushed out.
[xref]a[/xref]There is no peace, says Jehovah, for the wicked.
Listen to [note]1[/note]me, O coastlands, / And hearken, you peoples from afar. / Jehovah has called me [xref]a[/xref]from the womb; / From the bowels of my mother He has made mention of my name.
verse.note: Referring to Isaiah, the prophet of Jehovah, typifying Christ as the Servant of Jehovah ([link]Mark 10:45[/link]) for God's speaking ([link]Deut. 18:15[/link]; [link]John 3:34[/link]; [link]14:24[/link]). Isaiah served Jehovah as His mouthpiece to speak forth His word, which is the embodiment of Himself ([link]vv. 1-4[/link]). Isaiah's prophesying helped in the release of Israel and the rebuilding of the temple and the city. Cyrus, the Gentile king, Israel, God's chosen people, and Isaiah, the prophet set up by God, all did the same thing to please God: they served to release God's people, to build up God's house, and to build up God's kingdom, signified by the city of Jerusalem. Thus, they all typify Christ as God's servant ([link]Luke 4:18[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:18-19[/link]). All who are in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]) and who are thus one with Christ to release God's people and to build up His house and His kingdom are servants of God.

verse.text: And He has made my mouth like a [xref]a[/xref]sharp sword; / He has concealed me in the shadow of His hand, / And He has made me a polished arrow; / He has hidden me in His quiver.
And He said to me, You are My [xref]a[/xref]servant, / [note]1[/note]Israel, in whom I will be glorified.
verse.note: Jehovah considered the prophet Isaiah as His servant, a part of Israel, for His glorification. Isaiah was a part of Israel; hence, he was one with Israel as the servant of Jehovah. Christ also is a part of Israel ([link]Hosea 11:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 2:15b[/link]). That Jehovah will be glorified in His servant typifies that God is glorified in Christ ([link]John 13:31b[/link]) as the Israel of God. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 43[/link].

verse.text: But I said, I have [note]1[/note]labored in vain; / I have used up my strength for nothing and vanity; / Yet surely the justice [i]due[/i] to me is with Jehovah, / And my recompense with my God.
verse.note: Here Isaiah typifies Christ. People judged Christ wrongly, thinking that His word was nothing and vain. However, Christ was assured that the justice due to Him would come from God ([link]1 Pet. 2:23[/link]). God values Christ's word (cf. [link]Matt. 24:35[/link]) and will reward Him for His speaking.

verse.text: And now says Jehovah, / Who formed [note]1[/note]Me from the [note]2[/note]womb to be His Servant, / To bring Jacob back to Him, / So that Israel would be gathered to Him; / And I will be glorified in the sight of Jehovah, / And My God will be My strength.
verse.note: [link]Verses 5-9a[/link] refer to Christ as the Servant of Jehovah ([link]42:1-7[/link]). In this chapter whatever is spoken concerning Isaiah and Israel is also spoken concerning Christ. This means that Christ as the Servant of Jehovah fulfills all that Isaiah and Israel are as the servant of Jehovah.

God formed Jesus to be His Servant in the womb, with His divinity mingled with His humanity ([link]Matt. 1:18-20[/link]; [link]Luke 1:35[/link]). Thus, when He came out of the womb of His mother, He was a God-man.

verse.text: He says, It is too small a thing that You would be My Servant / To raise up the tribes of Jacob / And bring back the preserved of Israel; / [xref]a[/xref]I will also set You as a [note]1[/note]light of the nations / That You may be My [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]salvation unto the ends of the earth.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 42[/link].

Christ as the Servant of Jehovah serves God by being a covenant and a light to God's chosen people that He may be the full salvation of God extending to the ends of the earth ([link]42:5-7[/link]; [link]49:6[/link], [link]8b-9a[/link]). God's full salvation is based on God's righteousness and is consummated in God's life ([link]Rom. 5:17[/link], [link]21[/link]). Righteousness in God's justice and life through God's light are the two basic factors of God's salvation ([link]Rom. 1:16-17[/link]; [link]5:18b[/link]; [link]Titus 3:7[/link]). God's salvation in its two aspects is composed of Christ as the covenant for justification and Christ as the light for life ([link]Rom. 5:10[/link]). Through His death Christ as the covenant satisfies God's righteousness for justification as the base of God's full salvation, and in His resurrection Christ as the light imparts life as the consummation of God's full salvation. Ultimately, the complete salvation of God is embodied in the New Jerusalem, which is a matter of life built on the foundation of righteousness ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link]; [link]21:14[/link], [link]19-20[/link] and note [link]19[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2).[br][br]Through His death and in His resurrection Christ has become the new covenant as the new testament ([link]Heb. 8:10-12[/link]; [link]9:15-17[/link]) according to God's righteousness to be the base of God's full salvation. God gave Christ as a light to the nations that He might be God's salvation to all the world ([link]Matt. 4:16[/link]; [link]Luke 2:30-32[/link]). The life of this light ([link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]8:32[/link]), as the indestructible life ([link]Heb. 7:16b[/link]), the incorruptible life ([link]2 Tim. 1:10b[/link]), and the real and eternal life that we should lay hold on ([link]1 Tim. 6:19[/link], [link]12[/link]), becomes God's salvation to us in His righteousness ([link]Rom. 5:10[/link], [link]17[/link]). This life also ensures us, guarantees us, the heirs of God in His life, the right to inherit God with all His riches as our eternal inheritance ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]). Such a life of light grows in us continually, issuing in our church life today ([link]Eph. 5:8[/link]) and consummating in the New Jerusalem in eternity ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link], [link]9b-11[/link], [link]18-23[/link]; [link]22:1-5[/link]).

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / The [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer of Israel, His Holy One, / To the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]despised One, the One abhorred by the nation, / The One subjected to tyrants, / Kings will see and arise, / And princes will bow down; / Because of Jehovah, who is [xref]c[/xref]faithful, / The Holy One of Israel, who has chosen You.
verse.note: Christ was the despised One, the One abhorred by the nation of Israel, the One subjected to tyrants, i.e., the Roman officials ([link]Matt. 27:11-26[/link]). From His resurrection until today He has been not only glorified, honored, by God ([link]v. 5c[/link]) but also respected by human kings and worshipped by human princes.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Thus says Jehovah, / In an acceptable time I have answered You, / And in a day of salvation I have helped You; / And I will preserve You and give You for a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant of the people, / To restore the [note]2[/note]land, to [note]3[/note]apportion the desolate inheritances,
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link] in this chapter and note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 42[/link].

Or, the earth. The restoring of the land is mainly for the kingdom of God, which will eventually consummate in the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth. In the believers' experience, to restore the land means to have Christ as the land (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]) enlarged or expanded, to occupy Christ as the land for the building up of God's kingdom so that His temple, His testimony, may be established (cf. [link]1 Chron. 4:10[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:14-21[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:7-14[/link]).
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 42[/link].

verse.text: To say to the prisoners, Come forth, / [i]To say[/i] to those who are in darkness, Show yourselves.[separator][note]1[/note]They will feed along the roads, / And their pasture will be on all the bare heights;
verse.note: Because Christ has become a covenant for the people of Israel ([link]v. 8[/link]; [link]42:5-7[/link]), the captives will return.

verse.text: They will not [xref]a[/xref]hunger or thirst; / Neither the scorching heat nor the sun will [xref]b[/xref]strike them; / For He who has compassion on them will lead them / And will [xref]c[/xref]guide them beside the springs of water;
And I will make all My [xref]a[/xref]mountains into a road, / And My highways will be raised up.
Indeed, these will come from a distance, / And indeed these [i]will come[/i] [xref]a[/xref]from the north and the west, / And these from the land of the [note]1[/note]Sinim.
verse.note: Probably the Chinese.

verse.text: Give a [xref]a[/xref]ringing shout, O heavens, and exult, O earth, / And break forth into shouting, O mountains; / For Jehovah has comforted His people / And will have compassion on His afflicted ones.
But Zion has said, Jehovah has forsaken me, / And the Lord has forgotten me.
Can a woman forget her nursing child, / That she would not have [xref]a[/xref]compassion on the son of her womb? / Even though they may forget, / Yet I will not forget you.
Indeed, I have [xref]a[/xref]engraved you upon the palms [i]of My hands;[/i] / Your walls are continually before Me.
[note]1[/note]Your children make haste; / Your destroyers and those who lay you waste / Will go forth from you.
verse.note: Some versions read, Your builders outstrip your destroyers.

verse.text: Lift up your eyes and look around; / All of these gather themselves together and come to you. / As I live, declares Jehovah, / You will put all of them on like an [xref]a[/xref]ornament / And gird [i]yourself[/i] with them like a bride.
For your waste and desolate [i]places[/i] / And your devastated land — / For you will be too constricted now because of its inhabitants, / And those who swallowed you up will be far away.
The children of whom you were bereaved / Will yet say in your ears, / This place is too constricted for me; / Make room for me that I may dwell [i]here.[/i]

Then you will say in your heart, / Who has borne these for me, / Since I have been bereaved [i]of children[/i] and am barren, / An exile and driven about? / And who brought these up? / Indeed, I was left alone; / From where did these [i]come?[/i]

Thus says the Lord Jehovah, / Indeed, I will lift up My hand to the nations, / And unto the peoples I will lift up My banner; / And they will [xref]a[/xref]bring your sons in their arms, / And they will carry your daughters on their shoulders.

And kings will be your foster fathers; / And their princesses will be those who [xref]a[/xref]nurse you; / They will bow down to you with their faces toward the earth / And lick the dust of your feet; / And you will know that I am Jehovah; / Those who [xref]b[/xref]wait on Me will not be ashamed.
Can the booty be taken from the [xref]a[/xref]strong man, / Or the lawful captives be delivered?

Surely, thus says Jehovah, / Even the captive may be taken from the strong man, / And the booty may be released from the tyrant; / For I will strive with those who strive with you, / And I will save your children;

And I will feed those who oppress you with their own flesh; / And they will be drunk with their own blood as with sweet wine; / Then all flesh will know / That I am Jehovah your Savior / And your [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.

Thus says Jehovah, / Where is the [xref]a[/xref]bill of your mother's divorce / With which I have put her away? / Or to which of My creditors / Have I sold you? / Indeed, for your iniquities you were [xref]b[/xref]sold, / And for your transgressions your mother was put away.

Why [i]when[/i] I came was there no man? / [i]And when[/i] I [xref]a[/xref]called [i]why[/i] was there no one to answer? / Is My hand [xref]b[/xref]so short that it cannot redeem? / Or do I have no power to deliver? / Indeed, at My rebuke I [xref]c[/xref]dry up the sea; / I make the rivers a wilderness; / Their [xref]d[/xref]fish stink because there is no water, / And die of thirst.
I clothe the heavens with [xref]a[/xref]blackness, / And make sackcloth their [xref]b[/xref]covering.

The Lord Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]given [note]1[/note]me / The tongue of the instructed, / That I should know how to sustain the [xref]b[/xref]weary with a word. / He awakens [i]me[/i] morning by morning; / He awakens my ear / To hear as an instructed one.
verse.note: Referring to Isaiah, who typifies Christ as the Servant of Jehovah (see [link]49:1-5[/link]). [link]Verses 4-5[/link] speak of the instruction received by Christ as Jehovah's Servant.

verse.text: The Lord Jehovah has opened my [xref]a[/xref]ear; / And I was [xref]b[/xref]not rebellious, / Nor did I turn back.

[note]1[/note]I gave my back to those who [xref]a[/xref]strike [i]me[/i] / And my [xref]b[/xref]cheeks to those who pluck out [i]the hair;[/i] / I did not hide my face / From humiliation and [xref]c[/xref]spitting.
verse.note: [link]Verses 6-9[/link] show the life lived by Isaiah as the servant of Jehovah, typifying the life that Christ as the Servant of Jehovah lived on earth ([link]Matt. 26:67[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:23[/link]).

verse.text: The Lord Jehovah helps me; / Therefore I have not been dishonored; / Therefore I have set my [xref]a[/xref]face like a flint, / And I know that I will not be put to shame.
The One who justifies me is near; who will contend with me? / Let us stand up together! / Who is my adversary in judgment? / Let him come near to me.
Indeed, the Lord Jehovah helps me, / Who is the one who condemns me? / Indeed, they will all wear out like a [xref]a[/xref]garment; / The [xref]b[/xref]moth will consume them.
Who among you fears Jehovah; / Who hears the voice of His servant; / Who walks in darkness / And has no light? / Let him trust in the name of Jehovah, / And rely on his God.

Indeed, all of you who kindle a fire, / Who surround yourselves with firebrands, / Walk into the light of your fire / And into the firebrands which you have lit. / You will have this from My hand: / You will lie down in torment.

Listen to Me, you who pursue righteousness, / Who seek after Jehovah, / Look to the [note]1[/note]rock [i]from which[/i] you were hewn, / And to the excavation of the quarry [i]from which[/i] you were dug.
verse.note: Referring not to God but to Abraham, who was the source of Israel. Jehovah's calling of Israel is based on His calling of their father Abraham; hence, it is firm.

verse.text: Look to Abraham your father, / And to Sarah who travailed with you; / For I [xref]a[/xref]called him [i]when he was[/i] one [i]person,[/i] / And [xref]b[/xref]blessed him and multiplied him.

For Jehovah has comforted Zion; / He has comforted all her waste places, / And made her wilderness like Eden, / And her desert like the [xref]a[/xref]garden of Jehovah. / Gladness and joy will be found in her, / Thanksgiving and the voice of song.
Hearken to Me, O My people; / Give ear to Me, O My nation; / For [xref]a[/xref]instruction will go out from Me; / And I will set My judgment as a [xref]b[/xref]light for the peoples.
My righteousness is near; My salvation has gone forth; / My arms will judge the peoples; / The coastlands will wait for Me / And place their hope in My arm.

Lift up your eyes to the heavens, / And look upon the earth beneath; / For the [xref]a[/xref]heavens will vanish away like smoke, / And the earth will wear out like a [xref]b[/xref]garment, / And those who dwell there will die in like manner; / But My salvation will be forever, / And My righteousness will not be abolished.
Listen to Me, you who know righteousness, / A people in whose heart is My instruction, / Do not fear the reproach of man; / Do not be terrified at their revilings.
For the moth will eat them up like a garment, / And the worm will eat them like wool; / But My righteousness will be forever, / And My salvation from generation to generation.

[xref]a[/xref]Awake, awake! Put on strength, / O [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]arm of Jehovah; / Awake as in the days of old, / [i]As[/i] in the generations of past ages. / Was it not You who cut Rahab in pieces, / Who pierced through the dragon?
verse.note: Signifying the strength of Jehovah, the dynamic might of Christ in His divinity, and referring to Christ as the all-inclusive Servant of Jehovah ([link]53:1-2[/link]) in relation to Israel's return from captivity ([link]52:10-12[/link]). In Israel's return and restoration, the all-inclusive Christ is, first, the arm of Jehovah, second, the reigning God ([link]52:7[/link]), and, third, the exalted Christ ([link]52:13[/link]).

verse.text: Was it not You who [xref]a[/xref]dried up the sea, / The waters of the great deep; / Who made the depths of the sea [i]into[/i] a way / For the redeemed to pass through?

[xref]a[/xref]Therefore the [note]1[/note]ransomed of Jehovah will return / And will come to [xref]b[/xref]Zion with a ringing shout, / And eternal joy will be upon their heads. / They will lay hold on gladness and joy, / And [xref]c[/xref]sorrow and sighing will flee away.
verse.note: Referring here to the redemption of God's people for their release from captivity in Babylon, after which they could return (cf. [link]Exo. 6:6[/link]). Before God could redeem His people from captivity, they had to be redeemed from sin under God's condemnation, as illustrated by the redemption through the passover lamb prior to the exodus from Egypt ([link]Exo. 12[/link]).

verse.text: I, [i]even[/i] I, am He who will comfort you. / Who are you that you are afraid of man who will die, / And of the son of man [i]who[/i] will be made [i]like[/i] [xref]a[/xref]grass,

That you have forgotten Jehovah who made you, / Who [xref]a[/xref]stretched out the heavens / And laid the foundations of the earth, / That you have been continually afraid every day, / Because of the fury of the oppressor / When he sets himself up to destroy [i]you?[/i] / But where is the fury of the oppressor?
The one who is bowed down will soon be released / And will not die in the pit, / Nor will his bread be lacking.
I am Jehovah your God, / Who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar, / Jehovah of hosts is His name.

And I have put My words in your mouth, / And I have covered you in the shadow of My hand, / To [note]1[/note]plant the [xref]a[/xref]heavens and lay the foundations of the earth, / And to say to Zion, You are My people.
verse.note: Some versions have, stretch, or, establish.

verse.text: Wake yourself up, wake yourself up; / Stand up, O Jerusalem, / You who have [xref]a[/xref]drunk from the hand of Jehovah / The cup of His wrath; / The bowl of the cup of staggering / You have drunk; you have drained it out.
There is no one to guide her / Among all the children whom she has brought forth; / There is no one to take her by the hand / Among all the children she has raised up.
These two things have happened to you; / Who will lament for you? / Desolation and destruction, and famine and sword. / How will I comfort you?
Your sons have fainted; / They lie at the head of every street like an antelope in a net, / Full of the wrath of Jehovah, / The rebuke of your God.
Therefore hear this now, O afflicted one, / You who are drunk but not with wine:

Thus says your Lord Jehovah and your God / Who pleads the cause of His people, / Indeed, I have taken from your hand / The cup of staggering; / You will no longer need to drink / The bowl of the cup of My wrath anymore;

And I will put it into the hand of those who afflict you, / Who have said to your soul, Bow down / That we may walk over you; / And you have made your back like the ground, / Like the street for them to cross over.

[xref]a[/xref]Awake! Awake! Put on / Your strength, O Zion; / Put on your beautiful garments, / O Jerusalem, O [xref]b[/xref]holy city; / For the uncircumcised and the [xref]c[/xref]unclean / Will no longer come into you.
Shake yourself from the dust; arise, / Sit down, O Jerusalem; / Loose yourself from the bonds on your neck, / O captive daughter of Zion.
For thus says Jehovah, You are those who have been [xref]a[/xref]sold for nothing, and you will be [xref]b[/xref]redeemed without money.
For thus says the Lord Jehovah, At first My people went down to [xref]a[/xref]Egypt to sojourn there; then the [xref]b[/xref]Assyrian oppressed them without cause.

Now then what do I have here, declares Jehovah, since My people have been taken away for nothing? Those who rule over them howl, declares Jehovah, and My name is continually [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed all day long.
Therefore My people will know My name; therefore in that day [i]they will know[/i] that I am He who speaks; here I am.

[xref]a[/xref]How beautiful on the mountains / Are the [xref]b[/xref]feet of him who brings good news, / Of him who announces peace, who brings news of good things, / Who announces salvation; / Of him who says to Zion, [note]1[/note]Your God reigns!
verse.note: This is the announcing of the restoration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]). [link]Isaiah 40:9[/link] speaks of God coming to accomplish redemption unto salvation for His people, whereas this verse, after redemption has been accomplished, announces that in the restoration, the millennial kingdom, God reigns (cf. [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]). The reigning God here is the Redeemer, the Savior, mentioned in [link]ch. 40[/link].

verse.text: The voice of your watchmen! They lift up their voice; / They give a ringing shout together; / For they will see with their very own eyes / When Jehovah restores Zion.
Break forth, give a ringing shout together, / You wasted places of Jerusalem, / For Jehovah has comforted His people, / He has redeemed Jerusalem.
Jehovah has bared His holy [note]1[/note]arm / In the sight of all the nations, / And all the ends of the earth will see / The [xref]a[/xref]salvation of our God.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 51[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Depart! Depart! Go out from [note]1[/note]there! / Do not touch any unclean thing! / Go out from the midst of her! Cleanse yourselves, / You who bear the [note]2[/note]vessels of Jehovah!
verse.note: Referring to Babylon. See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 48[/link].

Indicating that the vessels of the temple, which had been carried away to Babylon ([link]2 Chron. 36:18[/link]; [link]Dan. 1:1-2[/link]), would be brought back to Jerusalem ([link]Ezra 1:7-11[/link]).

verse.text: For you will not go out in haste, / And you will not go in flight; / For Jehovah will [xref]a[/xref]go before you, / And the God of Israel will be your rear guard.
Indeed, My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Servant will act [note]2[/note]wisely and will prosper; / He will be [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]exalted and lifted up and very high.
verse.note: [link]Isaiah 52:13-53:12[/link] reveals Christ as the Servant of Jehovah not in the Old Testament economy but in the New Testament economy, i.e., as God who became a man, who died and resurrected, and who became the life-giving Spirit to enter into His elect and dwell in them as the indwelling Spirit.

From the day that He came out to minister on this earth, the Lord Jesus acted wisely and prospered in God's pleasure ([link]v. 13a[/link]; [link]53:10b[/link]; [link]Matt. 11:19[/link] and note 3). God's good pleasure was first that the Son would go to the cross and die for God's chosen people ([link]Matt. 26:39[/link]; [link]Heb. 10:5-10[/link]) and then that He would rise from the dead to regenerate millions of God's people to be God's sons ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]John 20:17[/link]). This is the wisdom by which Christ as the Servant of Jehovah acted wisely. Since His ascension Jesus has been acting prudently and wisely on the earth, and in whatever He has done, He has prospered.

Christ has been exalted to the third heavens, to the right hand of God ([link]Phil. 2:9[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:14[/link]; [link]7:26[/link]; [link]8:1[/link]). He has also been lifted up. Before being exalted and lifted up, Christ was humiliated ([link]v. 14[/link]; [link]53:1-10a[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:8[/link]).

verse.text: Even as many were astonished at [note]1[/note]Him — / His [note]2[/note]visage was [xref]a[/xref]marred more than that of any man, / And His form more than that of the sons of men —
verse.note: According to some MSS and ancient versions; other MSS read, you.

[i]Visage[/i] denotes the appearance and also refers to the face or facial expression. Christ's face and His form were marred (disfigured) in order that He might save us. This is astonishing, different from what people expected Christ as a servant of God to be.

verse.text: So will He [note]1[/note]surprise many nations; / Kings will [note]1[/note]shut their mouths because of Him; / [xref]a[/xref]For what had not been [note]2[/note]recounted to them they will see, / And what they had not [xref]b[/xref]heard of they will contemplate.
verse.note: Jesus will surprise many nations, and kings will shut their mouths because of Him, for what He is, is altogether different from what they imagined. People are surprised to learn that a great person such as Christ was actually a small man who lived in the despised region of Galilee, in the despised city of Nazareth, in the poor home of a carpenter, and that He was rejected and put on the cross and crucified ([link]53:2-10a[/link]).

The things to be recounted, to be seen, to be heard of, and to be contemplated are the things reported and revealed in [link]ch. 53[/link] concerning Christ in His incarnation, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension according to the New Testament gospel.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Who has believed our [note]1[/note]report? / And to whom has the [xref]b[/xref]arm of Jehovah been [note]1[/note]revealed?
verse.note: The prophets preached the New Testament gospel in the New Testament economy, but no one believed their report. Their report was based on God's revelation of Christ as the arm of Jehovah, the dynamic Redeemer (see note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 51[/link]). Both the report and the revelation concern Christ as the Servant of Jehovah ([link]v. 11b[/link]).[br][br]This chapter speaks clearly concerning Christ in four stages: (1) the stage of Christ's incarnation ([link]vv. 1b-3[/link]), (2) the stage of Christ's crucifixion ([link]vv. 4-10a[/link], [link]12b[/link]), (3) the stage of Christ's resurrection ([link]vv. 10b-11[/link]), and (4) the stage of Christ's ascension ([link]v. 12a[/link]). The entire chapter is a confession that will be made by the household of Israel who will be saved at Christ's second coming ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26-27[/link]). At that time they will confess the contents of [link]Isa. 53[/link], and this chapter will be full of taste to them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For He grew up like a tender [note]2[/note]plant before Him, / And like a [xref]a[/xref]root out of dry ground. / He has no [note]3[/note][i]attracting[/i] form nor [xref]b[/xref]majesty that we should look upon Him, / Nor beautiful appearance that we should desire Him.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] here introduces the reason that no one believed the report and received the revelation concerning Christ ([link]v. 1[/link]).

[link]Verses 1b-3[/link] contain the prophet's report and Jehovah's revelation concerning Christ as the incarnated Savior, who lived a lowly and sorrowful human life, which fully qualified Him to be the Redeemer and the Savior to save fallen men from Satan, sin, death, and self ([link]Heb. 2:14-18[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:21[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:10[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:24-25[/link]).[br][br]In His humanity Christ grew up not like a large tree but like a small delicate sprout (a tender plant) before Jehovah, in a difficult environment (dry ground), which included His being born of a poor family and His living in Nazareth, a despised city, in Galilee, a despised region.
Instead of majesty, Jesus had poverty ([link]Matt. 8:20[/link]), and instead of an attractive form and a beautiful appearance, He had a visage and form that were disfigured ([link]52:14[/link]).

verse.text: He was [xref]a[/xref]despised and forsaken of men, / A man of [note]1[/note]sorrows and acquainted with grief; / And like one from whom men hide their faces, / He was despised; and we did not esteem Him.
verse.note: Lit., pains. So also in the next verse. Christ was a "man whose chief distinction was, that His life was one of constant painful endurance" (Keil and Delitzsch). As the complete God, signified by the arm of Jehovah ([link]v. 1[/link]; [link]51:9[/link]; [link]52:10[/link]) as the power of God ([link]1 Cor. 1:22-24[/link]), Christ became a perfect man, signified by a man of sorrows, in His incarnation ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:5b[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Surely He has [note]1[/note]borne our [note]2[/note]sicknesses, / And carried our [note]2[/note]sorrows; / [note]3[/note]Yet we ourselves esteemed Him stricken, / Smitten of God and afflicted.
verse.note: In the report of the prophets and the revelation of Jehovah ([link]v. 1[/link]), Christ is revealed as the crucified Redeemer, who sacrificed Himself for our trespasses (our sin) to accomplish Jehovah's eternal redemption ([link]vv. 4-10a[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:12[/link]) that the believers in Christ may be redeemed (forgiven of sins — [link]Acts 10:43[/link], justified — [link]Acts 13:39[/link], and reconciled to God — [link]Rom. 5:10[/link]), resulting in the life union with Christ in His resurrection ([link]v. 10b[/link]), the reality of which is the life-giving Spirit ([link]John 11:25[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:11[/link]).

Sicknesses and sorrows, like transgressions and iniquities ([link]v. 5[/link]), come from sin; hence, they too need Christ's redemption ([link]Matt. 8:17[/link] and note). Christ bore our sicknesses at the time He was judged by God on the cross, in the hour when God put all our iniquities on Him ([link]v. 6b[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]).

People thought that Christ must have been wrong in something and that, as a result, He was stricken, smitten of God and afflicted. They did not understand that Christ died vicariously, in the place of us, the sinners ([link]vv. 4-5[/link], [link]8-9[/link], [link]11c[/link], [link]12c[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:18a[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But He was [xref]a[/xref]wounded because of our transgressions; / He was crushed because of our iniquities; / The chastening for our peace was upon Him, / And by His [xref]b[/xref]stripes we have been [note]2[/note]healed.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup][/link].
See note [link]24[sup]7[/sup] in 1 Pet. 2[/link].

verse.text: We all like [xref]a[/xref]sheep have gone astray; / Each of us has turned to his own way, / And Jehovah has caused the iniquity of [note]1[/note]us all / To [note]2[/note]fall on Him.
verse.note: Referring here especially to the remnant of the Jews at the time of the Lord's coming back. At that time all the remaining Jews will repent ([link]Zech. 12:10-14[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]) and will speak the words of this verse.

It was when God was judging Jesus on the cross that He caused the iniquity of us all to fall on Him, making Jesus, in the eyes of God, the unique sinner at that moment ([link]Matt. 27:45-46[/link] and notes [link]45[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]46[sup]2[/sup][/link]). Christ's death was not merely a murder ([link]Acts 7:52[/link]), nor was it a martyrdom; rather, it was carried out by God Himself according to His law. Thus, Christ died a vicarious death as the Substitute for sinners ([link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]), a death that was legal according to God's law and was recognized and approved by God according to the law.

verse.text: He was [note]1[/note]oppressed, and it was He who was afflicted, / Yet He did [xref]a[/xref]not open His mouth; / [xref]b[/xref]Like a lamb that is led to the slaughter / And like a sheep that is dumb before its shearers, / So He did not open His mouth.
verse.note: In His vicarious death for sinners, Christ was oppressed, afflicted, and led to the slaughter like a lamb and sheared before the shearers like a sheep, with no reaction ([link]Acts 8:32[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:63-64[/link]; [link]27:12[/link], [link]14[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]By oppression and by judgment He was taken away; / And as for His [note]2[/note]generation, who [i]among them[/i] had the thought / That He was [xref]b[/xref]cut off out of the land of the living / For the transgression of my people to whom the stroke [i]was due?[/i]
verse.note: Christ was oppressed by the hypocritical Jewish leaders ([link]Matt. 26:57[/link], [link]59[/link], [link]65-68[/link]) and then judged by the unjust Roman officials ([link]Luke 23:1-12[/link]; [link]John 18:33-38[/link]; [link]19:1-16[/link]). By these two things He was taken away and was crucified.
No one among Christ's generation understood that He was cut off out of the land of the living for the transgression of the prophet's people, the Jews, to whom the stroke was due.

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note]assigned His grave with the wicked, / But with a [xref]a[/xref]rich man in His [note]2[/note]death, / Although He had done [note]3[/note]no violence, / Nor was there any [xref]b[/xref]deceit in His mouth.
verse.note: Those who crucified Christ planned to bury Him with the two transgressors, the wicked ones ([link]Luke 23:32-33[/link]), but eventually God in His sovereignty caused Christ to be buried in a rich man's tomb ([link]Matt. 27:57-60[/link]).
The word is plural in Hebrew, [i]deaths,[/i] signifying "a violent death, the very pain of which makes it like dying again and again" (Keil and Delitzsch).

Christ was sinless ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:22[/link]); hence, He did not die for His own sins. He died vicariously for us, the sinners ([link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]).

verse.text: But Jehovah was pleased to crush Him, to afflict Him with grief. / When He makes Himself an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]offering for sin, / He will see a [note]2[/note]seed, He will [note]3[/note]extend [i]His[/i] [xref]b[/xref]days, / And the [note]4[/note]pleasure of Jehovah will prosper in His hand.
verse.note: Christ volunteered to be an offering for sin, referring not to the sin offering ([link]Lev. 4[/link]) but to an offering for sin in its totality — for wrongdoings, mistakes, trespasses, transgressions, evildoings, and iniquities ([link]John 1:29[/link]).

[link]Verses 10b-11[/link] refer to Christ in His resurrection. The seed here, a corporate seed, is the church as the Body of Christ, comprising all the believers produced as the many grains by the death of Christ as the one grain and by His reproductive resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is the resurrected Life-giver, the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link], [link]17[/link]), to produce a seed for the building up of His Body as His continuation for Jehovah's pleasure and for Christ's satisfaction.
Today Christ is extending His days by living in His believers ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; see note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 28[/link]). His believers as His Body are His extension.

The pleasure of God ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:13[/link]) is to see many sons born of Him to become the members of Christ, who constitute the church as the Body of Christ, the corporate expression of Christ. This depends altogether on Christ's death and resurrection.

verse.text: He will see [i]the[/i] [note]1[/note][i]fruit[/i] of the travail of His soul, / And He will be [note]2[/note]satisfied; / By the [note]3[/note]knowledge of Him, the righteous One, My [xref]a[/xref]Servant, will [note]4[/note]make the / many [xref]b[/xref]righteous, / And He will [xref]c[/xref]bear their iniquities.
verse.note: The fruit of the travail of Christ's soul implies all the items produced in and through Christ's resurrection, as follows: (1) As the processed One, the last Adam, Christ became the life-giving Spirit as the reality of the pneumatic Christ for His propagation through life-imparting ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]); (2) as the preeminent One, the One who has the first place in all things, Christ became the Firstborn from the dead for the germinating of God's new creation and for Christ to be Head of the Body ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]); (3) as the God-man, Christ was begotten of God in His humanity ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]) to be the firstborn Son of God in both the divine and human natures, to be a model for conforming many sons to His image ([link]Rom. 8:29b[/link]); (4) as the resurrection life ([link]John 11:25[/link]), Christ regenerated all His believers ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), making them His brothers and the many sons of God ([link]Heb. 2:10a[/link], [link]11b-12[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29b[/link]; [link]John 20:17[/link]), who are the members of God's household to be God's kingdom ([link]Eph. 2:19[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:10[/link]) and God's precious inheritance ([link]Eph. 1:11[/link]); (5) as the one grain of wheat, Christ became the many grains ([link]John 12:24[/link]), who are His increase ([link]John 3:30[/link]) and the components of His Body, i.e., the one bread, the church ([link]1 Cor. 10:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]); (6) through His life-releasing death and with His life-imparting resurrection, Christ produced a corporate seed as the issue of the travail of His soul, which seed He saw in His resurrection and was satisfied ([link]vv. 10c-11b[/link]; cf. [link]Gal. 3:29[/link]); and (7) as the life of the believers, the resurrected Christ is all the members and in all the members of the new man ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]).
Christ will see the church and be satisfied with the church.
Not Christ's knowledge but the knowing of Him, the righteous One, the resurrected Christ as the Servant of Jehovah.

Christ will make righteous those who know Him as the righteous One. Since this verse refers to Christ in His resurrection, to make us righteous is not merely to justify us objectively but to make us righteous subjectively by His living in us as the resurrection life and our living Him ([link]Matt. 5:20[/link] and note 1; [link]Rom. 5:19[/link] and note 1; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link] and note 3; [link]Phil. 3:9[/link] and note 5).

verse.text: Therefore I will divide to Him a [xref]a[/xref]portion with the [note]1[/note]Great, / And He will divide the [note]2[/note]spoil with the [note]1[/note]Strong; / Because He [xref]b[/xref]poured out His [note]3[/note]life unto death / And was [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]numbered with the transgressors, / Yet He alone [xref]d[/xref]bore the sin of many / And [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]interceded for the transgressors.
verse.note: The first part of this verse concerns Christ in His ascension. [i]The Great and the Strong[/i] here refer to God. In Christ's ascension God divided to Christ a portion with God as the great One, and Christ divided the spoil with God as the strong One.

[i]Spoil[/i] indicates that a war was fought. On the cross and in His resurrection Christ fought the battle, gained the victory, and took the spoil from Satan (see note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 4[/link]). In Christ's ascension there was a demonstration of Christ's victory by the sharing of the captives, the spoil, taken in Christ's victory. As the ascended Victor, Christ shared the spoil of His victory with God, the Great and the Strong ([link]Psa. 68:18[/link] and note 3). Then Christ gave the spoil to the church as gifts for the building up of the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 4:8b[/link], [link]11-12[/link] and note [link]8[sup]3[/sup][/link]). This is for the accomplishing of the pleasure of Jehovah, which will prosper in Christ's hand according to God's desire and plan ([link]v. 10c[/link]).

Lit., soul. Man, God, and Christ all had a part in Christ's crucifixion. Man did the murdering, the killing ([link]Acts 7:52[/link]), but God carried out the legal judgment to kill Christ as a legal Substitute that Christ might die a vicarious death for sinners ([link]vv. 6b[/link], [link]10a[/link]). Moreover, Christ Himself was willing to be such an offering. He made Himself that offering ([link]v. 10b[/link]), and He poured out His life for that purpose ([link]John 10:17-18[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:14[/link]).
When Christ was crucified on the cross, He was numbered with the transgressors ([link]Luke 23:32-33[/link]) and He interceded for the transgressors ([link]Luke 23:34a[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Give a ringing shout, O barren one, you who have not borne; / Break forth into joyful shouting and cry out, you who have not been in labor; / For [xref]b[/xref]more numerous are the children of the desolate one / Than the children of the married woman, says Jehovah.
Enlarge your tent site, / Let them stretch out the curtains of your habitations; / Spare not; / Lengthen your cords, / And strengthen your pegs;
For on the right and on the left you will break open, / And your [xref]a[/xref]seed will possess the nations / And will cause the desolate cities to be inhabited.

Fear not, for you will not be put to shame; / Neither be humiliated, for you will not be ashamed; / But you will forget the shame of your youth, / And the [xref]a[/xref]reproach of your widowhood you will no longer remember.

For your [xref]a[/xref]Maker is your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Husband; / Jehovah of hosts is His name. / And the Holy One of Israel is your [xref]c[/xref]Redeemer; / He is called the [xref]d[/xref]God of all the earth.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in Exo. 20[/link] and note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Hosea 1[/link].

verse.text: For Jehovah has called you, / Like a wife who has been forsaken and is grieved in spirit, / Even like a wife of [i]one's[/i] youth when she has been rejected, / Says your God.
For a short moment I forsook you, / But with great compassion I will [xref]a[/xref]gather you.
In a flood of wrath I hid / My face from you for a moment, / But with eternal lovingkindness I will have mercy on you, / Says Jehovah your [xref]a[/xref]Redeemer.

For this is [i]like[/i] the waters of [xref]a[/xref]Noah to Me, / When I swore that the waters of Noah / Would not overflow the earth ever again; / So I have sworn that I will not be angry with you, / Nor will I rebuke you.

For the mountains may [xref]a[/xref]depart, / And the hills may shake, / But My [xref]b[/xref]lovingkindness will not depart from you, / And My [note]1[/note]covenant of peace will not shake, / Says Jehovah who has compassion on you.
verse.note: Christ's dynamic redemption accomplished through His vicarious death and reproductive resurrection ([link]ch. 53[/link]) is in relation to His being the covenant for Israel's security. Christ as the Servant of Jehovah is the reality of this covenant to be a surety to Israel for their security ([link]42:6[/link] and note 1; [link]49:8[/link]). The dynamic redemption accomplished by Christ is the security not only to Israel but also to the seed ([link]53:10[/link]), which is the church as the corporate Body of the resurrected Christ.

verse.text: O afflicted one, storm-tossed [i]and[/i] not comforted, / Indeed, I Myself will lay down your stones in dark mortar, / And will lay your foundations with [xref]a[/xref]sapphires.
And I will make your battlements of rubies, / And your gates of carbuncles, / And all your borders will be precious stones.
And all your children will be [xref]a[/xref]taught of Jehovah, / And the peace of your children will be great.
In righteousness you will be established; / You will be far from oppression, for you will not fear, / And far from terror, for it will not come near you.
Indeed, they may fiercely attack you, but it is not of Me; / Whoever attacks you will fall because of you.
Indeed, it is I who have created the blacksmith / Who blows the fire of the coals, / And brings out a weapon for its work; / And it is I who have created the destroyer to ruin.

[note]1[/note]No weapon that is formed against you will prosper, / And every tongue that rises up to judge you, you will condemn. / This is the heritage of the servants of Jehovah, / And their righteousness which is of Me, declares Jehovah.
verse.note: This is Jehovah's declaration to the entire universe that the security of Israel is maintained by Christ, who is the covenant for them ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: Ho! Everyone who [xref]a[/xref]thirsts, [note]1[/note]come to the [note]2[/note]waters, / And you who have no money; / Come, [xref]b[/xref]buy and eat; / Yes, come, buy wine and [xref]c[/xref]milk / Without money and without price.
verse.note: In this book God always considers that He is our salvation as living water (cf. [link]12:2-3[/link]). The record concerning the accomplished redemption in [link]ch. 53[/link] is followed in this chapter by the invitation to come to the waters and drink. The call here is like that at the end of the Bible, in [link]Rev. 22:17[/link]. The waters in these two portions of the Word are the redeeming God, the very God who accomplished redemption for us through His incarnation, human living, crucifixion, and resurrection. These waters are both the eternal covenant and the sure mercies shown to David ([link]v. 3[/link]).
[i]Waters[/i] (plural) here reveals that God can be enjoyed not just in one aspect but in many aspects through our continual drinking of Him (cf. [link]John 7:38[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: Why do you spend money for what is not bread, / And the result of your [xref]a[/xref]labor for what does not satisfy? / Hear Me attentively, and eat what is good, / And let your soul delight itself in fatness.

Incline your ear and come to Me; / Hear, so that your soul may live; / And I will make an eternal [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]covenant with you, / Even the sure [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]mercies [i]shown[/i] to [note]3[/note]David.
verse.note: In [link]chs. 55-56[/link] Christ, as the Servant of Jehovah and the embodiment of the Triune God as the living waters ([link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]7:37-38[/link]), is an eternal covenant to Israel ([link]42:6[/link]; [link]49:8[/link]; [link]54:10[/link]; [link]61:8b[/link]), even the sure mercies shown to David, in relation to Israel's prosperity. As such, He is the center of the divine provisions to Israel ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]). See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 42[/link].

In [link]Acts 13:34[/link] Paul interprets the sure mercies as "the holy things of David, the faithful things," and in [link]v. 35[/link] there, he indicates that these things are Christ Himself in resurrection (see note [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 13[/link]). Paul's interpretation is confirmed by [link]v. 4[/link] in this chapter. Christ was incarnated to bring God as grace to us ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]16-17[/link]), and He was crucified and resurrected to become the sure mercies to us in resurrection. Because our situation was miserable and could not match God's grace, Christ, the embodiment of God's grace, became the sure mercies, and through these mercies we are now in the proper position to match God and receive Him as grace (cf. [link]Eph. 2:4[/link] and note 2). In Christ as the sure mercies, God reaches us in His grace to be our enjoyment. Christ is both the sure mercies and the eternal covenant that guarantees these mercies.[br][br]As the sure mercies of God, the resurrected Christ became the base of God's justification to His believers ([link]Acts 13:34-39[/link]; [link]Rom. 4:25[/link]). Based on such a justification in Christ's resurrection, the believers can be sanctified by enjoying Christ, the son of David ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]), as God's sure mercies, i.e., as the Holy One who did not see corruption ([link]Acts 13:35[/link]).

David and all the kings in David's family needed God's mercy ([link]Psa. 51:1[/link]; [link]52:8b[/link]). God promised that the very Christ, who would come out of David's descendants to be the King of kings on the earth ([link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:16[/link]), would be the sure mercies of God toward the royal family of David. Because of Christ as the sure mercies of God, no one could blot out the entire royal family of David (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]; cf. [link]Jer. 33:24-26[/link]). The last king of the royal family of David will be Jesus Christ, the embodiment of God's sure mercies.

verse.text: Indeed, I have given [note]1[/note]Him as a [xref]a[/xref]Witness to the peoples, / A Leader and a Commander to the peoples.
verse.note: This is Christ, who is not only the sure mercies shown to David ([link]v. 3[/link]) but also the Witness, Leader, and Commander to the peoples, the nations ([link]Rev. 1:5a[/link]; [link]3:14a[/link]; [link]Acts 5:31a[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:11-21[/link]).

verse.text: Indeed, you will call a nation that you do not know, / And a nation that does not know you will run to you, / Because of Jehovah your God, even the Holy One of Israel, / For He has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glorified you.
verse.note: To be glorified means that we are brought into God and that God becomes our expression.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Seek Jehovah while He may be found; / [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Call upon Him while He is near.
verse.note: This is to come to the Lord in order to drink of Him ([link]v. 1[/link]).
Calling on the Lord is the way to drink of Him (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Let the wicked forsake his way, / And the [note]1[/note]evildoer, his thoughts; / And let him [xref]a[/xref]return to Jehovah, and He will have compassion on him; / And to our God, for He will pardon abundantly.
verse.note: In the eyes of God, the wicked one, the evildoer, is the one who does not come to drink of Him (cf. note [link]5[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link]).

verse.text: For My [note]1[/note]thoughts are not your thoughts, / And your ways are not My [note]1[/note]ways, declares Jehovah.
verse.note: God's way and God's thought are that we would come to drink of Him freely (cf. [link]John 4:10[/link]; [link]7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:17[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For [i]as[/i] the [xref]a[/xref]heavens are higher than the earth, / So My ways are higher than your ways, / And My thoughts [i]higher[/i] than your thoughts.

For just as the [xref]a[/xref]rain comes down / And the snow from heaven, / And does not return there, / Until it waters the earth / And makes it bear and sprout forth, / That it may give [xref]b[/xref]seed to the [xref]c[/xref]sower and bread to the eater;

So will My [xref]a[/xref]word be which goes forth from My mouth; / It will not return to Me [note]1[/note]vainly, / But it will accomplish what I delight in, / And it will prosper in the matter to which I have [note]2[/note]sent it.
verse.note: Or, empty.

God has sent forth His word to water His people ([link]v. 10[/link]), to sanctify them ([link]John 17:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:26[/link]), to transform them ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]), and to conform them to His image ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]) that the Body of Christ may be built up.

verse.text: For you will [xref]a[/xref]go out with rejoicing, / And you will be led forth in peace; / The mountains and the hills / Will [xref]b[/xref]break forth before you with a ringing shout, / And all the trees of the field will clap [i]their[/i] hands.

In place of the thornbush, the fir tree will come up; / In place of the brier, the myrtle will come up; / And it will be to Jehovah as a [note]1[/note]name, / As an eternal [note]1[/note]sign that will not be cut off.
verse.note: What God is doing in His people by sending forth His word ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]) will be both a name (memorial) to God and an eternal sign (strong proof) that will never be cut off.

verse.text: Thus says Jehovah, / Preserve [note]1[/note]justice and do righteousness, / For My [note]1[/note]salvation is [xref]a[/xref]about to come / And My [note]1[/note]righteousness is [i]about[/i] to be revealed.
verse.note: In its Old Testament usage, the word [i]justice[/i] means the verdict of God's judgment. Justice plus righteousness equals salvation. As the result of Christ's death on the cross for us, God's verdict concerning us, the believers in Christ, is the justice that causes us to be justified, to be made righteous ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]). This justice that makes us righteous is God's salvation coming to us.

verse.text: Blessed is the man who does this, / And the son of man who takes hold of it, / Who keeps the [note]1[/note]Sabbath so as not to profane it / And keeps his hand from doing any evil.
verse.note: According to this book the real meaning of keeping the Sabbath is that we cease from our doing, stop our work, and enjoy what the Lord has done for us, drinking of Him as the waters ([link]12:3[/link]; [link]55:1[/link]). Keeping the Sabbath in this way is to be terminated and replaced by Christ so that we may enter into Him and rest in Him for eternity ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]). The entire Christian life should be such a Sabbath.

verse.text: And let not the son of a foreigner / Who has joined himself to Jehovah speak, saying, / Jehovah will surely separate me from His people; / Nor let the eunuch say, / Now I am a dry tree.
For thus says Jehovah, / To the eunuchs who keep My Sabbaths / And choose what pleases Me, / And hold fast My covenant,
To them I will give in My house and within My walls a memorial and a name / Better than that of sons and daughters; / I will give them an eternal name / Which will not be cut off.

Also the children of the foreigner who join themselves to Jehovah, / To minister to Him and to love the name of Jehovah, / To be servants to Him, / Everyone who keeps the Sabbath so as not to profane it / And holds fast My covenant,

Even these will I cause to come to My holy mountain / And to rejoice in My house of prayer; / Their [xref]a[/xref]burnt offerings and their sacrifices will be acceptable upon My altar; / For [xref]b[/xref]My house will be called a house of prayer for all the peoples.
The Lord Jehovah, who [xref]a[/xref]gathers the outcasts of Israel, declares: / Yet will I gather [note]1[/note][i]others[/i] to Him besides those gathered to Him [i]already.[/i]
verse.note: First, God gathered the Jews to Christ ([link]Acts 2-12[/link]), and then He began to gather the Gentiles from such places as Asia Minor and Macedonia ([link]Acts 13-20[/link]). Today He continues to gather people to Christ from throughout the earth.

verse.text: All you animals of the field, come to eat, / All you animals of the forest.
His watchmen are [xref]a[/xref]blind; / All of them know nothing; / All of them are dumb [xref]b[/xref]dogs, / They cannot bark; / Dreamers who lie down / [i]And[/i] love to slumber.

And these dogs are greedy; / They know no satisfaction. / And they are shepherds / [i]Who[/i] lack understanding. / All of them have turned to their own way, / Each to his own gain, to the last of them.
Come, [i]they say,[/i] let me get some wine, / And let us drink down some liquor; / And tomorrow will be like today, / [i]Only[/i] much more abundant.
The righteous man perishes, / And no one takes it to heart; / And godly men are being swept away, / While no one considers / That the righteous man is being swept away from evil.
He enters into peace; / They rest in their [note]1[/note]beds, / [i]Each[/i] who walks uprightly.
verse.note: I.e., graves.

verse.text: But draw near here, / You children of a sorceress, / You seed of an adulterer and of her who prostitutes herself.
Whom are you mocking, / And against whom are you opening your mouth wide / And sticking out your tongue? / Are you not children of transgression, / A seed of falsehood,
Who inflame yourselves among the [note]1[/note]terebinths, / Under every flourishing tree, / Who slaughter the children in the valleys / Under the clefts of the rocks?
verse.note: Trees used in the worship of idols.

verse.text: Among the smooth [i]stones[/i] of the valley is your portion, / They, yes, they are your lot. / Indeed, to them you have poured out a drink offering, / You have offered a meal offering. / Shall I ease Myself of these?
Upon a high and lofty mountain / You have set your bed. / Indeed, you went up there / To offer sacrifice.

And behind the door and doorpost / You have put your reminder. / For apart from Me, you have uncovered yourself and gone up; / You have extended your bed; / And you have made an agreement for yourself with them; / You loved their bed; you saw [i]their[/i] nakedness.
And you went to the king with oil, / And you increased your perfumes; / You sent your envoys far away / And debased yourself even as far as Sheol.
You were wearied with the length of your way, / [i]Yet[/i] you did not say, It is hopeless; / You found the renewing of your strength, / Therefore you did not weaken.
And whom have you been worried about and feared, / That you have lied and not remembered Me, / Nor taken it to heart? / Was I not silent, and that for a long time, / Yet you did not fear Me?
I will declare your righteousness / And your works, / Yet they will not profit you.

When you cry out, let your heaps [i]of idols[/i] deliver you. / But the wind will carry them all away; / A breath will take [i]them[/i] away.[separator]But he who takes [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]refuge in Me will inherit the land / And possess My holy mountain.
verse.note: To take refuge in the Lord is to enter into Him and stay in Him to enjoy Him. When we stay in the Lord, taking Him as our refuge, we enjoy Him, and eventually we will inherit Him as the land and possess Him as our high mountain.

verse.text: And it will be said, / Cast up, cast up; [xref]a[/xref]prepare the way; / Take up the obstacle out of the way of My people.

For thus says the high and exalted One, / Who inhabits eternity, whose name is [xref]a[/xref]Holy: / I will dwell in the high and holy place, / And with the contrite and [xref]b[/xref]lowly of [note]1[/note]spirit, / To revive the spirit of the lowly / And to revive the heart of the contrite.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 66[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For I will not contend forever, / Nor will I always be angry; / For the spirit would faint before Me, / And the souls which I have made.
Because of the iniquity of his unjust gain I was angry, / And I struck him; I hid Myself and was angry; / And he went on, turning away in the way of his heart.
I have seen his ways / And will heal him; / And I will lead him and restore comfort to him / [i]And[/i] to his mourning ones,
Creating the fruit of the lips: / Peace, peace to him who is [xref]a[/xref]far off and to him who is near, / Says Jehovah; and I will [xref]b[/xref]heal him.
But the [note]1[/note]wicked are like the [xref]a[/xref]tossed sea, / For it cannot be calm, / And its waters toss up mire and mud.
verse.note: The evil condition of the wicked is that they do not come to the Lord to eat and enjoy the Lord (cf. [link]55:1-2[/link]). They do many things, but they do not come to contact the Lord, to take Him, to receive Him, to taste Him, and to enjoy Him. In the sight of God, nothing is more evil than this. Cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 55[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]There is no peace, says my God, for the wicked.
Cry loudly; do not hold back; / Raise your voice like a [xref]a[/xref]trumpet, / And declare to My people their transgression / And to the house of Jacob their sins.

Yet they seek Me day by day / And take delight in knowing My ways, / Like a nation that has done righteousness / And has not forsaken the ordinance of their God. / They ask Me for righteous judgments; / They take [xref]a[/xref]delight in approaching God.

Why have we [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fasted, and yet You do not see? / [i]Why[/i] have we afflicted our soul, and yet You do not acknowledge? / Indeed, on the day of your fast you [note]2[/note]find delight, / And oppress all your laborers.
verse.note: The real meaning of fasting is to stop eating all things other than the Lord Jesus and to not have a taste for anything other than Him. God wants us to stop our doing and be replaced by Christ (keep the Sabbath — [link]56:2[/link]) and to keep away from the taste of anything other than Christ (fast). By resting and fasting we can partake of all that the processed Christ has accomplished for us. In totality, what Christ is and has accomplished is just the divine water ([link]55:1[/link]), which is the consummated Spirit as the consummation of the Triune God for us to drink and enjoy ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]).

In their hypocrisy the house of Jacob fasted, but they did many things in pursuit of their own interests. They did not rest in God nor take Him as their nourishment and life supply (cf. [link]55:1-2[/link]). This was their hypocrisy.

verse.text: Indeed, you [xref]a[/xref]fast for contention and strife, / And to strike with a fist of wickedness; / You do not fast, in the way [i]you do[/i] today, / To make your voice heard on high.

Is such the [xref]a[/xref]fast that I choose, / The day when a man afflicts his soul? / Is it for bowing his head like a rush / And for spreading out sackcloth and ashes as his bed? / Will you call this a fast, / And an acceptable day to Jehovah?
Is this not the fast that I choose, / To loosen the bonds of wickedness, / To undo the bands of the yoke, / And to let the oppressed go [xref]a[/xref]free, / And to break every yoke?

Is it not to [xref]a[/xref]divide your bread to the [xref]b[/xref]hungry, / And to bring the wandering poor home; / When you see the naked, to cover him, / And not to hide yourself from your own flesh?

Then your [xref]a[/xref]light will break forth like the dawn, / And your recovery will speedily spring forth. / And your righteousness will go before you; / The [xref]b[/xref]glory of Jehovah will guard you from behind.

Then you will call, and Jehovah will answer; / You will cry out, and He will say, Here I am.[separator]If you remove the yoke from your midst, / The pointing of the finger and the speaking of wickedness,
And if you draw out your soul to the hungry / And satisfy the desires of the afflicted; / Then your light will rise in the darkness, / And your gloom will be like midday;

And Jehovah will [xref]a[/xref]guide you continually, / And satisfy your soul in the dry times, / And strengthen your bones; / And you will be like a watered [xref]b[/xref]garden, / And like a [xref]c[/xref]spring of water, / Whose waters do not deceive.

And those who are of you will [xref]a[/xref]rebuild the ancient ruins; / You will raise up the foundations of generation upon generation; / And you will be called the repairer of the breach, / The restorer of the paths in which to dwell.

If you turn back your foot from the Sabbath, / From doing whatever you please on My holy day, / And call the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath a delight, / That which is holy to Jehovah honorable, / And honor it, not doing your own ways, / Nor finding your own pleasure and speaking [i]idle[/i] words;

Then you will have delight in Jehovah; / And I will cause you to ride upon the [xref]a[/xref]heights of the earth, / And I will feed you [i]with[/i] the inheritance of Jacob your father; / For the mouth of Jehovah has spoken.
No, Jehovah's hand is not [xref]a[/xref]so short that it cannot save; / Nor is His ear so heavy that it cannot hear.
But your iniquities have become a separation / Between you and your God, / And your sins have hidden [i]His[/i] face / From you so that He does [xref]a[/xref]not hear.
For your hands are defiled with [xref]a[/xref]blood, / And your fingers with iniquity; / Your lips have spoken falsehood, / Your tongue has muttered injustice.
No one sues righteously, / And no one pleads in truth; / They trust in vanity and speak lies; / [xref]a[/xref]They conceive mischief and bring forth iniquity.
They hatch adders' eggs / And weave the spider's web; / He who eats of their eggs dies, / And that which is crushed breaks forth into a viper.
Their webs will not become garments, / Nor will they cover themselves with their works; / Their works are works of iniquity, / And an act of violence is in their palms.
[xref]a[/xref]Their feet run toward evil, / And they hasten to shed innocent blood; / Their thoughts are thoughts of iniquity; / [xref]b[/xref]Desolation and destruction are in their highways.
[xref]a[/xref]The way of peace they do not know, / And there is no justice in their course; / They have made their paths crooked; / Whoever goes on it does not know peace.
